src: she lifted the princess from the earth, and so locks her in embracing, as if she would pin her to her heart that she might no more be in danger of losing.
trg: The dignity of this act was worth the audience of kings and princes; for by such was it acted.

src: You are married?
trg: We are not, sir, nor are we like to be; The stars, I see, will kiss the valleys first: The odds for high and low's alike.

src: I had rather be a country servant-maid Than a great queen, with this condition, To be thus taunted, scorn'd, and baited at: Small joy have I in being England's queen.
trg: And lessen'd be that small, God, I beseech thee! Thy honour, state and seat is due to me.

src: You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?
trg: Resolved. resolved.

src: Ah, Warwick, why hast thou withdrawn thyself? Thy brother's blood the thirsty earth hath drunk, Broach'd with the steely point of Clifford's lance;
trg: And in the very pangs of death he cried, Like to a dismal clangour heard from far, 'Warwick, revenge! brother, revenge my death!

src: That would be ten days' wonder at the least.
trg: That's a day longer than a wonder lasts.

src: O, he's a limb that has but a disease; Mortal, to cut it off; to cure it, easy. What has he done to Rome that's worthy death?
trg: Killing our enemies, the blood he hath lost-- Which, I dare vouch, is more than that he hath, By many an ounce--he dropp'd it for his country;

src: Mark your divorce, young sir, Whom son I dare not call; thou art too base To be acknowledged: thou a sceptre's heir, That thus affect'st a sheep-hook!
trg: Thou old traitor, I am sorry that by hanging thee I can But shorten thy life one week. And thou, fresh piece Of excellent witchcraft, who of force must know The royal fool thou copest with,--

src: In his tongue.
trg: Whose tongue?

src: Because that, like a Jack, thou keep'st the stroke Betwixt thy begging and my meditation. I am not in the giving vein to-day.
trg: Why, then resolve me whether you will or no.

src: Have done! for shame, if not for charity.
trg: Urge neither charity nor shame to me: Uncharitably with me have you dealt, And shamefully by you my hopes are butcher'd.

src: Well; come to me to-morrow.
Your will be done: this must my comfort be, Sun that warms you here shall shine on me; And those his golden beams to you here lent Shall point on me and gild my banishment.
trg: Norfolk, for thee remains a heavier doom, Which I with some unwillingness pronounce: The sly slow hours shall not determinate The dateless limit of thy dear exile;

src: I went To this pernicious caitiff deputy,--
trg: That's somewhat madly spoken.

src: Come, quench your blushes and present yourself That which you are, mistress o' the feast: come on, And bid us welcome to your sheep-shearing, As your good flock shall prosper.
'Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.
trg: Remember our reward, when the deed is done.

src: This is a poor epitome of yours, Which by the interpretation of full time May show like all yourself.
trg: The god of soldiers, With the consent of supreme Jove, inform Thy thoughts with nobleness;

src: I beseech your graces both to pardon me; His majesty hath straitly given in charge That no man shall have private conference, Of what degree soever, with his brother.
trg: Even so; an't please your worship, Brakenbury, You may partake of any thing we say: We speak no treason, man:

src: come, musicians, play. A hall, a hall! give room! and foot it, girls. More light, you knaves; and turn the tables up, And quench the fire, the room is grown too hot.
trg: Ah, sirrah, this unlook'd-for sport comes well. Nay, sit, nay, sit, good cousin Capulet; For you and I are past our dancing days: How long is't now since last yourself and I Were in a mask?

src: With all my heart I pardon him.
trg: A god on earth thou art.

src: O, spare me not, my brother Edward's son, For that I was his father Edward's son; That blood already, like the pelican, Hast thou tapp'd out and drunkenly caroused:
trg: My brother Gloucester, plain well-meaning soul, Whom fair befal in heaven 'mongst happy souls! May be a precedent and witness good That thou respect'st not spilling Edward's blood:
What is that Barnardine who is to be executed in the afternoon?

src: Will the king come, that I may breathe my last In wholesome counsel to his unstaid youth?
trg: Vex not yourself, nor strive not with your breath; For all in vain comes counsel to his ear.

src: Think you, my lord, this little prating York Was not incensed by his subtle mother To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?
trg: No doubt, no doubt; O, 'tis a parlous boy; Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable He is all the mother's, from the top to toe.
Now tell me, madam, do you love your children?

src: Our king, being ready to leap out of himself for joy of his found daughter, as if that joy were now become a loss, cries 'O, thy mother, thy mother!' then asks Bohemia forgiveness;
trg: then embraces his son-in-law; then again worries he his daughter with clipping her; now he thanks the old shepherd, which stands by like a weather-bitten conduit of many kings' reigns.

src: Our scene is alter'd from a serious thing, And now changed to 'The Beggar and the King.' My dangerous cousin, let your mother in: I know she is come to pray for your foul sin.
trg: If thou do pardon, whosoever pray, More sins for this forgiveness prosper may. This fester'd joint cut off, the rest rest sound; This let alone will all the rest confound.

src: Despair not, madam.
trg: Who shall hinder me? I will despair, and be at enmity With cozening hope:

src: Since I am put to know that your own science Exceeds, in that, the lists of all advice My strength can give you:
trg: then no more remains, But that to your sufficiency, as your Worth is able, And let them work.

src: Women will love her, that she is a woman More worth than any man; men, that she is The rarest of all women.
trg: Go, Cleomenes; Yourself, assisted with your honour'd friends, Bring them to our embracement. Still, 'tis strange He thus should steal upon us.

src: What cursed foot wanders this way to-night, To cross my obsequies and true love's rite? What with a torch! muffle me, night, awhile.
trg: Give me that mattock and the wrenching iron. Hold, take this letter; early in the morning See thou deliver it to my lord and father. Give me the light:

src: Where is thy conscience now?
trg: In the Duke of Gloucester's purse.

src: Claudio, whom here you have warrant to execute, is no greater forfeit to the law than Angelo who hath sentenced him.
trg: To make you understand this in a manifested effect, I crave but four days' respite; for the which you are to do me both a present and a dangerous courtesy.

src: Yes, certain, there's a letter for you; I saw't.
trg: A letter for me! it gives me an estate of seven years' health; in which time I will make a lip at the physician:

src: By so much is the wonder in extremes.
trg: Well, jest on, brothers: I can tell you both Her suit is granted for her husband's lands.

src: Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests; I will be sure my Katharina shall be fine.
trg: I know not what to say: but give me your hands; God send you joy, Petruchio! 'tis a match.

src: What manner of fellow was he that robbed you?
trg: A fellow, sir, that I have known to go about with troll-my-dames; I knew him once a servant of the prince:

src: Ha! am I king? 'tis so: but Edward lives.
trg: True, noble prince.

src: I know my duty; you are all undutiful: Lascivious Edward, and thou perjured George, And thou mis-shapen Dick, I tell ye all I am your better, traitors as ye are:
trg: And thou usurp'st my father's right and mine.

src: I pray you, answer him.
trg: Peace and prosperity! Who is't that calls

src: How! traitor!
trg: Nay, temperately; your promise.

src: O me! this sight of death is as a bell, That warns my old age to a sepulchre.
trg: Come, Montague; for thou art early up, To see thy son and heir more early down.

src: Well, go thy ways, old lad; for thou shalt ha't.
trg: 'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.

src: Didst thou not say he comes?
trg: Who? that Petruchio came?

src: Why, Romeo, art thou mad?
trg: Not mad, but bound more than a mad-man is; Shut up in prison, kept without my food, Whipp'd and tormented and--God-den, good fellow.

src: I humbly thank you.
trg: It grieves me for the death of Claudio; But there's no remedy.

src: Whether to knock against the gates of Rome, Or rudely visit them in parts remote, To fright them, ere destroy. But come in: Let me commend thee first to those that shall Say yea to thy desires.
trg: A thousand welcomes! And more a friend than e'er an enemy; Yet, Marcius, that was much. Your hand: most welcome!

src: let him be Until a time may serve: for present vengeance, Take it on her. Camillo and Polixenes Laugh at me, make their pastime at my sorrow:
trg: They should not laugh if I could reach them, nor Shall she within my power.

src: Then cursed she Hastings, then cursed she Buckingham, Then cursed she Richard.
trg: O, remember, God To hear her prayers for them, as now for us And for my sister and her princely sons, Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood, Which, as thou know'st, unjustly must be spilt.

src: And that same vengeance doth he hurl on thee, For false forswearing and for murder too: Thou didst receive the holy sacrament, To fight in quarrel of the house of Lancaster.
trg: And, like a traitor to the name of God, Didst break that vow; and with thy treacherous blade Unrip'dst the bowels of thy sovereign's son.

src: If to have done the thing you gave in charge Beget your happiness, be happy then, For it is done, my lord.
trg: But didst thou see them dead?

src: Thy pains, Fitzwater, shall not be forgot; Right noble is thy merit, well I wot.
trg: The grand conspirator, Abbot of Westminster, With clog of conscience and sour melancholy Hath yielded up his body to the grave;

src: The commons will not then be satisfied.
trg: They shall be satisfied: I'll read enough, When I do see the very book indeed Where all my sins are writ, and that's myself. Give me the glass, and therein will I read. No deeper wrinkles yet?

src: The veins unfill'd, our blood is cold, and then We pout upon the morning, are unapt To give or to forgive;
trg: but when we have stuff'd These and these conveyances of our blood With wine and feeding, we have suppler souls Than in our priest-like fasts:

src: Rode he on Barbary? Tell me, gentle friend, How went he under him?
trg: So proudly as if he disdain'd the ground.

src: It is my will, the which if thou respect, Show a fair presence and put off these frowns, And ill-beseeming semblance for a feast.
trg: It fits, when such a villain is a guest: I'll not endure him.

src: and your affections are A sick man's appetite, who desires most that Which would increase his evil. He that depends Upon your favours swims with fins of lead And hews down oaks with rushes. Hang ye!
trg: Trust Ye? With every minute you do change a mind, And call him noble that was now your hate, Him vile that was your garland.

src: Why, they stay at door, sir.
trg: O, father, you'll know more of that hereafter. Is it not too far gone? 'Tis time to part them. He's simple and tells much. How now, fair shepherd!

src: How! bribe me?
trg: Ay, with such gifts that heaven shall share with you.

src: That he consents, if Warwick yield consent; For on thy fortune I repose myself.
trg: Why, then, though loath, yet must I be content: We'll yoke together, like a double shadow To Henry's body, and supply his place;

src: As in a theatre, the eyes of men, After a well-graced actor leaves the stage, Are idly bent on him that enters next, Thinking his prattle to be tedious;
trg: Even so, or with much more contempt, men's eyes Did scowl on gentle Richard; no man cried 'God save him!' No joyful tongue gave him his welcome home: But dust was thrown upon his sacred head:

src: Deceitful Warwick! it was thy device By this alliance to make void my suit: Before thy coming Lewis was Henry's friend.
trg: And still is friend to him and Margaret: But if your title to the crown be weak, As may appear by Edward's good success, Then 'tis but reason that I be released From giving aid which late I promised.

src: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?
trg: Where is your sister, and Hortensio's wife?

src: Who knows not that?
trg: Thou, it seems, that calls for company to countenance her.

src: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.
trg: Sir, here's the door, this is Lucentio's house: My father's bears more toward the market-place; Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.

src: Now, sir, her father counts it dangerous That she doth give her sorrow so much sway, And in his wisdom hastes our marriage, To stop the inundation of her tears;
trg: Which, too much minded by herself alone, May be put from her by society: Now do you know the reason of this haste.

src: Pluck up thy spirits; look cheerfully upon me. Here love; thou see'st how diligent I am To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee: I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks.
trg: What, not a word? Nay, then thou lovest it not; And all my pains is sorted to no proof. Here, take away this dish.

src: O prince, I conjure thee, as thou believest There is another comfort than this world, That thou neglect me not, with that opinion That I am touch'd with madness!
trg: Make not impossible That which but seems unlike: 'tis not impossible But one, the wicked'st caitiff on the ground, May seem as shy, as grave, as just, as absolute As Angelo;

src: Why, our battalion trebles that account: Besides, the king's name is a tower of strength, Which they upon the adverse party want. Up with my tent there!
trg: Valiant gentlemen, Let us survey the vantage of the field Call for some men of sound direction Let's want no discipline, make no delay, For, lords, to-morrow is a busy day.

src: O thou well skill'd in curses, stay awhile, And teach me how to curse mine enemies!
trg: Forbear to sleep the nights, and fast the days; Compare dead happiness with living woe; Think that thy babes were fairer than they were, And he that slew them fouler than he is:

src: And for these great affairs do ask some charge, Towards our assistance we do seize to us The plate, corn, revenues and moveables, Whereof our uncle Gaunt did stand possess'd.
trg: How long shall I be patient? ah, how long Shall tender duty make me suffer wrong? I am the last of noble Edward's sons, Of whom thy father, Prince of Wales, was first:

src: Now will I in, to take some privy order, To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight; And to give notice, that no manner of person At any time have recourse unto the princes.
trg: This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings; Which in a set hand fairly is engross'd, That it may be this day read over in Paul's. And mark how well the sequel hangs together:

src: Do, good my lord, lest all the land do rue it.
trg: Would you enforce me to a world of care? Well, call them again. I am not made of stone, But penetrable to your. kind entreats, Albeit against my conscience and my soul.

src: Henry now lives in Scotland at his ease, Where having nothing, nothing can he lose. And as for you yourself, our quondam queen, You have a father able to maintain you;
trg: And better 'twere you troubled him than France.

src: He could never come better; he shall come in. I love a ballad but even too well, if it be doleful matter merrily set down, or a very pleasant thing indeed and sung lamentably.
trg: He hath songs for man or woman, of all sizes; no milliner can so fit his customers with gloves: he has the prettiest love-songs for maids; so without bawdry, which is strange;

src: Who told me, in the field by Tewksbury When Oxford had me down, he rescued me, And said, 'Dear brother, live, and be a king'?
trg: Who told me, when we both lay in the field Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me Even in his own garments, and gave himself, All thin and naked, to the numb cold night?

src: Most holy sir, I thank you.
trg: My business is a word or two with Claudio.

src: Ay, now my sovereign speaketh like himself; And now will I be Edward's champion.
trg: Sound trumpet; Edward shall be here proclaim'd: Come, fellow-soldier, make thou proclamation.

src: my stay To you a charge and trouble: to save both, Farewell, our brother.
trg: Tongue-tied, our queen? speak you.

src: One word, good friend. Lucio, a word with you.
trg: A hundred, if they'll do you any good. Is lechery so look'd after?

src: would I had died a maid And never seen thee, never borne thee son, Seeing thou hast proved so unnatural a father Hath he deserved to lose his birthright thus?
trg: Father, you cannot disinherit me: If you be king, why should not I succeed?

src: What, not an oath? nay, then the world goes hard When Clifford cannot spare his friends an oath. I know by that he's dead;
trg: Ay, but he's dead: off with the traitor's head, And rear it in the place your father's stands. And now to London with triumphant march, There to be crowned England's royal king:

src: Take him over the costard with the hilts of thy sword, and then we will chop him in the malmsey-butt in the next room.
trg: O excellent devise! make a sop of him.

src: so his successor Was like to be the best.
trg: Good Paulina, Who hast the memory of Hermione, I know, in honour, O, that ever I Had squared me to thy counsel!

src: He's right noble: Let him be call'd for.
trg: Call Coriolanus.

src: And of our labours thou shalt reap the gain.
Here comes the queen, whose looks bewray her anger: I'll steal away.
trg: Exeter, so will I.

src: I am ashamed: does not the stone rebuke me For being more stone than it?
trg: O royal piece, There's magic in thy majesty, which has My evils conjured to remembrance and From thy admiring daughter took the spirits, Standing like stone with thee.

src: So dear I loved the man, that I must weep. I took him for the plainest harmless creature That breathed upon this earth a Christian;
trg: Made him my book wherein my soul recorded The history of all her secret thoughts:

src: For even the day before, she broke her brow: And then my husband--God be with his soul! A' was a merry man--took up the child: 'Yea,' quoth he, 'dost thou fall upon thy face?
trg: Thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit; Wilt thou not, Jule?' and, by my holidame, The pretty wretch left crying and said 'Ay.' To see, now, how a jest shall come about!

src: Sister, content you in my discontent. Sir, to your pleasure humbly I subscribe: My books and instruments shall be my company, On them to took and practise by myself.
trg: Hark, Tranio! thou may'st hear Minerva speak.

src: True, The people are the city.
trg: By the consent of all, we were establish'd The people's magistrates.

src: You are retired, As if you were a feasted one and not The hostess of the meeting: pray you, bid These unknown friends to's welcome; for it is A way to make us better friends, more known.
trg: Come, quench your blushes and present yourself That which you are, mistress o' the feast: come on, And bid us welcome to your sheep-shearing, As your good flock shall prosper.

src: Hie to your chamber: I'll find Romeo To comfort you: I wot well where he is. Hark ye, your Romeo will be here at night: I'll to him; he is hid at Laurence' cell.
trg: O, find him! give this ring to my true knight, And bid him come to take his last farewell.

src: A dish that I do love to feed upon.
trg: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.

src: That sort was well fished for.
trg: When I wore it at your daughter's marriage?

src: 'Tis even so; yet you are Warwick still.
trg: Come, Warwick, take the time; kneel down, kneel down: Nay, when? strike now, or else the iron cools.

src: But when we saw our sunshine made thy spring, And that thy summer bred us no increase, We set the axe to thy usurping root;
trg: And though the edge hath something hit ourselves, Yet, know thou, since we have begun to strike, We'll never leave till we have hewn thee down, Or bathed thy growing with our heated bloods.

src: I will, and know her mind early to-morrow; To-night she is mew'd up to her heaviness.
trg: Sir Paris, I will make a desperate tender Of my child's love: I think she will be ruled In all respects by me; nay, more, I doubt it not. Wife, go you to her ere you go to bed;

src: Ay, but the case is alter'd: When you disgraced me in my embassade, Then I degraded you from being king, And come now to create you Duke of York. Alas!
trg: Yea, brother of Clarence, are thou here too? Nay, then I see that Edward needs must down.

src: It is foul weather in us all, good sir, When you are cloudy.
trg: Foul weather?
I know not, sir.

src: Silence! one word more Shall make me chide thee, if not hate thee. What! An advocate for an imposter! hush! Thou think'st there is no more such shapes as he, Having seen but him and Caliban:
trg: foolish wench! To the most of men this is a Caliban And they to him are angels.

src: Why should he die, sir?
trg: Why? For filling a bottle with a tundish. I would the duke we talk of were returned again: the ungenitured agent will unpeople the province with continency;

src: Hear'st thou, Mars?
trg: Name not the god, thou boy of tears!

src: Come, poor babe: I have heard, but not believed, the spirits o' the dead May walk again: if such thing be, thy mother Appear'd to me last night, for ne'er was dream So like a waking.
trg: To me comes a creature, Sometimes her head on one side, some another; I never saw a vessel of like sorrow, So fill'd and so becoming:

src: Is it upon record, or else reported Successively from age to age, he built it?
trg: Upon record, my gracious lord.

src: those being all my study, The government I cast upon my brother And to my state grew stranger, being transported And rapt in secret studies. Thy false uncle-- Dost thou attend me?
trg: Sir, most heedfully.

src: We hear not of him, neither need we fear him; His remedies are tame i' the present peace And quietness of the people, which before Were in wild hurry.
trg: We stood to't in good time. Is this Menenius?

src: Ill blows the wind that profits nobody. This man, whom hand to hand I slew in fight, May be possessed with some store of crowns;
trg: And I, that haply take them from him now, May yet ere night yield both my life and them To some man else, as this dead man doth me. Who's this? O God!

src: No shame but mine: I must, forsooth, be forced To give my hand opposed against my heart Unto a mad-brain rudesby full of spleen; Who woo'd in haste and means to wed at leisure.
trg: I told you, I, he was a frantic fool, Hiding his bitter jests in blunt behavior:

src: I have lived To see inherited my very wishes And the buildings of my fancy: only There's one thing wanting, which I doubt not but Our Rome will cast upon thee.
trg: Know, good mother, I had rather be their servant in my way, Than sway with them in theirs.

src: Sweet peace conduct his sweet soul to the bosom Of good old Abraham! Lords appellants, Your differences shall all rest under gage Till we assign you to your days of trial.
trg: Great Duke of Lancaster, I come to thee From plume-pluck'd Richard; who with willing soul Adopts thee heir, and his high sceptre yields To the possession of thy royal hand:

src: His grace looks cheerfully and smooth to-day; There's some conceit or other likes him well, When he doth bid good morrow with such a spirit.
trg: I think there's never a man in Christendom That can less hide his love or hate than he; For by his face straight shall you know his heart.

src: Towards Chertsey, noble lord?
trg: No, to White-Friars; there attend my coining. Was ever woman in this humour woo'd? Was ever woman in this humour won? I'll have her; but I will not keep her long. What!

src: He was a kind of nothing, titleless, Till he had forged himself a name o' the fire Of burning Rome.
trg: Why, so: you have made good work! A pair of tribunes that have rack'd for Rome, To make coals cheap,--a noble memory!

src: You lie, in faith; for you are call'd plain Kate, And bonny Kate and sometimes Kate the curst;
trg: But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom Kate of Kate Hall, my super-dainty Kate, For dainties are all Kates, and therefore, Kate, Take this of me, Kate of my consolation;

src: Think you so? Which way do you judge my wit would fly?
trg: Nay, your wit will not so soon out as another man's will;'tis strongly wedged up in a block-head, but if it were at liberty, 'twould, sure, southward.

src: Mistress, what's your opinion of your sister?
trg: That, being mad herself, she's madly mated.

src: Where is the provost?
trg: Here, if it like your honour.

src: O serpent heart, hid with a flowering face! Did ever dragon keep so fair a cave? Beautiful tyrant! fiend angelical! Dove-feather'd raven! wolvish-ravening lamb! Despised substance of divinest show!
trg: Just opposite to what thou justly seem'st, A damned saint, an honourable villain!

src: Come, bustle, bustle; caparison my horse. Call up Lord Stanley, bid him bring his power: I will lead forth my soldiers to the plain, And thus my battle shall be ordered:
trg: My foreward shall be drawn out all in length, Consisting equally of horse and foot;

src: Ay, sir, by Mistress Overdone's means: but as she spit in his face, so she defied him.
trg: Sir, if it please your honour, this is not so.

src: Thou and thy brother both shall buy this treason Even with the dearest blood your bodies bear.
trg: The harder match'd, the greater victory: My mind presageth happy gain and conquest.

src: The gods give you joy, sir, heartily!
trg: Most sweet voices! Better it is to die, better to starve, Than crave the hire which first we do deserve.

src: Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been, Pisa renowned for grave citizens.
trg: Among them know you one Vincentio?

src: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads?
trg: No, to the dignity and height of honour The high imperial type of this earth's glory.

src: Thy deed, inhuman and unnatural, Provokes this deluge most unnatural. O God, which this blood madest, revenge his death! O earth, which this blood drink'st revenge his death!
trg: Either heaven with lightning strike the murderer dead, Or earth, gape open wide and eat him quick, As thou dost swallow up this good king's blood Which his hell-govern'd arm hath butchered!

src: Nay, that's not so.
trg: I mean, sir, in delay We waste our lights in vain, like lamps by day. Take our good meaning, for our judgment sits Five times in that ere once in our five wits.

src: O hear me, Isabella!
trg: Vouchsafe a word, young sister, but one word.

src: I have, my liege.
trg: Tell me, moreover, hast thou sounded him, If he appeal the duke on ancient malice; Or worthily, as a good subject should, On some known ground of treachery in him?

src: Yea, brother of Clarence, are thou here too? Nay, then I see that Edward needs must down.
trg: Yet, Warwick, in despite of all mischance, Of thee thyself and all thy complices, Edward will always bear himself as king:

src: Good, speak to the mariners: fall to't, yarely, or we run ourselves aground: bestir, bestir.
trg: Heigh, my hearts! cheerly, cheerly, my hearts! yare, yare! Take in the topsail. Tend to the master's whistle. Blow, till thou burst thy wind, if room enough!

src: she is my house, My household stuff, my field, my barn, My horse, my ox, my ass, my any thing; And here she stands, touch her whoever dare;
trg: I'll bring mine action on the proudest he That stops my way in Padua. Grumio, Draw forth thy weapon, we are beset with thieves; Rescue thy mistress, if thou be a man.

src: Away betimes, before his forces join, And take the great-grown traitor unawares: Brave warriors, march amain towards Coventry. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Where is the post that came from valiant Oxford? How far hence is thy lord, mine honest fellow?

src: How fondly dost thou spur a forward horse! If I dare eat, or drink, or breathe, or live, I dare meet Surrey in a wilderness, And spit upon him, whilst I say he lies, And lies, and lies:
trg: there is my bond of faith, To tie thee to my strong correction. As I intend to thrive in this new world, Aumerle is guilty of my true appeal:

src: If you think well to carry this as you may, the doubleness of the benefit defends the deceit from reproof. What think you of it?
trg: The image of it gives me content already; and I trust it will grow to a most prosperous perfection.
Are you mankind?

src: For that, being one o' the lowest, basest, poorest, Of this most wise rebellion, thou go'st foremost: Thou rascal, that art worst in blood to run, Lead'st first to win some vantage.
trg: But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs: Rome and her rats are at the point of battle; The one side must have bale. Hail, noble Marcius!

src: As little joy, my lord, as you suppose You should enjoy, were you this country's king, As little joy may you suppose in me. That I enjoy, being the queen thereof.
trg: A little joy enjoys the queen thereof; For I am she, and altogether joyless. I can no longer hold me patient.

src: I shall desire you, sir, to give me leave To have free speech with you; and it concerns me To look into the bottom of my place: A power I have, but of what strength and nature I am not yet instructed.
trg: 'Tis so with me. Let us withdraw together, And we may soon our satisfaction have Touching that point.

src: Here in this country, where we now remain.
trg: I was anointed king at nine months old; My father and my grandfather were kings, And you were sworn true subjects unto me: And tell me, then, have you not broke your oaths?

src: Would yet he had lived! A lack, when once our grace we have forgot, Nothing goes right: we would, and we would not.
trg: These letters at fit time deliver me The provost knows our purpose and our plot. The matter being afoot, keep your instruction, And hold you ever to our special drift;

src: What, ho! my lord!
Ten days ago I drown'd these news in tears; And now, to add more measure to your woes, I come to tell you things sith then befall'n.
trg: After the bloody fray at Wakefield fought, Where your brave father breathed his latest gasp, Tidings, as swiftly as the posts could run, Were brought me of your loss and his depart.

src: Good news, good news; the ladies have prevail'd, The Volscians are dislodged, and Marcius gone: A merrier day did never yet greet Rome, No, not the expulsion of the Tarquins.
trg: Friend, Art thou certain this is true? is it most certain?

src: Too light for such a swain as you to catch; And yet as heavy as my weight should be.
trg: Should be! should--buzz!

src: I shall, between this and supper, tell you most strange things from Rome; all tending to the good of their adversaries. Have you an army ready, say you?
trg: A most royal one; the centurions and their charges, distinctly billeted, already in the entertainment, and to be on foot at an hour's warning.

src: victory sits on our helms.
trg: Rescue, my Lord of Norfolk, rescue, rescue! The king enacts more wonders than a man, Daring an opposite to every danger:

src: Neither.
trg: What, neither?

src: Pardon me, madam: little joy have I To breathe this news; yet what I say is true. King Richard, he is in the mighty hold Of Bolingbroke: their fortunes both are weigh'd:
trg: In your lord's scale is nothing but himself, And some few vanities that make him light;

src: shall we serve heaven With less respect than we do minister To our gross selves? Good, good my lord, bethink you; Who is it that hath died for this offence? There's many have committed it.
Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?
trg: I would your duty were as foolish too: The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca, Hath cost me an hundred crowns since supper-time.

src: Yea.
trg: When, I beseech you? that in his reprieve, Longer or shorter, he may be so fitted That his soul sicken not.

src: Though little fire grows great with little wind, Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all: So I to her and so she yields to me; For I am rough and woo not like a babe.
trg: Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed! But be thou arm'd for some unhappy words.

src: And, toward the education of your daughters, I here bestow a simple instrument, And this small packet of Greek and Latin books: If you accept them, then their worth is great.
trg: Lucentio is your name; of whence, I pray?

src: Ours of true zeal and deep integrity. Our prayers do out-pray his; then let them have That mercy which true prayer ought to have.
trg: Good aunt, stand up.

src: Subjects may challenge nothing of their sovereigns; But if an humble prayer may prevail, I then crave pardon of your majesty.
trg: For what, lieutenant? for well using me? Nay, be thou sure I'll well requite thy kindness, For that it made my imprisonment a pleasure;

src: And indeed, sir, there are cozeners abroad; therefore it behoves men to be wary.
trg: Fear not thou, man, thou shalt lose nothing here.

src: Nothing so certain as your anchors, who Do their best office, if they can but stay you Where you'll be loath to be:
trg: besides you know Prosperity's the very bond of love, Whose fresh complexion and whose heart together Affliction alters.

src: And summon him to-morrow to the Tower, To sit about the coronation. If thou dost find him tractable to us, Encourage him, and show him all our reasons:
trg: If he be leaden, icy-cold, unwilling, Be thou so too; and so break off your talk, And give us notice of his inclination:

src: Now will I write letters to Angelo,-- The provost, he shall bear them, whose contents Shall witness to him I am near at home, And that, by great injunctions, I am bound To enter publicly:
trg: him I'll desire To meet me at the consecrated fount A league below the city; and from thence, By cold gradation and well-balanced form, We shall proceed with Angelo.

src: Pardon me, God, I knew not what I did! And pardon, father, for I knew not thee! My tears shall wipe away these bloody marks; And no more words till they have flow'd their fill.
trg: O piteous spectacle! O bloody times! Whiles lions war and battle for their dens, Poor harmless lambs abide their enmity. Weep, wretched man, I'll aid thee tear for tear;

src: Have you a catalogue Of all the voices that we have procured Set down by the poll?
trg: I have; 'tis ready.

src: Lives my sweet son?
trg: Pardon, dear father.

src: Bound by my charity and my blest order, I come to visit the afflicted spirits Here in the prison.
trg: Do me the common right To let me see them and to make me know The nature of their crimes, that I may minister To them accordingly.

src: How will the country for these woful chances Misthink the king and not be satisfied!
trg: Was ever son so rued a father's death?

src: that thereby he may gather The ground of your ill-will, and so remove it.
trg: I cannot tell: the world is grown so bad, That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch: Since every Jack became a gentleman There's many a gentle person made a Jack.

src: you have well saved me a day's journey.
trg: There hath been in Rome strange insurrections; the people against the senators, patricians, and nobles.

src: You had more beard when I last saw you; but your favour is well approved by your tongue. What's the news in Rome? I have a note from the Volscian state, to find you out there:
trg: you have well saved me a day's journey.

src: 'Twill be deliver'd back on good condition.
trg: Condition! I would I were a Roman; for I cannot, Being a Volsce, be that I am. Condition! What good condition can a treaty find I' the part that is at mercy?

src: Hail, lords! I am return'd your soldier, No more infected with my country's love Than when I parted hence, but still subsisting Under your great command.
trg: You are to know That prosperously I have attempted and With bloody passage led your wars even to The gates of Rome.

src: Eleven, sir.
trg: I pray you home to dinner with me.

src: though I be old, I doubt not but to ride as fast as York: And never will I rise up from the ground Till Bolingbroke have pardon'd thee. Away, be gone!
trg: Can no man tell me of my unthrifty son? 'Tis full three months since I did see him last; If any plague hang over us, 'tis he. I would to God, my lords, he might be found:

src: I would your cambric were sensible as your finger, that you might leave pricking it for pity. Come, you shall go with us.
trg: No, good madam, pardon me; indeed, I will not forth.

src: and it cried bitterly: 'Yea,' quoth my husband,'fall'st upon thy face? Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age; Wilt thou not, Jule?' it stinted and said 'Ay.'
trg: And stint thou too, I pray thee, nurse, say I.

src: Well begun, Tranio.
trg: Sir, a word ere you go; Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?

src: Either you must Confess yourselves wondrous malicious, Or be accused of folly. I shall tell you A pretty tale: it may be you have heard it;
trg: But, since it serves my purpose, I will venture To stale 't a little more.

src: I might call him A thing divine, for nothing natural I ever saw so noble.
No, Exeter, these graces challenge grace: And when the lion fawns upon the lamb, The lamb will never cease to follow him.
trg: Hark, hark, my lord! what shouts are these?

src: Go, Lovel, with all speed to Doctor Shaw; Go thou to Friar Penker; bid them both Meet me within this hour at Baynard's Castle.
trg: Now will I in, to take some privy order, To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight; And to give notice, that no manner of person At any time have recourse unto the princes.

src: Why, boy, how is it?
trg: I would you did but see how it chafes, how it rages, how it takes up the shore! but that's not the point. O, the most piteous cry of the poor souls! sometimes to see 'em, and not to see 'em;

src: The lark, that tirra-lyra chants, With heigh! with heigh! the thrush and the jay, Are summer songs for me and my aunts, While we lie tumbling in the hay.
trg: I have served Prince Florizel and in my time wore three-pile; but now I am out of service: But shall I go mourn for that, my dear? The pale moon shines by night:

src: No might nor greatness in mortality Can censure 'scape; back-wounding calumny The whitest virtue strikes. What king so strong Can tie the gall up in the slanderous tongue? But who comes here?
trg: Go; away with her to prison!

src: A very mean meaning.
trg: Right, I mean you.

src: Tapster; a poor widow's tapster.
trg: Your mistress' name?

src: For which I must not plead, but that I am At war 'twixt will and will not.
trg: Well; the matter?

src: But how long shall that title 'ever' last?
trg: Sweetly in force unto her fair life's end.

src: Return to the tribunes.
trg: Well, what then? what then?

src: He, but a duke, would have his son a king, And raise his issue, like a loving sire;
trg: Thou, being a king, blest with a goodly son, Didst yield consent to disinherit him, Which argued thee a most unloving father. Unreasonable creatures feed their young;

src: 'Tis much. Servants, leave me and her alone. Madam, undress you and come now to bed.
trg: Thrice noble lord, let me entreat of you To pardon me yet for a night or two, Or, if not so, until the sun be set:

src: Well, lords, the Duke of Lancaster is dead.
trg: And living too; for now his son is duke.

src: and then the prince my brother and the princess my sister called my father father; and so we wept, and there was the first gentleman-like tears that ever we shed.
trg: We may live, son, to shed many more.

src: look thee, a bearing-cloth for a squire's child! look thee here; take up, take up, boy; open't. So, let's see: it was told me I should be rich by the fairies. This is some changeling: open't.
trg: What's within, boy?

src: Sound drums and trumpets! farewell sour annoy! For here, I hope, begins our lasting joy.
trg: If you shall chance, Camillo, to visit Bohemia, on the like occasion whereon my services are now on foot, you shall see, as I have said, great difference betwixt our Bohemia and your Sicilia.

src: We have ever your good word.
trg: He that will give good words to thee will flatter Beneath abhorring. What would you have, you curs, That like nor peace nor war? the one affrights you, The other makes you proud.

src: What think'st thou, then, of Stanley? what will he?
trg: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.

src: Not swear it, now I am a gentleman? Let boors and franklins say it, I'll swear it.
trg: How if it be false, son?

src: And be you kings, command, and I'll obey.
trg: We are true subjects to the king, King Edward.

src: He tells her something That makes her blood look out: good sooth, she is The queen of curds and cream.
trg: Come on, strike up!

src: There lies that Tybalt.
trg: Up, sir, go with me; I charge thee in the princes name, obey.

src: And will, no doubt, shortly be rid of me.
trg: Poor heart, adieu! I pity thy complaining.

src: come from thy ward, For I can here disarm thee with this stick And make thy weapon drop.
trg: Beseech you, father.

src: Claudio to prison? 'tis not so.
trg: Nay, but I know 'tis so: I saw him arrested, saw him carried away; and, which is more, within these three days his head to be chopped off.

src: Basta; content thee, for I have it full. We have not yet been seen in any house, Nor can we lie distinguish'd by our faces For man or master; then it follows thus;
trg: Thou shalt be master, Tranio, in my stead, Keep house and port and servants as I should: I will some other be, some Florentine, Some Neapolitan, or meaner man of Pisa. 'Tis hatch'd and shall be so:

src: O, let my sovereign turn away his face And bid his ears a little while be deaf, Till I have told this slander of his blood, How God and good men hate so foul a liar.
trg: Mowbray, impartial are our eyes and ears: He is our subject, Mowbray; so art thou: Free speech and fearless I to thee allow.

src: What, art thou hurt?
trg: Ay, ay, a scratch, a scratch; marry, 'tis enough. Where is my page? Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.

src: to London will we march amain, And once again bestride our foaming steeds, And once again cry 'Charge upon our foes!' But never once again turn back and fly.
trg: Ay, now methinks I hear great Warwick speak: Ne'er may he live to see a sunshine day, That cries 'Retire,' if Warwick bid him stay.

src: My brother and thy uncle, call'd Antonio-- I pray thee, mark me--that a brother should Be so perfidious!--he whom next thyself Of all the world I loved and to him put The manage of my state;
trg: as at that time Through all the signories it was the first And Prospero the prime duke, being so reputed In dignity, and for the liberal arts Without a parallel;

src: Let's hear. O fie! the treble jars.
trg: Spit in the hole, man, and tune again.

src: and wilt thou, pupil-like, Take thy correction mildly, kiss the rod, And fawn on rage with base humility, Which art a lion and a king of beasts?
trg: A king of beasts, indeed; if aught but beasts, I had been still a happy king of men. Good sometime queen, prepare thee hence for France:

src: A challenge, on my life.
trg: Romeo will answer it.

src: what old or newer torture Must I receive, whose every word deserves To taste of thy most worst?
trg: Thy tyranny Together working with thy jealousies, Fancies too weak for boys, too green and idle For girls of nine, O, think what they have done And then run mad indeed, stark mad!

src: You may deny that you were not the cause Of my Lord Hastings' late imprisonment.
trg: She may, my lord, for--

src: The consul Coriolanus.
trg: He consul!

src: O, if a virgin, And your affection not gone forth, I'll make you The queen of Naples.
trg: Soft, sir! one word more. They are both in either's powers; but this swift business I must uneasy make, lest too light winning Make the prize light. One word more; I charge thee That thou attend me:

src: That she is living, Were it but told you, should be hooted at Like an old tale: but it appears she lives, Though yet she speak not. Mark a little while. Please you to interpose, fair madam:
trg: kneel And pray your mother's blessing. Turn, good lady; Our Perdita is found.

src: Hark how I'll bribe you: good my lord, turn back.
trg: How! bribe me?

src: Give me, give me! O, tell not me of fear!
trg: Hold; get you gone, be strong and prosperous In this resolve: I'll send a friar with speed To Mantua, with my letters to thy lord.

src: Away, away, to meet the queen's great power! 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Thus far our fortune keeps an upward course, And we are graced with wreaths of victory.

src: But yet, Paulina, Hermione was not so much wrinkled, nothing So aged as this seems.
trg: O, not by much.

src: Yet you are wither'd.
trg: 'Tis with cares.

src: Here is the head; I'll carry it myself.
trg: Convenient is it. Make a swift return; For I would commune with you of such things That want no ear but yours.

src: Madam, what makes you in this sudden change?
trg: Why brother Rivers, are you yet to learn What late misfortune is befall'n King Edward?

src: I should so. Were I the ghost that walk'd, I'ld bid you mark Her eye, and tell me for what dull part in't You chose her; then I'ld shriek, that even your ears Should rift to hear me;
trg: and the words that follow'd Should be 'Remember mine.'

src: Behold our patroness, the life of Rome! Call all your tribes together, praise the gods, And make triumphant fires; strew flowers before them:
trg: Unshout the noise that banish'd Marcius, Repeal him with the welcome of his mother; Cry 'Welcome, ladies, welcome!'

src: I tell thee, man, 'tis better with me now Than when I met thee last where now we meet: Then was I going prisoner to the Tower, By the suggestion of the queen's allies;
trg: But now, I tell thee--keep it to thyself-- This day those enemies are put to death, And I in better state than e'er I was.

src: Ay, if the devil tempt thee to do good.
trg: Shall I forget myself to be myself?

src: This is a brave fellow.
trg: Believe me, thou talkest of an admirable conceited fellow. Has he any unbraided wares?

src: Tut, I have lost myself; I am not here; This is not Romeo, he's some other where.
trg: Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.

src: Come, officer, away!
trg: No, holy father; throw away that thought; Believe not that the dribbling dart of love Can pierce a complete bosom.

src: Help me into some house, Benvolio, Or I shall faint. A plague o' both your houses! They have made worms' meat of me: I have it, And soundly too: your houses!
trg: This gentleman, the prince's near ally, My very friend, hath got his mortal hurt In my behalf; my reputation stain'd With Tybalt's slander,--Tybalt, that an hour Hath been my kinsman!

src: let Romeo hence in haste, Else, when he's found, that hour is his last. Bear hence this body and attend our will: Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.
trg: Gallop apace, you fiery-footed steeds, Towards Phoebus' lodging: such a wagoner As Phaethon would whip you to the west, And bring in cloudy night immediately.

src: O Clifford, but bethink thee once again, And in thy thought o'er-run my former time;
trg: And, if though canst for blushing, view this face, And bite thy tongue, that slanders him with cowardice Whose frown hath made thee faint and fly ere this!

src: Softly, my masters! if you be gentlemen, Do me this right; hear me with patience. Baptista is a noble gentleman, To whom my father is not all unknown;
trg: And were his daughter fairer than she is, She may more suitors have and me for one. Fair Leda's daughter had a thousand wooers; Then well one more may fair Bianca have: And so she shall;

src: And affecting one sole throne, Without assistance.
trg: I think not so.

src: When the sun sets, the air doth drizzle dew; But for the sunset of my brother's son It rains downright. How now! a conduit, girl? what, still in tears? Evermore showering?
trg: In one little body Thou counterfeit'st a bark, a sea, a wind; For still thy eyes, which I may call the sea, Do ebb and flow with tears; the bark thy body is, Sailing in this salt flood;

src: Well aim'd of such a young one.
trg: Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.

src: Most willingly; But yet my caution was more pertinent Than the rebuke you give it.
trg: He loves your people But tie him not to be their bedfellow. Worthy Cominius, speak. Nay, keep your place.

src: When we were chosen tribunes for the people,--
trg: Mark'd you his lip and eyes?

src: What follows this? How prettily the young swain seems to wash The hand was fair before! I have put you out: But to your protestation; let me hear What you profess.
trg: Do, and be witness to 't.

src: Alas, alas! Why, all the souls that were were forfeit once; And He that might the vantage best have took Found out the remedy.
trg: How would you be, If He, which is the top of judgment, should But judge you as you are? O, think on that; And mercy then will breathe within your lips, Like man new made.

src: I fear me, never.
trg: How far is it, my lord, to Berkeley now?

src: 'tis a world to see, How tame, when men and women are alone, A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew. Give me thy hand, Kate: I will unto Venice, To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding-day.
trg: Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests; I will be sure my Katharina shall be fine.

src: And give me leave, And do not say 'tis superstition, that I kneel and then implore her blessing. Lady, Dear queen, that ended when I but began, Give me that hand of yours to kiss.
trg: O, patience! The statue is but newly fix'd, the colour's Not dry.

src: Yea, Richard, when I know; for I protest As yet I do not: but, as I can learn, He hearkens after prophecies and dreams; And from the cross-row plucks the letter G.
trg: And says a wizard told him that by G His issue disinherited should be; And, for my name of George begins with G, It follows in his thought that I am he.

src: I am sorry, sir, I have thus far stirr'd you: but I could afflict you farther.
trg: Do, Paulina; For this affliction has a taste as sweet As any cordial comfort. Still, methinks, There is an air comes from her: what fine chisel Could ever yet cut breath?

src: Of Mantua, sir? marry, God forbid! And come to Padua, careless of your life?
trg: My life, sir! how, I pray? for that goes hard.

src: Cambio!
trg: What sayest thou, Biondello?

src: A sail, a sail!
trg: Two, two; a shirt and a smock.

src: We charge you, that you have contrived to take From Rome all season'd office and to wind Yourself into a power tyrannical; For which you are a traitor to the people.
trg: How! traitor!

src: My lord; I do confess I ne'er was married; And I confess besides I am no maid: I have known my husband; yet my husband Knows not that ever he knew me.
trg: He was drunk then, my lord: it can be no better.

src: But this most cruel usage of your queen, Not able to produce more accusation Than your own weak-hinged fancy, something savours Of tyranny and will ignoble make you, Yea, scandalous to the world.
trg: On your allegiance, Out of the chamber with her! Were I a tyrant, Where were her life? she durst not call me so, If she did know me one. Away with her!

src: You speak o' the people, As if you were a god to punish, not A man of their infirmity.
trg: 'Twere well We let the people know't.

src: Their noise be our instruction. Ladders, ho!
trg: They fear us not, but issue forth their city. Now put your shields before your hearts, and fight With hearts more proof than shields. Advance, brave Titus:

src: Sign me a present pardon for my brother, Or with an outstretch'd throat I'll tell the world aloud What man thou art.
trg: Who will believe thee, Isabel?

src: But can you, if you would?
trg: Look, what I will not, that I cannot do.

src: Another way I have to man my haggard, To make her come and know her keeper's call, That is, to watch her, as we watch these kites That bate and beat and will not be obedient.
trg: She eat no meat to-day, nor none shall eat; Last night she slept not, nor to-night she shall not; As with the meat, some undeserved fault I'll find about the making of the bed;

src: Northumberland, then present, wept to see it.
trg: What were you snarling all before I came, Ready to catch each other by the throat, And turn you all your hatred now on me? Did York's dread curse prevail so much with heaven?

src: Brother Petruchio, sister Katharina, And thou, Hortensio, with thy loving widow, Feast with the best, and welcome to my house: My banquet is to close our stomachs up, After our great good cheer.
trg: Pray you, sit down; For now we sit to chat as well as eat.

src: Ay, hand from hand, my love, and heart from heart.
trg: Banish us both and send the king with me.

src: If you have writ your annals true, 'tis there, That, like an eagle in a dove-cote, I Flutter'd your Volscians in Corioli: Alone I did it. Boy!
trg: Why, noble lords, Will you be put in mind of his blind fortune, Which was your shame, by this unholy braggart, 'Fore your own eyes and ears?

src: Now, my liege, Tell me what blessings I have here alive, That I should fear to die? Therefore proceed. But yet hear this: mistake me not; Your honours all, I do refer me to the oracle:
trg: Apollo be my judge!

src: My lord, in the base court he doth attend To speak with you; may it please you to come down.
trg: Down, down I come; like glistering Phaethon, Wanting the manage of unruly jades. In the base court? Base court, where kings grow base, To come at traitors' calls and do them grace. In the base court?

src: Good ladies, let's go. Yes, yes, yes; the senate has letters from the general, wherein he gives my son the whole name of the war: he hath in this action outdone his former deeds doubly
trg: In troth, there's wondrous things spoke of him.

src: What, all so soon asleep! I wish mine eyes Would, with themselves, shut up my thoughts: I find They are inclined to do so.
trg: Please you, sir, Do not omit the heavy offer of it: It seldom visits sorrow; when it doth, It is a comforter.

src: who, as thou know'st, are dear To princely Richard and to Buckingham.
trg: The princes both make high account of you; For they account his head upon the bridge.

src: God grant him health! Did you confer with him?
trg: Madam, we did: he desires to make atonement Betwixt the Duke of Gloucester and your brothers, And betwixt them and my lord chamberlain; And sent to warn them to his royal presence.

src: Why then, the mustard without the beef.
trg: Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave, That feed'st me with the very name of meat: Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you, That triumph thus upon my misery! Go, get thee gone, I say.

src: Intended or committed was this fault? If on the first, how heinous e'er it be, To win thy after-love I pardon thee.
trg: Then give me leave that I may turn the key, That no man enter till my tale be done.

src: Where she at least is banish'd from your eye, Who hath cause to wet the grief on't.
trg: Prithee, peace.

src: Not possible; for who shall bear your part, And be in Padua here Vincentio's son, Keep house and ply his book, welcome his friends, Visit his countrymen and banquet them?
trg: Basta; content thee, for I have it full. We have not yet been seen in any house, Nor can we lie distinguish'd by our faces For man or master; then it follows thus;
Why stops my lord, shall I not hear my task?

src: What news? what news?
trg: You have holp to ravish your own daughters and To melt the city leads upon your pates, To see your wives dishonour'd to your noses,--

src: Have done, have done.
trg: O princely Buckingham I'll kiss thy hand, In sign of league and amity with thee: Now fair befal thee and thy noble house!

src: How should he be made, then?
trg: Some report a sea-maid spawned him; some, that he was begot between two stock-fishes. But it is certain that when he makes water his urine is congealed ice; that I know to be true:

src: Men's eyes were made to look, and let them gaze; I will not budge for no man's pleasure, I.
trg: Well, peace be with you, sir: here comes my man.

src: Thou hast never in thy life Show'd thy dear mother any courtesy, When she, poor hen, fond of no second brood, Has cluck'd thee to the wars and safely home, Loaden with honour.
trg: Say my request's unjust, And spurn me back: but if it be not so, Thou art not honest; and the gods will plague thee, That thou restrain'st from me the duty which To a mother's part belongs.

src: I see you do not mean to part with her, Or else you like not of my company.
trg: Mistake me not; I speak but as I find. Whence are you, sir? what may I call your name?

src: The old priest of Saint Luke's church is at your command at all hours.
trg: And what of all this?

src: A most royal one; the centurions and their charges, distinctly billeted, already in the entertainment, and to be on foot at an hour's warning.
trg: I am joyful to hear of their readiness, and am the man, I think, that shall set them in present action. So, sir, heartily well met, and most glad of your company.

src: How! know you where you are?
trg: Respect to your great place! and let the devil Be sometime honour'd for his burning throne! Where is the duke? 'tis he should hear me speak.

src: The boy is foolish, and I fear not him. Look, how thou dream'st! I say again, give out That Anne my wife is sick and like to die: About it;
trg: for it stands me much upon, To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me. I must be married to my brother's daughter, Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.

src: Ay, here's a deer whose skin's a keeper's fee: This is the quondam king; let's seize upon him.
trg: Let me embrace thee, sour adversity, For wise men say it is the wisest course.

src: Go to, sir; you weigh equally; a feather will turn the scale.
trg: Pray, sir, by your good favour,--for surely, sir, a good favour you have, but that you have a hanging look,--do you call, sir, your occupation a mystery?

src: To fear the foe, since fear oppresseth strength, Gives in your weakness strength unto your foe, And so your follies fight against yourself. Fear and be slain; no worse can come to fight:
trg: And fight and die is death destroying death; Where fearing dying pays death servile breath.

src: Such proclamation hath been made, my liege.
trg: Sir Thomas Lovel and Lord Marquis Dorset, 'Tis said, my liege, in Yorkshire are in arms. Yet this good comfort bring I to your grace, The Breton navy is dispersed by tempest:

src: To the palace, an it like your worship.
trg: Your affairs there, what, with whom, the condition of that fardel, the place of your dwelling, your names, your ages, of what having, breeding, and any thing that is fitting to be known, discover.

src: And grieve to hear't. What faults he made before the last, I think Might have found easy fines:
trg: but there to end Where he was to begin and give away The benefit of our levies, answering us With our own charge, making a treaty where There was a yielding,--this admits no excuse.

src: No, not a denier. Go by, Jeronimy: go to thy cold bed, and warm thee.
trg: I know my remedy; I must go fetch the third--borough.

src: Ay, nurse; what of that? both with an R.
trg: Ah. mocker! that's the dog's name; R is for the--No; I know it begins with some other letter:--and she hath the prettiest sententious of it, of you and rosemary, that it would do you good to hear it.

src: there to visit A son of mine, which long I have not seen.
trg: What is his name?

src: Why, then, I will. Farewell, old Gaunt. Thou goest to Coventry, there to behold Our cousin Hereford and fell Mowbray fight:
trg: O, sit my husband's wrongs on Hereford's spear, That it may enter butcher Mowbray's breast! Farewell, old Gaunt: thy sometimes brother's wife With her companion grief must end her life.

src: A widow, then?
trg: Neither, my lord.

src: Nor none that live, I hope.
trg: An if they live, I hope I need not fear. But come, my lord; and with a heavy heart, Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.

src: O, God ye god-den.
trg: May not one speak?

src: ' and where some stretch-mouthed rascal would, as it were, mean mischief and break a foul gap into the matter, he makes the maid to answer 'Whoop, do me no harm, good man;
trg: ' puts him off, slights him, with 'Whoop, do me no harm, good man.'

src: Yes, by Saint Anne, do I. A good matter, surely: comes there any more of it?
trg: My lord, 'tis but begun.

src: No, my good lord, for that is not forgot Which ne'er I did remember: to my knowledge, I never in my life did look on him.
trg: Then learn to know him now; this is the duke.

src: Had I not reason, think ye, to make haste, And seek their ruin that usurp'd our right? The midwife wonder'd and the women cried 'O, Jesus bless us, he is born with teeth!' And so I was;
trg: which plainly signified That I should snarl and bite and play the dog. Then, since the heavens have shaped my body so, Let hell make crook'd my mind to answer it.

src: Thank you. Wondrous heavy.
trg: What a strange drowsiness possesses them!

src: and your beards deserve not so honourable a grave as to stuff a botcher's cushion, or to be entombed in an ass's pack- saddle. Yet you must be saying, Marcius is proud;
trg: who in a cheap estimation, is worth predecessors since Deucalion, though peradventure some of the best of 'em were hereditary hangmen. God-den to your worships:

src: You peasant swain! you whoreson malt-horse drudge! Did I not bid thee meet me in the park, And bring along these rascal knaves with thee?
trg: Nathaniel's coat, sir, was not fully made, And Gabriel's pumps were all unpink'd i' the heel; There was no link to colour Peter's hat, And Walter's dagger was not come from sheathing:

src: And here he writes that he did buy a poison Of a poor 'pothecary, and therewithal Came to this vault to die, and lie with Juliet. Where be these enemies? Capulet! Montague!
trg: See, what a scourge is laid upon your hate, That heaven finds means to kill your joys with love. And I for winking at your discords too Have lost a brace of kinsmen: all are punish'd.

src: And to make us no better thought of, a little help will serve; for once we stood up about the corn, he himself stuck not to call us the many-headed multitude.
trg: We have been called so of many; not that our heads are some brown, some black, some auburn, some bald, but that our wits are so diversely coloured:

src: More pity that the eagle should be mew'd, While kites and buzzards prey at liberty.
trg: What news abroad?

src: Nay. but his taunts.
trg: Being moved, he will not spare to gird the gods.

src: Words against me? this is a good friar, belike! And to set on this wretched woman here Against our substitute! Let this friar be found.
trg: But yesternight, my lord, she and that friar, I saw them at the prison: a saucy friar, A very scurvy fellow.

src: He cannot temperately transport his honours From where he should begin and end, but will Lose those he hath won.
trg: In that there's comfort.

src: ' and by the operation of the second cup draws it on the drawer, when indeed there is no need.
trg: Am I like such a fellow?

src: But might you do't, and do the world no wrong, If so your heart were touch'd with that remorse As mine is to him?
trg: He's sentenced; 'tis too late.

src: Right.
trg: Why, then is my pump well flowered.

src: Nay, come away.
trg: This man has marr'd his fortune.

src: List to your tribunes. Audience: peace, I say!
trg: First, hear me speak.

src: And when he says he is, say that he dreams, For he is nothing but a mighty lord. This do and do it kindly, gentle sirs: It will be pastime passing excellent, If it be husbanded with modesty.
trg: My lord, I warrant you we will play our part, As he shall think by our true diligence He is no less than what we say he is.

src: I mean, in bearing weight of government, While he enjoys the honour and his ease.
trg: And, Clarence, now then it is more than needful Forthwith that Edward be pronounced a traitor, And all his lands and goods be confiscate.

src: Well, let us to the king: there is that in this fardel will make him scratch his beard.
And say it is the queen and her allies That stir the king against the duke my brother. Now, they believe it; and withal whet me To be revenged on Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: But then I sigh;
trg: and, with a piece of scripture, Tell them that God bids us do good for evil: And thus I clothe my naked villany With old odd ends stolen out of holy writ;

src: Before the time be out? no more!
trg: I prithee, Remember I have done thee worthy service; Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served Without or grudge or grumblings: thou didst promise To bate me a full year.

src: This is his lordship's man.
trg: And here comes Claudio's pardon.

src: And hark, what noise the general makes! To him! There is the man of my soul's hate, Aufidius, Piercing our Romans: then, valiant Titus, take Convenient numbers to make good the city;
trg: Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, will haste To help Cominius.

src: I have no brother, I am like no brother; And this word 'love,' which graybeards call divine, Be resident in men like one another And not in me: I am myself alone. Clarence, beware;
trg: thou keep'st me from the light: But I will sort a pitchy day for thee; For I will buz abroad such prophecies That Edward shall be fearful of his life, And then, to purge his fear, I'll be thy death.

src: and, when he shall die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine That all the world will be in love with night And pay no worship to the garish sun.
trg: O, I have bought the mansion of a love, But not possess'd it, and, though I am sold, Not yet enjoy'd:

src: And whosoe'er gainsays King Edward's right, By this I challenge him to single fight.
trg: Long live Edward the Fourth!

src: The strangeness of your story put Heaviness in me.
trg: Shake it off. Come on; We'll visit Caliban my slave, who never Yields us kind answer.

src: thy mother plays, and I Play too, but so disgraced a part, whose issue Will hiss me to my grave: contempt and clamour Will be my knell. Go, play, boy, play.
trg: There have been, Or I am much deceived, cuckolds ere now; nay, there's comfort in't Whiles other men have gates and those gates open'd, As mine, against their will.

src: When the sea is. Hence! What cares these roarers for the name of king? To cabin: silence! trouble us not.
trg: Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.

src: his noble hand Did will what he did spend and spent not that Which his triumphant father's hand had won; His hands were guilty of no kindred blood, But bloody with the enemies of his kin. O Richard!
trg: York is too far gone with grief, Or else he never would compare between.

src: Nor near nor farther off, my gracious lord, Than this weak arm: discomfort guides my tongue And bids me speak of nothing but despair.
trg: One day too late, I fear me, noble lord, Hath clouded all thy happy days on earth: O, call back yesterday, bid time return, And thou shalt have twelve thousand fighting men!

src: It blots thy beauty as frosts do bite the meads, Confounds thy fame as whirlwinds shake fair buds, And in no sense is meet or amiable.
trg: A woman moved is like a fountain troubled, Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty; And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty Will deign to sip or touch one drop of it.

src: Well, no more.
trg: No more words, we beseech you.

src: Being moved, he will not spare to gird the gods.
trg: Be-mock the modest moon.

src: Forget to pity him, lest thy pity prove A serpent that will sting thee to the heart.
trg: O heinous, strong and bold conspiracy! O loyal father of a treacherous son!

src: Is the senate possessed of this?
trg: Good ladies, let's go. Yes, yes, yes; the senate has letters from the general, wherein he gives my son the whole name of the war: he hath in this action outdone his former deeds doubly

src: Why, I am past my gamut long ago.
trg: Yet read the gamut of Hortensio.

src: Certainly He flouted us downright.
trg: No,'tis his kind of speech: he did not mock us.

src: Sweet rest his soul! Fly, lords, and save yourselves; For Warwick bids you all farewell to meet in heaven.
trg: Away, away, to meet the queen's great power! 3 KING HENRY VI

src: Hortensio, peace! thou know'st not gold's effect: Tell me her father's name and 'tis enough; For I will board her, though she chide as loud As thunder when the clouds in autumn crack.
trg: Her father is Baptista Minola, An affable and courteous gentleman: Her name is Katharina Minola, Renown'd in Padua for her scolding tongue.

src: What means our cousin, that he stares and looks So wildly?
trg: God save your grace! I do beseech your majesty, To have some conference with your grace alone.

src: yet thou art a mother, And hast the comfort of thy children left thee: But death hath snatch'd my husband from mine arms, And pluck'd two crutches from my feeble limbs, Edward and Clarence.
trg: O, what cause have I, Thine being but a moiety of my grief, To overgo thy plaints and drown thy cries!

src: Katharina the curst! A title for a maid of all titles the worst.
trg: Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace, And offer me disguised in sober robes To old Baptista as a schoolmaster Well seen in music, to instruct Bianca;

src: Or else you would not have bestow'd the heir Of the Lord Bonville on your new wife's son, And leave your brothers to go speed elsewhere.
trg: Alas, poor Clarence! is it for a wife That thou art malcontent? I will provide thee.

src: It cannot fail but by The violation of my faith; and then Let nature crush the sides o' the earth together And mar the seeds within! Lift up thy looks: From my succession wipe me, father;
trg: I Am heir to my affection.

src: Forgive him, Angelo, that brought you home The head of Ragozine for Claudio's: The offence pardons itself. Dear Isabel, I have a motion much imports your good;
trg: Whereto if you'll a willing ear incline, What's mine is yours and what is yours is mine. So, bring us to our palace; where we'll show What's yet behind, that's meet you all should know.

src: Proceed.
He may command me as my sovereign; But you have power in me as in a kinsman.
trg: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.

src: But, my daughter, Say you the like to him?
trg: I cannot speak So well, nothing so well; no, nor mean better: By the pattern of mine own thoughts I cut out The purity of his.

src: Nay, not as one would say, healthy; but so sound as things that are hollow: thy bones are hollow; impiety has made a feast of thee.
trg: How now! which of your hips has the most profound sciatica?

src: Now here a period of tumultuous broils. Away with Oxford to Hames Castle straight: For Somerset, off with his guilty head. Go, bear them hence; I will not hear them speak.
trg: For my part, I'll not trouble thee with words.

src: For now he lives in fame, though not in life. I'll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham,--
trg: What, my gracious lord?

src: I, an old turtle, Will wing me to some wither'd bough and there My mate, that's never to be found again, Lament till I am lost.
trg: O, peace, Paulina! Thou shouldst a husband take by my consent, As I by thine a wife: this is a match, And made between's by vows. Thou hast found mine; But how, is to be question'd;

src: Ay, sir, very well.
trg: Nay; I beseech you, mark it well.

src: Ay, such a pleasure as incaged birds Conceive when after many moody thoughts At last by notes of household harmony They quite forget their loss of liberty.
trg: But, Warwick, after God, thou set'st me free, And chiefly therefore I thank God and thee; He was the author, thou the instrument.

src: Away, you fool! it more becomes a man Than gilt his trophy:
trg: the breasts of Hecuba, When she did suckle Hector, look'd not lovelier Than Hector's forehead when it spit forth blood At Grecian sword, contemning. Tell Valeria, We are fit to bid her welcome.

src: Sir, You speak a language that I understand not: My life stands in the level of your dreams, Which I'll lay down.
trg: Your actions are my dreams; You had a bastard by Polixenes, And I but dream'd it. As you were past all shame,-- Those of your fact are so--so past all truth: Which to deny concerns more than avails;

src: Let's have some merry ones.
trg: Why, this is a passing merry one and goes to the tune of 'Two maids wooing a man:' there's scarce a maid westward but she sings it; 'tis in request, I can tell you.

src: Take up the sword again, or take up me.
trg: Arise, dissembler: though I wish thy death, I will not be the executioner.

src: Even he, my lord.
trg: How often have I told you 'twould be thus! How often said, my dignity would last But till 'twere known!

src: A noble fellow, I warrant him.
trg: The worthy fellow is our general: he's the rock, the oak not to be wind-shaken.

src: We'll part the time between's then; and in that I'll no gainsaying.
trg: Press me not, beseech you, so. There is no tongue that moves, none, none i' the world, So soon as yours could win me:

src: He shall, sure on't.
trg: Sir, sir,--

src: for in her youth There is a prone and speechless dialect, Such as move men; beside, she hath prosperous art When she will play with reason and discourse, And well she can persuade.
trg: I pray she may; I'll to her.

src: O thou, the earthly author of my blood, Whose youthful spirit, in me regenerate, Doth with a twofold vigour lift me up To reach at victory above my head, Add proof unto mine armour with thy prayers;
trg: And with thy blessings steel my lance's point, That it may enter Mowbray's waxen coat, And furbish new the name of John a Gaunt, Even in the lusty havior of his son.

src: O thou caitiff! O thou varlet! O thou wicked Hannibal! I respected with her before I was married to her!
trg: If ever I was respected with her, or she with me, let not your worship think me the poor duke's officer. Prove this, thou wicked Hannibal, or I'll have mine action of battery on thee.

src: Away, away, mad ass! his name is Lucentio and he is mine only son, and heir to the lands of me, Signior Vincentio.
trg: Lucentio! O, he hath murdered his master! Lay hold on him, I charge you, in the duke's name. O, my son, my son! Tell me, thou villain, where is my son Lucentio?

src: if one jot beyond The bound of honour, or in act or will That way inclining, harden'd be the hearts Of all that hear me, and my near'st of kin Cry fie upon my grave!
trg: I ne'er heard yet That any of these bolder vices wanted Less impudence to gainsay what they did Than to perform it first.
What is the matter, uncle? speak; Recover breath; tell us how near is danger, That we may arm us to encounter it.

src: The Earl of Wiltshire hath the realm in farm.
trg: The king's grown bankrupt, like a broken man.

src: I have begun, And now I give my sensual race the rein: Fit thy consent to my sharp appetite; Lay by all nicety and prolixious blushes, That banish what they sue for;
trg: redeem thy brother By yielding up thy body to my will; Or else he must not only die the death, But thy unkindness shall his death draw out To lingering sufferance.

src: His bloody brow! O Jupiter, no blood!
trg: Away, you fool! it more becomes a man Than gilt his trophy:

src: Why, here's he that was wont to thwack our general, Caius Marcius.
trg: Why do you say 'thwack our general '?

src: I will be his conduct.
trg: Lords, you that here are under our arrest, Procure your sureties for your days of answer. Little are we beholding to your love, And little look'd for at your helping hands.

src: Come hither, you rogue. What, have you forgot me?
trg: Forgot you! no, sir: I could not forget you, for I never saw you before in all my life.

src: And I,--like one lost in a thorny wood, That rends the thorns and is rent with the thorns, Seeking a way and straying from the way;
trg: Not knowing how to find the open air, But toiling desperately to find it out,-- Torment myself to catch the English crown:

src: An honour! were not I thine only nurse, I would say thou hadst suck'd wisdom from thy teat.
trg: Well, think of marriage now; younger than you, Here in Verona, ladies of esteem, Are made already mothers: by my count, I was your mother much upon these years That you are now a maid.

src: And if he chance to speak, be ready straight And with a low submissive reverence Say 'What is it your honour will command?
trg: ' Let one attend him with a silver basin Full of rose-water and bestrew'd with flowers, Another bear the ewer, the third a diaper, And say 'Will't please your lordship cool your hands?

src: Now, by my holidame, here comes Katharina!
trg: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?

src: It is fifteen years since I saw my country: though I have for the most part been aired abroad, I desire to lay my bones there. Besides, the penitent king, my master, hath sent for me;
trg: to whose feeling sorrows I might be some allay, or I o'erween to think so, which is another spur to my departure.

src: The moon! the sun: it is not moonlight now.
trg: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.

src: What you command, that rests in me to do.
trg: But you will take exceptions to my boon.

src: This damn'd witch Sycorax, For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible To enter human hearing, from Argier, Thou know'st, was banish'd: for one thing she did They would not take her life.
trg: Is not this true?

src: Edward's seven sons, whereof thyself art one, Were as seven vials of his sacred blood, Or seven fair branches springing from one root:
trg: Some of those seven are dried by nature's course, Some of those branches by the Destinies cut; Ah, Gaunt, his blood was thine!

src: Yet let us all together to our troops, And give them leave to fly that will not stay; And call them pillars that will stand to us;
trg: And, if we thrive, promise them such rewards As victors wear at the Olympian games: This may plant courage in their quailing breasts; For yet is hope of life and victory.

src: Why, therefore fire; for I have caught extreme cold. Where's the cook? is supper ready, the house trimmed, rushes strewed, cobwebs swept;
trg: the serving-men in their new fustian, their white stockings, and every officer his wedding-garment on? Be the jacks fair within, the jills fair without, the carpets laid, and every thing in order?

src: What custom wills, in all things should we do't, The dust on antique time would lie unswept, And mountainous error be too highly heapt For truth to o'er-peer.
trg: Rather than fool it so, Let the high office and the honour go To one that would do thus. I am half through; The one part suffer'd, the other will I do. Here come more voices. Your voices:

src: Thou, it seems, that calls for company to countenance her.
trg: I call them forth to credit her.

src: Faith, mistress, then I have no cause to stay.
trg: But I have cause to pry into this pedant: Methinks he looks as though he were in love: Yet if thy thoughts, Bianca, be so humble To cast thy wandering eyes on every stale, Seize thee that list:

src: but we have been Deceived in thy integrity, deceived In that which seems so.
trg: Be it forbid, my lord!

src: But thou didst kill my children.
trg: But in your daughter's womb I bury them: Where in that nest of spicery they shall breed Selves of themselves, to your recomforture.

src: thence we looked toward England, And cited up a thousand fearful times, During the wars of York and Lancaster That had befall'n us.
trg: As we paced along Upon the giddy footing of the hatches, Methought that Gloucester stumbled; and, in falling, Struck me, that thought to stay him, overboard, Into the tumbling billows of the main.

src: No, my good lord, my friends are in the north.
