trg: Peace, you mumbling fool! Utter your gravity o'er a gossip's bowl; For here we need it not.

src: Nay, good, be patient.
trg: When the sea is. Hence! What cares these roarers for the name of king? To cabin: silence! trouble us not.

src: Then all alone At the prefixed hour of her waking, Came I to take her from her kindred's vault; Meaning to keep her closely at my cell, Till I conveniently could send to Romeo:
trg: But when I came, some minute ere the time Of her awaking, here untimely lay The noble Paris and true Romeo dead. She wakes; and I entreated her come forth, And bear this work of heaven with patience:

src: What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?
trg: My lord protector needs will have it so.

src: What, shall I groan and tell thee?
trg: Groan! why, no. But sadly tell me who.

src: Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench; I love her ten times more than e'er I did: O, how I long to have some chat with her!
trg: Well, go with me and be not so discomfited: Proceed in practise with my younger daughter; She's apt to learn and thankful for good turns.

src: Thou that wast seal'd in thy nativity The slave of nature and the son of hell! Thou slander of thy mother's heavy womb! Thou loathed issue of thy father's loins! Thou rag of honour! thou detested--
trg: Margaret.

src: Your fellow Tranio here, to save my life, Puts my apparel and my countenance on, And I for my escape have put on his; For in a quarrel since I came ashore I kill'd a man and fear I was descried:
trg: Wait you on him, I charge you, as becomes, While I make way from hence to save my life: You understand me?

src: One of these two must be necessities, Which then will speak, that you must change this purpose, Or I my life.
trg: Thou dearest Perdita, With these forced thoughts, I prithee, darken not The mirth o' the feast. Or I'll be thine, my fair, Or not my father's.

src: Never, Paulina; so be blest my spirit!
trg: Then, good my lords, bear witness to his oath.

src: What, do you tremble? are you all afraid? Alas, I blame you not; for you are mortal, And mortal eyes cannot endure the devil. Avaunt, thou dreadful minister of hell!
trg: Thou hadst but power over his mortal body, His soul thou canst not have; therefore be gone.

src: But how did you desire it should be made?
trg: Marry, sir, with needle and thread.

src: In your affairs, my lord, If ever I were wilful-negligent, It was my folly; if industriously I play'd the fool, it was my negligence, Not weighing well the end;
trg: if ever fearful To do a thing, where I the issue doubted, Where of the execution did cry out Against the non-performance, 'twas a fear Which oft infects the wisest:

src: What is your will?
trg: Might you dispense with your leisure, I would by and by have some speech with you: the satisfaction I would require is likewise your own benefit.

src: Sweet prince, the untainted virtue of your years Hath not yet dived into the world's deceit Nor more can you distinguish of a man Than of his outward show;
trg: which, God he knows, Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart. Those uncles which you want were dangerous; Your grace attended to their sugar'd words, But look'd not on the poison of their hearts :

src: Affrighted much, I did in time collect myself and thought This was so and no slumber. Dreams are toys: Yet for this once, yea, superstitiously, I will be squared by this.
trg: I do believe Hermione hath suffer'd death, and that Apollo would, this being indeed the issue Of King Polixenes, it should here be laid, Either for life or death, upon the earth Of its right father.

src: Poor Clarence did forsake his father, Warwick; Yea, and forswore himself,--which Jesu pardon!--
trg: Which God revenge!

src: Come, come, dispatch; 'tis bootless to exclaim.
trg: O bloody Richard! miserable England! I prophesy the fearful'st time to thee That ever wretched age hath look'd upon. Come, lead me to the block; bear him my head.

src: Dear, they durst not, So dear the love my people bore me, nor set A mark so bloody on the business, but With colours fairer painted their foul ends.
trg: In few, they hurried us aboard a bark, Bore us some leagues to sea; where they prepared A rotten carcass of a boat, not rigg'd, Nor tackle, sail, nor mast; the very rats Instinctively had quit it:

src: And dares him to set forward to the fight.
trg: Courageously and with a free desire Attending but the signal to begin.

src: Marry, so I mean, sweet Katharina, in thy bed: And therefore, setting all this chat aside, Thus in plain terms: your father hath consented That you shall be my wife; your dowry 'greed on;
trg: And, Will you, nill you, I will marry you. Now, Kate, I am a husband for your turn;

src: O, welcome, Oxford! for we want thy help.
trg: Montague, Montague, for Lancaster!

src: Nay, stay; lets hear the orisons he makes.
trg: She-wolf of France, but worse than wolves of France, Whose tongue more poisons than the adder's tooth!

src: For this, be sure, to-night thou shalt have cramps, Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up; urchins Shall, for that vast of night that they may work, All exercise on thee;
trg: thou shalt be pinch'd As thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stinging Than bees that made 'em.

src: Sound drums and trumpets boldly and cheerfully; God and Saint George! Richmond and victory!
trg: What said Northumberland as touching Richmond?

src: Would I had been by, to have helped the old man!
trg: I would you had been by the ship side, to have helped her: there your charity would have lacked footing.

src: Farewell, kind neighbours: we wish'd Coriolanus Had loved you as we did.
trg: Now the gods keep you!

src: A goodly house: the feast smells well; but I Appear not like a guest.
trg: What would you have, friend? whence are you? Here's no place for you: pray, go to the door.

src: If not, I'll use the advantage of my power And lay the summer's dust with showers of blood Rain'd from the wounds of slaughter'd Englishmen:
trg: The which, how far off from the mind of Bolingbroke It is, such crimson tempest should bedrench The fresh green lap of fair King Richard's land, My stooping duty tenderly shall show.

src: but, if you do remember, I send it through the rivers of your blood, Even to the court, the heart, to the seat o' the brain;
trg: And, through the cranks and offices of man, The strongest nerves and small inferior veins From me receive that natural competency Whereby they live:

src: Hold, valiant Clifford! for a thousand causes I would prolong awhile the traitor's life. Wrath makes him deaf: speak thou, Northumberland.
trg: Hold, Clifford! do not honour him so much To prick thy finger, though to wound his heart:

src: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.
trg: Well, then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby, And, as it were far off sound thou Lord Hastings, How doth he stand affected to our purpose;

src: Nay, temperately; your promise.
trg: The fires i' the lowest hell fold-in the people! Call me their traitor! Thou injurious tribune!

src: 'We smothered The most replenished sweet work of nature, That from the prime creation e'er she framed.' Thus both are gone with conscience and remorse; They could not speak;
trg: and so I left them both, To bring this tidings to the bloody king. And here he comes. All hail, my sovereign liege!

src: Go, see him out at gates, and follow him, As he hath followed you, with all despite; Give him deserved vexation. Let a guard Attend us through the city.
trg: Come, come; let's see him out at gates; come. The gods preserve our noble tribunes! Come.

src: Lo, as at English feasts, so I regreet The daintiest last, to make the end most sweet:
trg: O thou, the earthly author of my blood, Whose youthful spirit, in me regenerate, Doth with a twofold vigour lift me up To reach at victory above my head, Add proof unto mine armour with thy prayers;

src: He that will give good words to thee will flatter Beneath abhorring. What would you have, you curs, That like nor peace nor war? the one affrights you, The other makes you proud.
trg: He that trusts to you, Where he should find you lions, finds you hares; Where foxes, geese: you are no surer, no, Than is the coal of fire upon the ice, Or hailstone in the sun.

src: My lord, your sorrow was too sore laid on, Which sixteen winters cannot blow away, So many summers dry; scarce any joy Did ever so long live; no sorrow But kill'd itself much sooner.
trg: Dear my brother, Let him that was the cause of this have power To take off so much grief from you as he Will piece up in himself.

src: Sir, spare your threats: The bug which you would fright me with I seek. To me can life be no commodity: The crown and comfort of my life, your favour, I do give lost;
trg: for I do feel it gone, But know not how it went. My second joy And first-fruits of my body, from his presence I am barr'd, like one infectious.

src: If I could find example Of thousands that had struck anointed kings And flourish'd after, I'ld not do't; but since Nor brass nor stone nor parchment bears not one, Let villany itself forswear't.
trg: I must Forsake the court: to do't, or no, is certain To me a break-neck. Happy star, reign now! Here comes Bohemia.

src: Pompey.
trg: What else?

src: and by my prescience I find my zenith doth depend upon A most auspicious star, whose influence If now I court not but omit, my fortunes Will ever after droop. Here cease more questions:
trg: Thou art inclined to sleep; 'tis a good dulness, And give it way: I know thou canst not choose. Come away, servant, come. I am ready now. Approach, my Ariel, come.

src: Now I'll tell you without asking: my master is the great rich Capulet; and if you be not of the house of Montagues, I pray, come and crush a cup of wine. Rest you merry!
trg: At this same ancient feast of Capulet's Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so lovest, With all the admired beauties of Verona: Go thither;

src: Take heed you dally not before your king; Lest he that is the supreme King of kings Confound your hidden falsehood, and award Either of you to be the other's end.
trg: So prosper I, as I swear perfect love!

src: And you.
trg: Direct me, if it be your will, Where great Aufidius lies: is he in Antium?

src: Truly, the souls of men are full of dread: Ye cannot reason almost with a man That looks not heavily and full of fear.
trg: Before the times of change, still is it so: By a divine instinct men's minds mistrust Ensuing dangers; as by proof, we see The waters swell before a boisterous storm. But leave it all to God.

src: Pleads he in earnest? look upon his face; His eyes do drop no tears, his prayers are in jest; His words come from his mouth, ours from our breast: He prays but faintly and would be denied;
trg: We pray with heart and soul and all beside: His weary joints would gladly rise, I know; Our knees shall kneel till to the ground they grow: His prayers are full of false hypocrisy;

src: Such a nature, Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow Which he treads on at noon: but I do wonder His insolence can brook to be commanded Under Cominius.
trg: Fame, at the which he aims, In whom already he's well graced, can not Better be held nor more attain'd than by A place below the first:

src: How accompanied?
trg: With old Menenius, and those senators That always favour'd him.

src: Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends, They have chose a consul that will from them take Their liberties;
trg: make them of no more voice Than dogs that are as often beat for barking As therefore kept to do so.

src: Madam.
trg: Al'ce madam, or Joan madam?

src: Much more to be thus opposite with heaven, For it requires the royal debt it lent you.
trg: Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother, Of the young prince your son: send straight for him Let him be crown'd; in him your comfort lives:

src: Nor now my scandal, Richard, dost thou hear;
trg: I know it well, Lord Warwick; blame me not: 'Tis love I bear thy glories makes me speak. But in this troublous time what's to be done?

src: O, give me thy hand, One writ with me in sour misfortune's book! I'll bury thee in a triumphant grave; A grave? O no!
trg: a lantern, slaughter'd youth, For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes This vault a feasting presence full of light. Death, lie thou there, by a dead man interr'd.

src: No, but there's a woman with maid by him. You have not heard of the proclamation, have you?
trg: What proclamation, man?

src: He has no equal.
trg: When we were chosen tribunes for the people,--

src: And fight and die is death destroying death; Where fearing dying pays death servile breath.
trg: My father hath a power; inquire of him And learn to make a body of a limb.

src: Wilt thou provoke me? then have at thee, boy!
trg: O Lord, they fight! I will go call the watch.

src: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads; take it in what sense thou wilt.
trg: They must take it in sense that feel it.

src: Tell me of corn! This was my speech, and I will speak't again--
trg: Not now, not now.

src: But when the duke is slain, they'll quickly fly.
trg: Far be the thought of this from Henry's heart, To make a shambles of the parliament-house! Cousin of Exeter, frowns, words and threats Shall be the war that Henry means to use.

src: Lawn as white as driven snow; Cyprus black as e'er was crow; Gloves as sweet as damask roses; Masks for faces and for noses; Bugle bracelet, necklace amber, Perfume for a lady's chamber;
trg: Golden quoifs and stomachers, For my lads to give their dears: Pins and poking-sticks of steel, What maids lack from head to heel: Come buy of me, come; come buy, come buy;

src: I will go sit and weep Till I can find occasion of revenge.
trg: Was ever gentleman thus grieved as I? But who comes here?

src: Yes, if you will, my lord.
trg: Thou want'st a rough pash and the shoots that I have, To be full like me: yet they say we are Almost as like as eggs; Come, sir page, Look on me with your welkin eye: sweet villain! Most dear'st!

src: So could I, faith, boy, to have the next wish after, That Lucentio indeed had Baptista's youngest daughter.
trg: But, sirrah, not for my sake, but your master's, I advise You use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies: When I am alone, why, then I am Tranio;

src: O here's a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an inch narrow to an ell broad!
trg: I stretch it out for that word 'broad;' which added to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.

src: Does Bridget paint still, Pompey, ha?
trg: Come your ways, sir; come.

src: I come, anon.--But if thou mean'st not well, I do beseech thee--
Under your sentence?
trg: Yea.

src: Signior Hortensio, 'twixt such friends as we Few words suffice; I come to wive it wealthily in Padua; If wealthily, then happily in Padua.
trg: Nay, look you, sir, he tells you flatly what his mind is: Why give him gold enough and marry him to a puppet or an aglet-baby;

src: And what is left, to lose it by his country, Were to us all, that do't and suffer it, A brand to the end o' the world.
trg: This is clean kam.

src: They are; and Bolingbroke Hath seized the wasteful king. O, what pity is it That he had not so trimm'd and dress'd his land As we this garden!
trg: We at time of year Do wound the bark, the skin of our fruit-trees, Lest, being over-proud in sap and blood, With too much riches it confound itself:

src: And 'twere the cheaper way: Better it were a brother died at once, Than that a sister, by redeeming him, Should die for ever.
trg: Were not you then as cruel as the sentence That you have slander'd so?

src: What noise there, ho?
trg: No noise, my lord; but needful conference About some gossips for your highness.

src: Relate your wrongs; in what? by whom? be brief. Here is Lord Angelo shall give you justice: Reveal yourself to him.
trg: O worthy duke, You bid me seek redemption of the devil: Hear me yourself; for that which I must speak Must either punish me, not being believed, Or wring redress from you. Hear me, O hear me, here!

src: A pretty peat! it is best Put finger in the eye, an she knew why.
trg: Sister, content you in my discontent. Sir, to your pleasure humbly I subscribe: My books and instruments shall be my company, On them to took and practise by myself.

src: Saw'st thou the melancholy Lord Northumberland?
trg: Thomas the Earl of Surrey, and himself, Much about cock-shut time, from troop to troop Went through the army, cheering up the soldiers.

src: Pray heartily he be at palace.
What news abroad?
trg: No news so bad abroad as this at home; The King is sickly, weak and melancholy, And his physicians fear him mightily.

src: My wretchedness unto a row of pins, They'll talk of state; for every one doth so Against a change; woe is forerun with woe.
trg: Go, bind thou up yon dangling apricocks, Which, like unruly children, make their sire Stoop with oppression of their prodigal weight: Give some supportance to the bending twigs.

src: Come, sir, come, we know you well enough.
trg: You know neither me, yourselves nor any thing. You are ambitious for poor knaves' caps and legs: you wear out a good wholesome forenoon in hearing a cause between an orange wife and a fosset-seller;

src: The noble sister of Publicola, The moon of Rome, chaste as the icicle That's curdied by the frost from purest snow And hangs on Dian's temple: dear Valeria!
trg: This is a poor epitome of yours, Which by the interpretation of full time May show like all yourself.

src: And then to crave a league of amity; And lastly, to confirm that amity With a nuptial knot, if thou vouchsafe to grant That virtuous Lady Bona, thy fair sister, To England's king in lawful marriage.
Is Clarence dead? the order was reversed.
trg: But he, poor soul, by your first order died, And that a winged Mercury did bear: Some tardy cripple bore the countermand, That came too lag to see him buried.

src: let's talk; it is not day.
trg: It is, it is: hie hence, be gone, away! It is the lark that sings so out of tune, Straining harsh discords and unpleasing sharps. Some say the lark makes sweet division;

src: Go take her hence, and marry her instantly. Do you the office, friar; which consummate, Return him here again. Go with him, provost.
trg: My lord, I am more amazed at his dishonour Than at the strangeness of it.

src: Ay, mother; but I would not have it so.
trg: Why, my young cousin, it is good to grow.

src: My Lord of Warwick, hear me but one word: Let me for this my life-time reign as king.
trg: Confirm the crown to me and to mine heirs, And thou shalt reign in quiet while thou livest.

src: Lay it by too: another.
trg: This is a merry ballad, but a very pretty one.

src: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, thy conscience flies out.
trg: Let it go; there's few or none will entertain it.

src: I hope the king made peace with all of us And the compact is firm and true in me.
trg: And so in me; and so, I think, in all: Yet, since it is but green, it should be put To no apparent likelihood of breach, Which haply by much company might be urged:

src: Let me but meet you, ladies, one hour hence, And I'll salute your grace of York as mother, And reverend looker on, of two fair queens.
trg: Come, madam, you must straight to Westminster, There to be crowned Richard's royal queen.

src: Good aunt, stand up.
trg: Nay, do not say, 'stand up;' Say, 'pardon' first, and afterwards 'stand up.' And if I were thy nurse, thy tongue to teach, 'Pardon' should be the first word of thy speech.

src: As well as one so great and so forlorn May hold together: on her frights and griefs, Which never tender lady hath born greater, She is something before her time deliver'd.
trg: A boy?

src: But to make an end of the ship, to see how the sea flap-dragoned it: but, first, how the poor souls roared, and the sea mocked them;
trg: and how the poor gentleman roared and the bear mocked him, both roaring louder than the sea or weather.

src: His looks are full of peaceful majesty, His head by nature framed to wear a crown, His hand to wield a sceptre, and himself Likely in time to bless a regal throne.
trg: Make much of him, my lords, for this is he Must help you more than you are hurt by me.

src: Pray you, let's to him.
trg: You do the nobler.

src: Bolder, though not so subtle. My valour's poison'd With only suffering stain by him; for him Shall fly out of itself:
trg: where I find him, were it At home, upon my brother's guard, even there, Against the hospitable canon, would I Wash my fierce hand in's heart. Go you to the city; Learn how 'tis held;

src: if I do, Pompey, I shall beat you to your tent, and prove a shrewd Caesar to you; in plain dealing, Pompey, I shall have you whipt: so, for this time, Pompey, fare you well.
trg: I thank your worship for your good counsel: but I shall follow it as the flesh and fortune shall better determine. Whip me? No, no; let carman whip his jade:

src: the smiles of knaves Tent in my cheeks, and schoolboys' tears take up The glasses of my sight!
trg: a beggar's tongue Make motion through my lips, and my arm'd knees, Who bow'd but in my stirrup, bend like his That hath received an alms!

src: That's a certain text.
trg: Come you to make confession to this father?

src: Peace, peace!
Bid them come near. Now, fellows, you are welcome.
trg: We thank your honour.

src: To do that office of thine own good will Which tired majesty did make thee offer, The resignation of thy state and crown To Henry Bolingbroke.
trg: Give me the crown. Here, cousin, seize the crown; Here cousin: On this side my hand, and on that side yours.

src: Fare ye well: Thou hast years upon thee; and thou art too full Of the wars' surfeits, to go rove with one That's yet unbruised: bring me but out at gate.
trg: Come, my sweet wife, my dearest mother, and My friends of noble touch, when I am forth, Bid me farewell, and smile. I pray you, come.

src: O place and greatness! millions of false eyes Are stuck upon thee: volumes of report Run with these false and most contrarious quests Upon thy doings:
trg: thousand escapes of wit Make thee the father of their idle dreams And rack thee in their fancies. Welcome, how agreed?

src: By the apostle Paul, shadows to-night Have struck more terror to the soul of Richard Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers Armed in proof, and led by shallow Richmond.
trg: It is not yet near day. Come, go with me; Under our tents I'll play the eaves-dropper, To see if any mean to shrink from me.

src: No, if I digg'd up thy forefathers' graves And hung their rotten coffins up in chains, It could not slake mine ire, nor ease my heart.
trg: The sight of any of the house of York Is as a fury to torment my soul; And till I root out their accursed line And leave not one alive, I live in hell. Therefore--

src: What a blow was there given!
trg: An it had not fallen flat-long.

src: Not all the water in the rough rude sea Can wash the balm off from an anointed king; The breath of worldly men cannot depose The deputy elected by the Lord:
trg: For every man that Bolingbroke hath press'd To lift shrewd steel against our golden crown, God for his Richard hath in heavenly pay A glorious angel:

src: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?
trg: Ay, if the devil tempt thee to do good.

src: So long as hell and Richard likes of it.
trg: Say, I, her sovereign, am her subject love.

src: In some sort, sir: but though my case be a pitiful one, I hope I shall not be flayed out of it.
trg: O, that's the case of the shepherd's son: hang him, he'll be made an example.

src: I beseech thee, youth, Put not another sin upon my head, By urging me to fury: O, be gone! By heaven, I love thee better than myself; For I come hither arm'd against myself: Stay not, be gone;
trg: live, and hereafter say, A madman's mercy bade thee run away.

src: Great lords, wise men ne'er sit and wail their loss, But cheerly seek how to redress their harms.
trg: What though the mast be now blown overboard, The cable broke, the holding-anchor lost, And half our sailors swallow'd in the flood? Yet lives our pilot still. Ah, what a shame!

src: We will ourself in person to this war: And, for our coffers, with too great a court And liberal largess, are grown somewhat light, We are inforced to farm our royal realm;
trg: The revenue whereof shall furnish us For our affairs in hand: if that come short, Our substitutes at home shall have blank charters;

src: Stay, madam; I must speak a word with you.
trg: I have no more sons of the royal blood For thee to murder: for my daughters, Richard, They shall be praying nuns, not weeping queens; And therefore level not to hit their lives.

src: As now she might have done, So much to my good comfort, as it is Now piercing to my soul. O, thus she stood, Even with such life of majesty, warm life, As now it coldly stands, when first I woo'd her!
trg: I am ashamed: does not the stone rebuke me For being more stone than it?

src: I think she'll sooner prove a soldier Iron may hold with her, but never lutes.
trg: Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?

src: When I was last in Holborn, I saw good strawberries in your garden there I do beseech you send for some of them.
trg: Marry, and will, my lord, with all my heart.

src: As a long-parted mother with her child Plays fondly with her tears and smiles in meeting, So, weeping, smiling, greet I thee, my earth, And do thee favours with my royal hands.
trg: Feed not thy sovereign's foe, my gentle earth, Nor with thy sweets comfort his ravenous sense;

src: lesser had been The thwartings of your dispositions, if You had not show'd them how ye were disposed Ere they lack'd power to cross you.
trg: Let them hang.

src: Is love a tender thing? it is too rough, Too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorn.
trg: If love be rough with you, be rough with love; Prick love for pricking, and you beat love down. Give me a case to put my visage in: A visor for a visor!

src: And, to be noted for a merry man, He'll woo a thousand, 'point the day of marriage, Make feasts, invite friends, and proclaim the banns; Yet never means to wed where he hath woo'd.
trg: Now must the world point at poor Katharina, And say, 'Lo, there is mad Petruchio's wife, If it would please him come and marry her!'

src: I told your majesty as much before: This proveth Edward's love and Warwick's honesty.
trg: Did I forget that by the house of York My father came untimely to his death? Did I let pass the abuse done to my niece? Did I impale him with the regal crown? Did I put Henry from his native right?

src: What is his name?
trg: Lucentio, gentle sir.

src: here lies the county slain, And Juliet bleeding, warm, and newly dead, Who here hath lain these two days buried. Go, tell the prince: run to the Capulets: Raise up the Montagues: some others search:
trg: We see the ground whereon these woes do lie; But the true ground of all these piteous woes We cannot without circumstance descry.

src: And see another, as I see thee now, Deck'd in thy rights, as thou art stall'd in mine! Long die thy happy days before thy death;
trg: And, after many lengthen'd hours of grief, Die neither mother, wife, nor England's queen!

src: The love of wicked men converts to fear; That fear to hate, and hate turns one or both To worthy danger and deserved death.
trg: My guilt be on my head, and there an end. Take leave and part; for you must part forthwith.

src: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?
trg: So please your lordship to accept our duty.

src: And, as we march, our strength will be augmented In every county as we go along. Strike up the drum; cry 'Courage!' and away. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Great lords, wise men ne'er sit and wail their loss, But cheerly seek how to redress their harms.

src: The more my wrong, the more his spite appears: What, did he marry me to famish me? Beggars, that come unto my father's door, Upon entreaty have a present aims;
trg: If not, elsewhere they meet with charity:

src: I will not do't.
trg: But can you, if you would?

src: Dost grant me, hedgehog? then, God grant me too Thou mayst be damned for that wicked deed! O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous!
trg: The fitter for the King of heaven, that hath him.

src: And why, my lady wisdom? hold your tongue, Good prudence; smatter with your gossips, go.
trg: I speak no treason.

src: Conceit, more rich in matter than in words, Brags of his substance, not of ornament: They are but beggars that can count their worth;
trg: But my true love is grown to such excess I cannot sum up sum of half my wealth.

src: My true Paulina, We shall not marry till thou bid'st us.
trg: That Shall be when your first queen's again in breath; Never till then.

src: 'Tis more, 'tis more, his son is elder, sir; His son is thirty.
trg: Will you tell me that? His son was but a ward two years ago.

src: Ho, by your leave!
trg: Good morning to you, fair and gracious daughter.

src: Why, here's no crab; and therefore look not sour.
trg: There is, there is.

src: I will prove so, sir, to my power.
trg: Ay, by any means prove a tall fellow: if I do not wonder how thou darest venture to be drunk, not being a tall fellow, trust me not. Hark!

src: Thy hounds shall make the welkin answer them And fetch shrill echoes from the hollow earth.
trg: Say thou wilt course; thy greyhounds are as swift As breathed stags, ay, fleeter than the roe.

src: I warrant you, my lord.
trg: Catesby!

src: God hold it, to your honour's good content!
trg: Gramercy, fellow: there, drink that for me.

src: and now, arriving A place of potency and sway o' the state, If he should still malignantly remain Fast foe to the plebeii, your voices might Be curses to yourselves?
trg: Thus to have said, As you were fore-advised, had touch'd his spirit And tried his inclination; so putting him to rage, You should have ta'en the advantage of his choler And pass'd him unelected.

src: Nay, come, Kate, come; you must not look so sour.
trg: It is my fashion, when I see a crab.

src: I warrant you. But, sir, here comes your boy; 'Twere good he were school'd.
trg: Fear you not him. Sirrah Biondello, Now do your duty throughly, I advise you: Imagine 'twere the right Vincentio.

src: I'll bring him to you. Let me desire your company: he must come, Or what is worst will follow.
trg: Pray you, let's to him.

src: ' And even here brake off, and came away.
trg: What tongueless blocks were they! would not they speak?

src: O Buckingham, now do I play the touch, To try if thou be current gold indeed Young Edward lives: think now what I would say.
trg: Say on, my loving lord.

src: In faith, I will. Let me peruse this face. Mercutio's kinsman, noble County Paris! What said my man, when my betossed soul Did not attend him as we rode?
trg: I think He told me Paris should have married Juliet: Said he not so? or did I dream it so? Or am I mad, hearing him talk of Juliet, To think it was so?

src: Madam, I know not, nor I greatly care not: God knows I had as lief be none as one.
trg: Well, bear you well in this new spring of time, Lest you be cropp'd before you come to prime. What news from Oxford? hold those justs and triumphs?

src: No, first let's reason with him.
trg: Where art thou, keeper? give me a cup of wine.

src: My lord, I would that Thursday were to-morrow.
trg: Well get you gone: o' Thursday be it, then. Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed, Prepare her, wife, against this wedding-day. Farewell, my lord. Light to my chamber, ho! Afore me!

src: Most bounteous sir, Look, if it please you, on this man condemn'd, As if my brother lived: I partly think A due sincerity govern'd his deeds, Till he did look on me: since it is so, Let him not die.
trg: My brother had but justice, In that he did the thing for which he died: For Angelo, His act did not o'ertake his bad intent, And must be buried but as an intent That perish'd by the way:

src: as for the rest appeall'd, It issues from the rancour of a villain, A recreant and most degenerate traitor Which in myself I boldly will defend;
trg: And interchangeably hurl down my gage Upon this overweening traitor's foot, To prove myself a loyal gentleman Even in the best blood chamber'd in his bosom.

src: Tut, fear not me.
trg: But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista?

src: And he that hath commanded is the king.
trg: Erroneous vassal! the great King of kings Hath in the tables of his law commanded That thou shalt do no murder: and wilt thou, then, Spurn at his edict and fulfil a man's? Take heed;

src: Amen.
trg: Thou concludest like the sanctimonious pirate, that went to sea with the Ten Commandments, but scraped one out of the table.

src: They love not poison that do poison need, Nor do I thee: though I did wish him dead, I hate the murderer, love him murdered.
trg: The guilt of conscience take thou for thy labour, But neither my good word nor princely favour: With Cain go wander through shades of night, And never show thy head by day nor light.

src: Tut, that's a foolish observation: Richard, be Duke of Gloucester. Now to London, To see these honours in possession. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Under this thick-grown brake we'll shroud ourselves; For through this laund anon the deer will come; And in this covert will we make our stand, Culling the principal of all the deer.

src: For sleeping England long time have I watch'd; Watching breeds leanness, leanness is all gaunt: The pleasure that some fathers feed upon, Is my strict fast; I mean, my children's looks;
trg: And therein fasting, hast thou made me gaunt: Gaunt am I for the grave, gaunt as a grave, Whose hollow womb inherits nought but bones.

src: therefore I'll watch him Till he be dieted to my request, And then I'll set upon him.
trg: You know the very road into his kindness, And cannot lose your way.

src: Thy place is fill'd, thy sceptre wrung from thee, Thy balm wash'd off wherewith thou wast anointed:
trg: No bending knee will call thee Caesar now, No humble suitors press to speak for right, No, not a man comes for redress of thee; For how can I help them, and not myself?

src: I thank my liege, that in regard of me He shortens four years of my son's exile: But little vantage shall I reap thereby;
trg: For, ere the six years that he hath to spend Can change their moons and bring their times about My oil-dried lamp and time-bewasted light Shall be extinct with age and endless night;

src: Dost thou love pictures?
trg: we will fetch thee straight Adonis painted by a running brook, And Cytherea all in sedges hid, Which seem to move and wanton with her breath, Even as the waving sedges play with wind.

src: Why, is he not with the queen?
trg: No, my good Lord; he hath forsook the court, Broken his staff of office and dispersed The household of the king.

src: And four shall quickly draw out my command, Which men are best inclined.
trg: March on, my fellows: Make good this ostentation, and you shall Divide in all with us.

src: Unless for that he comes to be your liege, You cannot guess wherefore the Welshman comes. Thou wilt revolt, and fly to him, I fear.
trg: No, mighty liege; therefore mistrust me not.

src: Let us be clear'd Of being tyrannous, since we so openly Proceed in justice, which shall have due course, Even to the guilt or the purgation. Produce the prisoner.
trg: It is his highness' pleasure that the queen Appear in person here in court. Silence!

src: Katharina, I charge thee, tell these headstrong women What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.
trg: Come, come, you're mocking: we will have no telling.

src: Ha!
trg: No more.

src: Let them assemble, And on a safer judgment all revoke Your ignorant election; enforce his pride, And his old hate unto you;
trg: besides, forget not With what contempt he wore the humble weed, How in his suit he scorn'd you;

src: Gentle son Edward, thou wilt stay with me?
trg: Ay, to be murder'd by his enemies.

src: Thou poisonous slave, got by the devil himself Upon thy wicked dam, come forth!
trg: As wicked dew as e'er my mother brush'd With raven's feather from unwholesome fen Drop on you both! a south-west blow on ye And blister you all o'er!

src: The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.
trg: 'Tis all one, I will show myself a tyrant: when I have fought with the men, I will be cruel with the maids, and cut off their heads.

src: Then let the earth be drunken with our blood: I'll kill my horse, because I will not fly. Why stand we like soft-hearted women here, Wailing our losses, whiles the foe doth rage;
trg: And look upon, as if the tragedy Were play'd in jest by counterfeiting actors?

src: Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby Am I; And as I truly fight, defend me heaven!
trg: On pain of death, no person be so bold Or daring-hardy as to touch the lists, Except the marshal and such officers Appointed to direct these fair designs.

src: Good morrow, father.
trg: Benedicite! What early tongue so sweet saluteth me? Young son, it argues a distemper'd head So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed:

src: Therefore do nimble-pinion'd doves draw love, And therefore hath the wind-swift Cupid wings.
trg: Now is the sun upon the highmost hill Of this day's journey, and from nine till twelve Is three long hours, yet she is not come.

src: Kind sister, thanks: we'll enter all together. And, in good time, here the lieutenant comes. Master lieutenant, pray you, by your leave, How doth the prince, and my young son of York?
trg: Right well, dear madam. By your patience, I may not suffer you to visit them; The king hath straitly charged the contrary.

src: Comfort, dear mother: God is much displeased That you take with unthankfulness, his doing:
trg: In common worldly things, 'tis call'd ungrateful, With dull unwilligness to repay a debt Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent;

src: what care I What curious eye doth quote deformities? Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me.
trg: Come, knock and enter; and no sooner in, But every man betake him to his legs.

src: My gracious uncle, let me know my fault: On what condition stands it and wherein?
trg: Even in condition of the worst degree, In gross rebellion and detested treason: Thou art a banish'd man, and here art come Before the expiration of thy time, In braving arms against thy sovereign.

src: We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards: This wide-chapp'd rascal--would thou mightst lie drowning The washing of ten tides!
trg: He'll be hang'd yet, Though every drop of water swear against it And gape at widest to glut him.

src: And, Henry, hadst thou sway'd as kings should do, Or as thy father and his father did, Giving no ground unto the house of York, They never then had sprung like summer flies;
trg: I and ten thousand in this luckless realm Had left no mourning widows for our death; And thou this day hadst kept thy chair in peace. For what doth cherish weeds but gentle air?

src: The Tower, the Tower.
trg: O Ned, sweet Ned! speak to thy mother, boy! Canst thou not speak? O traitors! murderers!

src: Pardon, master; I will be correspondent to command And do my spiriting gently.
trg: Do so, and after two days I will discharge thee.

src: I give this heavy weight from off my head And this unwieldy sceptre from my hand, The pride of kingly sway from out my heart;
trg: With mine own tears I wash away my balm, With mine own hands I give away my crown, With mine own tongue deny my sacred state, With mine own breath release all duty's rites:

src: No, madam, no; I may not leave it so: I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.
trg: Let me but meet you, ladies, one hour hence, And I'll salute your grace of York as mother, And reverend looker on, of two fair queens.

src: What's open made to justice, That justice seizes: what know the laws That thieves do pass on thieves? 'Tis very pregnant, The jewel that we find, we stoop and take't Because we see it;
trg: but what we do not see We tread upon, and never think of it. You may not so extenuate his offence For I have had such faults;

src: My husband lives, that Tybalt would have slain; And Tybalt's dead, that would have slain my husband: All this is comfort; wherefore weep I then?
trg: Some word there was, worser than Tybalt's death, That murder'd me: I would forget it fain; But, O, it presses to my memory, Like damned guilty deeds to sinners' minds:

src: Know, Rome, that all alone Marcius did fight Within Corioli gates: where he hath won, With fame, a name to Caius Marcius; these In honour follows Coriolanus. Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!
trg: Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!

src: so tedious is this day As is the night before some festival To an impatient child that hath new robes And may not wear them. O, here comes my nurse, And she brings news;
trg: and every tongue that speaks But Romeo's name speaks heavenly eloquence. Now, nurse, what news? What hast thou there? the cords That Romeo bid thee fetch?

src: You know him not, sir.
trg: Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee, For in Baptista's keep my treasure is:

src: I wish I had a cause to seek him there, To oppose his hatred fully. Welcome home. Behold, these are the tribunes of the people, The tongues o' the common mouth: I do despise them;
trg: For they do prank them in authority, Against all noble sufferance.

src: What villain madam?
trg: That same villain, Romeo.

src: Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life, I pour the helpless balm of my poor eyes. Cursed be the hand that made these fatal holes! Cursed be the heart that had the heart to do it!
trg: Cursed the blood that let this blood from hence!

src: I pray now, call her. Withdraw yourselves.
trg: And, madam, I must be present at your conference.

src: 'Tis most like he will.
trg: It shall be to him then as our good wills, A sure destruction.

src: Thine eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.
trg: Would they were basilisks, to strike thee dead!

src: But who comes here? the new-deliver'd Hastings?
trg: Good time of day unto my gracious lord!

src: I mean, my lords, those powers that the queen Hath raised in Gallia have arrived our coast And, as we hear, march on to fight with us.
trg: A little gale will soon disperse that cloud And blow it to the source from whence it came: The very beams will dry those vapours up, For every cloud engenders not a storm.

src: Father, what news? what is the prince's doom? What sorrow craves acquaintance at my hand, That I yet know not?
trg: Too familiar Is my dear son with such sour company: I bring thee tidings of the prince's doom.

src: and love to Richard Is a strange brooch in this all-hating world.
trg: Hail, royal prince!

src: Go in to him, and fetch him out.
trg: He is coming, sir, he is coming; I hear his straw rustle.

src: Ha! durst the traitor breathe out so proud words? Well I will arm me, being thus forewarn'd: They shall have wars and pay for their presumption. But say, is Warwick friends with Margaret?
trg: Ay, gracious sovereign; they are so link'd in friendship That young Prince Edward marries Warwick's daughter.

src: She may, Lord Rivers! why, who knows not so? She may do more, sir, than denying that:
trg: She may help you to many fair preferments, And then deny her aiding hand therein, And lay those honours on your high deserts. What may she not? She may, yea, marry, may she--

src: Come, come, you're mocking: we will have no telling.
trg: Come on, I say; and first begin with her.

src: My lord,--
trg: No lord of thine, thou haught insulting man, Nor no man's lord; I have no name, no title, No, not that name was given me at the font, But 'tis usurp'd:

src: Will't please your lordship drink a cup of sack?
trg: Will't please your honour taste of these conserves?

src: Master Barnardine! you must rise and be hanged. Master Barnardine!
trg: What, ho, Barnardine!

src: Then is there here one Master Caper, at the suit of Master Three-pile the mercer, for some four suits of peach-coloured satin, which now peaches him a beggar.
trg: all great doers in our trade, and are now 'for the Lord's sake.'

src: if you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long, and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap. Cheerly, good hearts! Out of our way, I say.
trg: I have great comfort from this fellow: methinks he hath no drowning mark upon him; his complexion is perfect gallows. Stand fast, good Fate, to his hanging:

src: It shall be so; he shall to Brittany. Come, therefore, let's about it speedily. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Now, brother Richard, Lord Hastings, and the rest, Yet thus far fortune maketh us amends, And says that once more I shall interchange My waned state for Henry's regal crown.

src: No, I'll none of you.
trg: Why, my sweet lord?

src: Hark! a drum.
trg: Catesby, o'erlook the walls.

src: One Isabel, a sister, desires access to you.
trg: Teach her the way. O heavens! Why does my blood thus muster to my heart, Making both it unable for itself, And dispossessing all my other parts Of necessary fitness?

src: O ill-dispersing wind of misery! O my accursed womb, the bed of death! A cockatrice hast thou hatch'd to the world, Whose unavoided eye is murderous.
trg: Come, madam, come; I in all haste was sent.

src: Condition! I would I were a Roman; for I cannot, Being a Volsce, be that I am. Condition! What good condition can a treaty find I' the part that is at mercy?
trg: Five times, Marcius, I have fought with thee: so often hast thou beat me, And wouldst do so, I think, should we encounter As often as we eat.

src: Call them again, my lord, and accept their suit.
trg: Do, good my lord, lest all the land do rue it.

src: You lords and heads o' the state, perfidiously He has betray'd your business, and given up, For certain drops of salt, your city Rome, I say 'your city,' to his wife and mother;
trg: Hear'st thou, Mars?

src: God-den, our neighbours.
trg: God-den to you all, god-den to you all.

src: O Paulina, We honour you with trouble: but we came To see the statue of our queen: your gallery Have we pass'd through, not without much content In many singularities;
trg: but we saw not That which my daughter came to look upon, The statue of her mother.

src: Mum.
trg: Come, sir: did you set these women on to slander Lord Angelo? they have confessed you did.

src: But I, who never knew how to entreat, Nor never needed that I should entreat, Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep, With oath kept waking and with brawling fed:
trg: And that which spites me more than all these wants, He does it under name of perfect love; As who should say, if I should sleep or eat, 'Twere deadly sickness or else present death.

src: I doubt it not; and all these woes shall serve For sweet discourses in our time to come.
trg: O God, I have an ill-divining soul! Methinks I see thee, now thou art below, As one dead in the bottom of a tomb: Either my eyesight fails, or thou look'st pale.

src: Faith, sir, few of any wit in such matters: as they are chosen, they are glad to choose me for them; I do it for some piece of money, and go through with all.
trg: Look you bring me in the names of some six or seven, the most sufficient of your parish.

src: I take it up; and by that sword I swear Which gently laid my knighthood on my shoulder, I'll answer thee in any fair degree, Or chivalrous design of knightly trial:
trg: And when I mount, alive may I not light, If I be traitor or unjustly fight!

src: show your sheep-biting face, and be hanged an hour! Will't not off?
trg: Thou art the first knave that e'er madest a duke. First, provost, let me bail these gentle three. Sneak not away, sir; for the friar and you Must have a word anon. Lay hold on him.

src: An 'twere to give again,--but 'tis no matter.
trg: Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your voices that I may be consul, I have here the customary gown.

src: Think you, but that I know our state secure, I would be so triumphant as I am?
trg: The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London, Were jocund, and supposed their state was sure, And they indeed had no cause to mistrust; But yet, you see how soon the day o'ercast.

src: Indeed, he should be a footman by the garments he has left with thee: if this be a horseman's coat, it hath seen very hot service. Lend me thy hand, I'll help thee: come, lend me thy hand.
trg: O, good sir, tenderly, O!

src: Will not you go?
trg: I am attended at the cypress grove: I pray you-- 'Tis south the city mills--bring me word thither How the world goes, that to the pace of it I may spur on my journey.

src: Well, but what's o'clock?
trg: Upon the stroke of ten.

src: Wondrous! ay, I warrant you, and not without his true purchasing.
trg: The gods grant them true!

src: I like it well: good Grumio, fetch it me.
trg: I cannot tell; I fear 'tis choleric. What say you to a piece of beef and mustard?

src: He will be talking.
trg: Which, of he or Adrian, for a good wager, first begins to crow?

src: I am agreed; and would I had given him the best horse in Padua to begin his wooing that would thoroughly woo her, wed her and bed her and rid the house of her! Come on.
trg: I pray, sir, tell me, is it possible That love should of a sudden take such hold?

src: At my poor house look to behold this night Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light:
trg: Such comfort as do lusty young men feel When well-apparell'd April on the heel Of limping winter treads, even such delight Among fresh female buds shall you this night Inherit at my house;

src: Then in plain terms tell her my loving tale.
trg: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.

src: Well, think of marriage now; younger than you, Here in Verona, ladies of esteem, Are made already mothers: by my count, I was your mother much upon these years That you are now a maid.
trg: Thus then in brief: The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.

src: Then 'twas my turn to fly, and now 'tis thine.
trg: You said so much before, and yet you fled.

src: O, I am slain! If thou be merciful, Open the tomb, lay me with Juliet.
trg: In faith, I will. Let me peruse this face. Mercutio's kinsman, noble County Paris! What said my man, when my betossed soul Did not attend him as we rode?

src: I pray you, husband, be not so disquiet: The meat was well, if you were so contented.
trg: I tell thee, Kate, 'twas burnt and dried away; And I expressly am forbid to touch it, For it engenders choler, planteth anger;

src: Nay, take me with thee, good sweet Exeter: Not that I fear to stay, but love to go Whither the queen intends. Forward; away! 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Here burns my candle out; ay, here it dies, Which, whiles it lasted, gave King Henry light. O Lancaster, I fear thy overthrow More than my body's parting with my soul!

src: Petruchio is my name; Antonio's son, A man well known throughout all Italy.
trg: I know him well: you are welcome for his sake.

src: Say you?
trg: Marry, sir, I think, if you handled her privately, she would sooner confess: perchance, publicly, she'll be ashamed.

src: No, my lord.
trg: Are you a maid?

src: Pedlar, let's have the first choice. Follow me, girls.
trg: And you shall pay well for 'em. Will you buy any tape, Or lace for your cape, My dainty duck, my dear-a? Any silk, any thread, Any toys for your head, Of the new'st and finest, finest wear-a?

src: How now! what's the matter?
trg: What, is the man lunatic?

src: Why, how now, daughter Katharina! in your dumps?
trg: Call you me daughter? now, I promise you You have show'd a tender fatherly regard, To wish me wed to one half lunatic;

src: Prepare you, lords, for Edward is at hand. Ready to fight; therefore be resolute.
trg: I thought no less: it is his policy To haste thus fast, to find us unprovided.

src: What countryman, I pray?
trg: Of Mantua.

src: O, then began the tempest to my soul, Who pass'd, methought, the melancholy flood, With that grim ferryman which poets write of, Unto the kingdom of perpetual night.
trg: The first that there did greet my stranger soul, Was my great father-in-law, renowned Warwick; Who cried aloud, 'What scourge for perjury Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?

src: And he that will not fight for such a hope. Go home to bed, and like the owl by day, If he arise, be mock'd and wonder'd at.
trg: Thanks, gentle Somerset; sweet Oxford, thanks.

src: And we create, in absence of ourself, Our uncle York lord governor of England; For he is just and always loved us well. Come on, our queen: to-morrow must we part;
trg: Be merry, for our time of stay is short

src: Thy garments are not spotted with our blood, Nor thou within the compass of my curse.
trg: Nor no one here; for curses never pass The lips of those that breathe them in the air.

src: O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for: Take up my mistress' gown to his master's use! O, fie, fie, fie!
My lord, will't please you to fall to?
trg: Taste of it first, as thou art wont to do.

src: What, art so near? If thou'lt see a thing to talk on when thou art dead and rotten, come hither. What ailest thou, man?
trg: I have seen two such sights, by sea and by land! but I am not to say it is a sea, for it is now the sky: betwixt the firmament and it you cannot thrust a bodkin's point.

src: You, my lord, best know, Who least will seem to do so, my past life Hath been as continent, as chaste, as true, As I am now unhappy;
trg: which is more Than history can pattern, though devised And play'd to take spectators. For life, I prize it As I weigh grief, which I would spare:

src: He's a lamb indeed, that baes like a bear.
trg: He's a bear indeed, that lives like a lamb. You two are old men: tell me one thing that I shall ask you.

src: Name not the god, thou boy of tears!
trg: Ha!

src: Nor, gentle daughter, fear you not at all. He is your husband on a pre-contract: To bring you thus together, 'tis no sin, Sith that the justice of your title to him Doth flourish the deceit.
trg: Come, let us go: Our corn's to reap, for yet our tithe's to sow.

src: Harry of Hereford, Lancaster and Derby, Receive thy lance; and God defend the right!
trg: Strong as a tower in hope, I cry amen.

src: Nay, I knew by his face that there was something in him: he had, sir, a kind of face, methought,--I cannot tell how to term it.
trg: He had so; looking as it were--would I were hanged, but I thought there was more in him than I could think.

src: Even as thou wilt, sweet Warwick, let it be; For in thy shoulder do I build my seat, And never will I undertake the thing Wherein thy counsel and consent is wanting.
trg: Richard, I will create thee Duke of Gloucester, And George, of Clarence: Warwick, as ourself, Shall do and undo as him pleaseth best.

src: This forenamed maid hath yet in her the continuance of her first affection:
trg: his unjust unkindness, that in all reason should have quenched her love, hath, like an impediment in the current, made it more violent and unruly. Go you to Angelo;

src: Good friar, I know you do, and have found it.
trg: Take, then, this your companion by the hand, Who hath a story ready for your ear. I shall attend your leisure: but make haste; The vaporous night approaches.

src: He does me double wrong That wounds me with the flatteries of his tongue. Discharge my followers: let them hence away, From Richard's night to Bolingbroke's fair day.
trg: So that by this intelligence we learn The Welshmen are dispersed, and Salisbury Is gone to meet the king, who lately landed With some few private friends upon this coast.

src: Why, what is pomp, rule, reign, but earth and dust? And, live we how we can, yet die we must.
trg: Ah, Warwick, Warwick! wert thou as we are. We might recover all our loss again; The queen from France hath brought a puissant power: Even now we heard the news: ah, could'st thou fly!

src: Here, sir! here, sir! here, sir! here, sir! You logger-headed and unpolish'd grooms! What, no attendance? no regard? no duty? Where is the foolish knave I sent before?
trg: Here, sir; as foolish as I was before.

src: It is not truer he is Angelo Than this is all as true as it is strange: Nay, it is ten times true; for truth is truth To the end of reckoning.
trg: Away with her! Poor soul, She speaks this in the infirmity of sense.

src: Where be the thronging troops that follow'd thee? Decline all this, and see what now thou art: For happy wife, a most distressed widow; For joyful mother, one that wails the name;
trg: For queen, a very caitiff crown'd with care; For one being sued to, one that humbly sues; For one that scorn'd at me, now scorn'd of me; For one being fear'd of all, now fearing one;

src: If I do so, it will be of more price, Being spoke behind your back, than to your face.
trg: Poor soul, thy face is much abused with tears.

src: Is not this true?
trg: Ay, sir.

src: And Warwick, doing what you gave in charge, Is now dishonoured by this new marriage.
trg: What if both Lewis and Warwick be appeased By such invention as I can devise?

src: Is it good den?
trg: 'Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of the dial is now upon the prick of noon.

src: The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabour More than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue From every meaner man.
trg: Come I too late?

src: Sir, at the farthest for a week or two: But then up farther, and as for as Rome; And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.
trg: What countryman, I pray?

src: if I then deny it, 'Tis none of mine.
trg: say't and justify't.

src: What is her burying grave that is her womb, And from her womb children of divers kind We sucking on her natural bosom find, Many for many virtues excellent, None but for some and yet all different.
trg: O, mickle is the powerful grace that lies In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities:

src: 'Twill grieve your grace my sons should call you father.
trg: No more than when my daughters call thee mother. Thou art a widow, and thou hast some children; And, by God's mother, I, being but a bachelor, Have other some:

src: I have; 'tis ready.
trg: Have you collected them by tribes?

src: Now it's twenty-seven: every gash was an enemy's grave. Hark! the trumpets.
trg: These are the ushers of Marcius: before him he carries noise, and behind him he leaves tears: Death, that dark spirit, in 's nervy arm doth lie; Which, being advanced, declines, and then men die.

src: Have you thought on A place whereto you'll go?
trg: Not any yet: But as the unthought-on accident is guilty To what we wildly do, so we profess Ourselves to be the slaves of chance and flies Of every wind that blows.

src: True.
trg: and that there were No earthly mean to save him, but that either You must lay down the treasures of your body To this supposed, or else to let him suffer; What would you do?

src: As I did sleep under this yew-tree here, I dreamt my master and another fought, And that my master slew him.
trg: Romeo! Alack, alack, what blood is this, which stains The stony entrance of this sepulchre? What mean these masterless and gory swords To lie discolour'd by this place of peace? Romeo! O, pale!

src: Mistake no more: I am not Licio, Nor a musician, as I seem to be; But one that scorn to live in this disguise, For such a one as leaves a gentleman, And makes a god of such a cullion:
trg: Know, sir, that I am call'd Hortensio.

src: O most kind maid, It was the swift celerity of his death, Which I did think with slower foot came on, That brain'd my purpose. But, peace be with him!
trg: That life is better life, past fearing death, Than that which lives to fear: make it your comfort, So happy is your brother.

src: Welcome, my lords. I wot your love pursues A banish'd traitor: all my treasury Is yet but unfelt thanks, which more enrich'd Shall be your love and labour's recompense.
trg: Your presence makes us rich, most noble lord.

src: There is no other way Unless thou couldst put on some other shape, And not be Richard that hath done all this.
trg: Say that I did all this for love of her.

src: Brother, I go; I'll win them, fear it not: And thus most humbly I do take my leave. Sir John and Sir Hugh Mortimer, mine uncles, You are come to Sandal in a happy hour;
trg: The army of the queen mean to besiege us.

src: She was, good Curtis, before this frost: but, thou knowest, winter tames man, woman and beast; for it hath tamed my old master and my new mistress and myself, fellow Curtis.
trg: Away, you three-inch fool! I am no beast.

src: Dismiss them home. Here comes his mother.
trg: Let's not meet her.

src: And, for the good report I hear of you And for the love he beareth to your daughter And she to him, to stay him not too long, I am content, in a good father's care, To have him match'd;
trg: and if you please to like No worse than I, upon some agreement Me shall you find ready and willing With one consent to have her so bestow'd;

src: Hark, how they knock! Who's there? Romeo, arise; Thou wilt be taken. Stay awhile! Stand up; Run to my study. By and by! God's will, What simpleness is this! I come, I come! Who knocks so hard?
trg: whence come you? what's your will?

src: We do it not alone, sir.
trg: I know you can do very little alone; for your helps are many, or else your actions would grow wondrous single: your abilities are too infant-like for doing much alone. You talk of pride:

src: I thought of her, Even in these looks I made. But your petition Is yet unanswer'd. I will to your father: Your honour not o'erthrown by your desires, I am friend to them and you:
trg: upon which errand I now go toward him; therefore follow me And mark what way I make: come, good my lord.

src: If thou remember'st aught ere thou camest here, How thou camest here thou mayst.
trg: But that I do not.

src: So it is.
trg: Then make your garden rich in gillyvors, And do not call them bastards.

src: Why, just, my lord, and that is Angelo, Who thinks he knows that he ne'er knew my body, But knows he thinks that he knows Isabel's.
trg: This is a strange abuse. Let's see thy face.

src: Well, what then?
trg: The former agents, if they did complain, What could the belly answer?

src: ' And more he would have said, and more he spoke, Which sounded like a clamour in a vault, That mought not be distinguished;
trg: but at last I well might hear, delivered with a groan, 'O, farewell, Warwick!'

src: What, weeping-ripe, my Lord Northumberland? Think but upon the wrong he did us all, And that will quickly dry thy melting tears.
trg: Here's for my oath, here's for my father's death.

src: Ay, you have been a mouse-hunt in your time; But I will watch you from such watching now.
trg: A jealous hood, a jealous hood! Now, fellow, What's there?

src: rewards His deeds with doing them, and is content To spend the time to end it.
trg: He's right noble: Let him be call'd for.

src: Nay, then you lie: it is the blessed sun.
trg: Then, God be bless'd, it is the blessed sun: But sun it is not, when you say it is not; And the moon changes even as your mind. What you will have it named, even that it is;

src: In God's name, lead; your king's name be obey'd: And what God will, that let your king perform; And what he will, I humbly yield unto. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Brother of Gloucester, at Saint Alban's field This lady's husband, Sir Richard Grey, was slain, His lands then seized on by the conqueror: Her suit is now to repossess those lands;

src: God gi' god-den. I pray, sir, can you read?
trg: Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.

src: For my authority bears of a credent bulk, That no particular scandal once can touch But it confounds the breather.
trg: He should have lived, Save that riotous youth, with dangerous sense, Might in the times to come have ta'en revenge, By so receiving a dishonour'd life With ransom of such shame.

src: and though I must be content to bear with those that say you are reverend grave men, yet they lie deadly that tell you you have good faces.
trg: If you see this in the map of my microcosm, follows it that I am known well enough too? what barm can your bisson conspectuities glean out of this character, if I be known well enough too?

src: What comfort, man? how is't with aged Gaunt?
trg: O how that name befits my composition! Old Gaunt indeed, and gaunt in being old: Within me grief hath kept a tedious fast; And who abstains from meat that is not gaunt?

src: 'Twas you that kill'd young Rutland, was it not?
trg: Ay, and old York, and yet not satisfied.

src: What good is cover'd with the face of heaven, To be discover'd, that can do me good?
trg: The advancement of your children, gentle lady.

src: Why, then the world and all that's in't is nothing; The covering sky is nothing; Bohemia nothing; My wife is nothing; nor nothing have these nothings, If this be nothing.
trg: Good my lord, be cured Of this diseased opinion, and betimes; For 'tis most dangerous.

src: If ever he return and I can speak to him, I will open my lips in vain, or discover his government.
trg: That shall not be much amiss: Yet, as the matter now stands, he will avoid your accusation; he made trial of you only. Therefore fasten your ear on my advisings:

src: commends it to your blessing.
trg: Out! A mankind witch! Hence with her, out o' door: A most intelligencing bawd!

src: Thou hast. Where was she born? speak; tell me.
trg: Sir, in Argier.

src: To-morrow; to-day; presently; you shall have the drum struck up this afternoon: 'tis, as it were, a parcel of their feast, and to be executed ere they wipe their lips.
trg: Why, then we shall have a stirring world again. This peace is nothing, but to rust iron, increase tailors, and breed ballad-makers.

src: Amen!
trg: What?

src: But he, my lord, is gone to Ravenspurgh, To offer service to the Duke of Hereford, And sent me over by Berkeley, to discover What power the Duke of York had levied there;
trg: Then with directions to repair to Ravenspurgh.

src: He that trusts to you, Where he should find you lions, finds you hares; Where foxes, geese: you are no surer, no, Than is the coal of fire upon the ice, Or hailstone in the sun.
trg: Your virtue is To make him worthy whose offence subdues him And curse that justice did it. Who deserves greatness Deserves your hate;

src: Marry, sir, to get a husband for her sister.
trg: A husband! a devil.

src: Join not with grief, fair woman, do not so, To make my end too sudden: learn, good soul, To think our former state a happy dream; From which awaked, the truth of what we are Shows us but this:
trg: I am sworn brother, sweet, To grim Necessity, and he and I Will keep a league till death. Hie thee to France And cloister thee in some religious house:

src: We know't, we know't.
trg: Let us kill him, and we'll have corn at our own price. Is't a verdict?

src: I am a subject, And I challenge law: attorneys are denied me; And therefore, personally I lay my claim To my inheritance of free descent.
trg: The noble duke hath been too much abused.

src: Which God revenge!
trg: To fight on Edward's party for the crown; And for his meed, poor lord, he is mew'd up. I would to God my heart were flint, like Edward's;

src: Are you contented to resign the crown?
trg: Ay, no; no, ay; for I must nothing be; Therefore no no, for I resign to thee. Now mark me, how I will undo myself;

src: See that he be convey'd unto the Tower: And go we, brothers, to the man that took him, To question of his apprehension. Widow, go you along. Lords, use her honourably.
trg: Ay, Edward will use women honourably. Would he were wasted, marrow, bones and all, That from his loins no hopeful branch may spring, To cross me from the golden time I look for!

src: Summon a session, that we may arraign Our most disloyal lady, for, as she hath Been publicly accused, so shall she have A just and open trial. While she lives My heart will be a burthen to me.
trg: Leave me, And think upon my bidding.

src: I told him that your father was at Venice, And that you look'd for him this day in Padua.
trg: Thou'rt a tall fellow: hold thee that to drink. Here comes Baptista: set your countenance, sir. Signior Baptista, you are happily met. Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of:

src: I may, and will, if she be so contented: She will be pleased; then wherefore should I doubt? Hap what hap may, I'll roundly go about her: It shall go hard if Cambio go without her.
trg: Come on, i' God's name; once more toward our father's. Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!

src: O, speak no more, for I have heard too much.
trg: Say how he died, for I will hear it all.

src: That hand shall burn in never-quenching fire That staggers thus my person. Exton, thy fierce hand Hath with the king's blood stain'd the king's own land. Mount, mount, my soul!
trg: thy seat is up on high; Whilst my gross flesh sinks downward, here to die.

src: Give me another horse: bind up my wounds. Have mercy, Jesu!--Soft! I did but dream. O coward conscience, how dost thou afflict me! The lights burn blue. It is now dead midnight.
trg: Cold fearful drops stand on my trembling flesh. What do I fear?  myself?  there's none else by: Richard loves Richard; that is, I am I. Is there a murderer here?  No. Yes, I am: Then fly.

src: I care not: It is an heretic that makes the fire, Not she which burns in't. I'll not call you tyrant;
trg: But this most cruel usage of your queen, Not able to produce more accusation Than your own weak-hinged fancy, something savours Of tyranny and will ignoble make you, Yea, scandalous to the world.

src: Assist me, then, sweet Warwick, and I will; For hither we have broken in by force.
trg: We'll all assist you; he that flies shall die.

src: Ay; 'tis an honester service than to meddle with thy mistress. Thou pratest, and pratest; serve with thy trencher, hence!
trg: Where is this fellow?

src: You should account me the more virtuous that I have not been common in my love. I will, sir, flatter my sworn brother, the people, to earn a dearer estimation of them;
trg: 'tis a condition they account gentle: and since the wisdom of their choice is rather to have my hat than my heart, I will practise the insinuating nod and be off to them most counterfeitly;

src: An't please you, sir, to undertake the business for us, here is that gold I have: I'll make it as much more and leave this young man in pawn till I bring it you.
trg: After I have done what I promised?

src: Noble prince, As there comes light from heaven and words from breath, As there is sense in truth and truth in virtue, I am affianced this man's wife as strongly As words could make up vows:
trg: and, my good lord, But Tuesday night last gone in's garden-house He knew me as a wife. As this is true, Let me in safety raise me from my knees Or else for ever be confixed here, A marble monument!

src: Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master; That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long, To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.
trg: O master, master, I have watch'd so long That I am dog-weary: but at last I spied An ancient angel coming down the hill, Will serve the turn.

src: Wolves and bears, they say Casting their savageness aside have done Like offices of pity. Sir, be prosperous In more than this deed does require!
trg: And blessing Against this cruelty fight on thy side, Poor thing, condemn'd to loss!

src: Groan! why, no. But sadly tell me who.
trg: Bid a sick man in sadness make his will: Ah, word ill urged to one that is so ill! In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.

src: Go on, go on Thou canst not speak too much; I have deserved All tongues to talk their bitterest.
trg: Say no more: Howe'er the business goes, you have made fault I' the boldness of your speech.

src: for thy revenge Wrench up thy power to the highest.
trg: Wert thou the Hector That was the whip of your bragg'd progeny, Thou shouldst not scape me here. Officious, and not valiant, you have shamed me In your condemned seconds.

src: And then?
trg: And then he sends you word He dreamt to-night the boar had razed his helm: Besides, he says there are two councils held;

src: The which, how far off from the mind of Bolingbroke It is, such crimson tempest should bedrench The fresh green lap of fair King Richard's land, My stooping duty tenderly shall show.
trg: Go, signify as much, while here we march Upon the grassy carpet of this plain.

src: For the benefit of silence, would thou wert so too!
trg: Well, my lord.

src: He's sentenced; 'tis too late.
Here let us rest, if this rebellious earth Have any resting for her true king's queen. But soft, but see, or rather do not see, My fair rose wither:
trg: yet look up, behold, That you in pity may dissolve to dew, And wash him fresh again with true-love tears.

src: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?
trg: How but well, sir? how but well? It were impossible I should speed amiss.

src: Who may, in the ambush of my name, strike home, And yet my nature never in the fight To do in slander. And to behold his sway, I will, as 'twere a brother of your order, Visit both prince and people:
trg: therefore, I prithee, Supply me with the habit and instruct me How I may formally in person bear me Like a true friar. More reasons for this action At our more leisure shall I render you;

src: So doth the cony struggle in the net.
trg: So triumph thieves upon their conquer'd booty; So true men yield, with robbers so o'ermatch'd.

src: Your grant, or your denial, shall be mine: Yet I confess that often ere this day, When I have heard your king's desert recounted, Mine ear hath tempted judgment to desire.
trg: Then, Warwick, thus: our sister shall be Edward's; And now forthwith shall articles be drawn Touching the jointure that your king must make, Which with her dowry shall be counterpoised.

src: In one little body Thou counterfeit'st a bark, a sea, a wind; For still thy eyes, which I may call the sea, Do ebb and flow with tears; the bark thy body is, Sailing in this salt flood;
trg: the winds, thy sighs; Who, raging with thy tears, and they with them, Without a sudden calm, will overset Thy tempest-tossed body. How now, wife! Have you deliver'd to her our decree?

src: I understand thee well; and be thou sure, when he shall come to his account, he knows not What I can urge against him.
trg: Although it seems, And so he thinks, and is no less apparent To the vulgar eye, that he bears all things fairly.

src: Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh, Till I be brought to such a silly pass!
trg: Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?

src: I, by attorney, bless thee from thy mother Who prays continually for Richmond's good: So much for that. The silent hours steal on, And flaky darkness breaks within the east.
trg: In brief,--for so the season bids us be,-- Prepare thy battle early in the morning, And put thy fortune to the arbitrement Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.

src: My soul to heaven, my blood upon your heads!
trg: Had he been slaughter-man to all my kin, I should not for my life but weep with him. To see how inly sorrow gripes his soul.

src: My lord?
trg: The sun will not be seen to-day; The sky doth frown and lour upon our army. I would these dewy tears were from the ground. Not shine to-day! Why, what is that to me More than to Richmond?

src: In winter's tedious nights sit by the fire With good old folks and let them tell thee tales Of woeful ages long ago betid;
trg: And ere thou bid good night, to quit their griefs, Tell thou the lamentable tale of me And send the hearers weeping to their beds:

src: so long as nature Will bear up with this exercise, so long I daily vow to use it. Come and lead me Unto these sorrows.
trg: Thou art perfect then, our ship hath touch'd upon The deserts of Bohemia?

src: Why, therefore Warwick came to seek you out; And therefore comes my brother Montague. Attend me, lords.
trg: The proud insulting queen, With Clifford and the haught Northumberland, And of their feather many more proud birds, Have wrought the easy-melting king like wax.

src: I am thus bold to put your grace in mind Of what you promised me.
trg: Well, but what's o'clock?

src: If I prove honey-mouth'd let my tongue blister And never to my red-look'd anger be The trumpet any more. Pray you, Emilia, Commend my best obedience to the queen:
trg: If she dares trust me with her little babe, I'll show't the king and undertake to be Her advocate to the loud'st. We do not know How he may soften at the sight o' the child:

src: What's your will, father
trg: That now you are come, you will be gone. Leave me awhile with the maid: my mind promises with my habit no loss shall touch her by my company.

src: Any man that can write may answer a letter.
trg: Nay, he will answer the letter's master, how he dares, being dared.

src: What says he?
trg: Nay, nothing; all is said His tongue is now a stringless instrument; Words, life and all, old Lancaster hath spent.

src: Those gracious words revive my drooping thoughts And give my tongue-tied sorrows leave to speak.
trg: Now, therefore, be it known to noble Lewis, That Henry, sole possessor of my love, Is of a king become a banish'd man, And forced to live in Scotland a forlorn;

src: It shall be possible. Swear by this sword Thou wilt perform my bidding.
trg: I will, my lord.

src: And buried once, why not upon my head? Aumerle, thou weep'st, my tender-hearted cousin! We'll make foul weather with despised tears;
trg: Our sighs and they shall lodge the summer corn, And make a dearth in this revolting land. Or shall we play the wantons with our woes, And make some pretty match with shedding tears?

src: Here. Why dost thou spit at me?
trg: Would it were mortal poison, for thy sake!

src: of temporal royalties He thinks me now incapable;
trg: confederates-- So dry he was for sway--wi' the King of Naples To give him annual tribute, do him homage, Subject his coronet to his crown and bend The dukedom yet unbow'd--alas, poor Milan!

src: The hopeless word of 'never to return' Breathe I against thee, upon pain of life.
trg: A heavy sentence, my most sovereign liege, And all unlook'd for from your highness' mouth:

src: My inch of taper will be burnt and done, And blindfold death not let me see my son.
trg: Why uncle, thou hast many years to live.

src: I have seen two such sights, by sea and by land! but I am not to say it is a sea, for it is now the sky: betwixt the firmament and it you cannot thrust a bodkin's point.
trg: Why, boy, how is it?

src: Heavens grant that Warwick's words bewitch him not!
trg: Now Warwick, tell me, even upon thy conscience, Is Edward your true king? for I were loath To link with him that were not lawful chosen.

src: Ah, so much interest have I in thy sorrow As I had title in thy noble husband! I have bewept a worthy husband's death, And lived by looking on his images:
trg: But now two mirrors of his princely semblance Are crack'd in pieces by malignant death, And I for comfort have but one false glass, Which grieves me when I see my shame in him. Thou art a widow;

src: behold now presently, and swoon for what's to come upon thee. The glorious gods sit in hourly synod about thy particular prosperity, and love thee no worse than thy old father Menenius does!
trg: O my son, my son! thou art preparing fire for us; look thee, here's water to quench it. I was hardly moved to come to thee;

src: O, death's a great disguiser; and you may add to it. Shave the head, and tie the beard; and say it was the desire of the penitent to be so bared before his death: you know the course is common.
trg: If any thing fall to you upon this, more than thanks and good fortune, by the saint whom I profess, I will plead against it with my life.

src: If you thrive well, bring them to Baynard's Castle; Where you shall find me well accompanied With reverend fathers and well-learned bishops.
trg: I go: and towards three or four o'clock Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.

src: Tell her thou madest away her uncle Clarence, Her uncle Rivers; yea, and, for her sake, Madest quick conveyance with her good aunt Anne.
