trg: Come, come, you mock me; this is not the way To win our daughter.

src: Work you then.
trg: Hang, cur! hang, you whoreson, insolent noisemaker! We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.

src: With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons! To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle, He prettily and aptly taunts himself: So cunning and so young is wonderful.
trg: My lord, will't please you pass along? Myself and my good cousin Buckingham Will to your mother, to entreat of her To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.

src: I should leave grazing, were I of your flock, And only live by gazing.
trg: Out, alas! You'd be so lean, that blasts of January Would blow you through and through. Now, my fair'st friend, I would I had some flowers o' the spring that might Become your time of day;

src: Take it up straight: Within this hour bring me word 'tis done, And by good testimony, or I'll seize thy life, With what thou else call'st thine.
trg: If thou refuse And wilt encounter with my wrath, say so; The bastard brains with these my proper hands Shall I dash out. Go, take it to the fire; For thou set'st on thy wife.

src: Exton, I thank thee not; for thou hast wrought A deed of slander with thy fatal hand Upon my head and all this famous land.
trg: From your own mouth, my lord, did I this deed.

src: Madam, yourself are not exempt in this, Nor your son Dorset, Buckingham, nor you; You have been factious one against the other, Wife, love Lord Hastings, let him kiss your hand;
trg: And what you do, do it unfeignedly.

src: To be received plain, I'll speak more gross: Your brother is to die.
trg: So.

src: Alack, what trouble Was I then to you!
trg: O, a cherubim Thou wast that did preserve me. Thou didst smile. Infused with a fortitude from heaven, When I have deck'd the sea with drops full salt, Under my burthen groan'd;

src: Where did you study all this goodly speech?
trg: It is extempore, from my mother-wit.

src: Have you forgot the Duke of Hereford, boy?
trg: No, my good lord, for that is not forgot Which ne'er I did remember: to my knowledge, I never in my life did look on him.

src: but he, in twelve, Found truth in all but one: I, in twelve thousand, none. God save the king! Will no man say amen? Am I both priest and clerk? well then, amen. God save the king!
trg: although I be not he; And yet, amen, if heaven do think him me. To do what service am I sent for hither?

src: Thou dearest Perdita, With these forced thoughts, I prithee, darken not The mirth o' the feast. Or I'll be thine, my fair, Or not my father's.
trg: For I cannot be Mine own, nor any thing to any, if I be not thine. To this I am most constant, Though destiny say no. Be merry, gentle;

src: So many hours must I contemplate; So many hours must I sport myself; So many days my ewes have been with young; So many weeks ere the poor fools will ean: So many years ere I shall shear the fleece:
trg: So minutes, hours, days, months, and years, Pass'd over to the end they were created, Would bring white hairs unto a quiet grave. Ah, what a life were this! how sweet! how lovely!

src: Away, fond woman! were he twenty times my son, I would appeach him.
trg: Hadst thou groan'd for him As I have done, thou wouldst be more pitiful. But now I know thy mind; thou dost suspect That I have been disloyal to thy bed, And that he is a bastard, not thy son:

src: But the safer when 'tis back'd with France.
trg: 'Tis better using France than trusting France: Let us be back'd with God and with the seas Which He hath given for fence impregnable, And with their helps only defend ourselves;

src: Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms! Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health! Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is! This love feel I, that feel no love in this.
trg: Dost thou not laugh?

src: O Lord, they fight! I will go call the watch.
trg: O, I am slain! If thou be merciful, Open the tomb, lay me with Juliet.

src: for the nobles receive so to heart the banishment of that worthy Coriolanus, that they are in a ripe aptness to take all power from the people and to pluck from them their tribunes for ever.
trg: This lies glowing, I can tell you, and is almost mature for the violent breaking out.

src: Comfort, my liege; remember who you are.
trg: I had forgot myself; am I not king? Awake, thou coward majesty! thou sleepest. Is not the king's name twenty thousand names? Arm, arm, my name! a puny subject strikes At thy great glory.

src: Ah, Warwick, Warwick! wert thou as we are. We might recover all our loss again; The queen from France hath brought a puissant power: Even now we heard the news: ah, could'st thou fly!
trg: Why, then I would not fly. Ah, Montague, If thou be there, sweet brother, take my hand. And with thy lips keep in my soul awhile! Thou lovest me not;

src: You keep a constant temper.
trg: Now, sir, is your name Menenius?

src: stalls, bulks, windows, Are smother'd up, leads fill'd, and ridges horsed With variable complexions, all agreeing In earnestness to see him:
trg: seld-shown flamens Do press among the popular throngs and puff To win a vulgar station:

src: These eyes, that now are dimm'd with death's black veil, Have been as piercing as the mid-day sun, To search the secret treasons of the world:
trg: The wrinkles in my brows, now filled with blood, Were liken'd oft to kingly sepulchres; For who lived king, but I could dig his grave? And who durst mine when Warwick bent his brow?

src: but there to end Where he was to begin and give away The benefit of our levies, answering us With our own charge, making a treaty where There was a yielding,--this admits no excuse.
trg: He approaches: you shall hear him.

src: I do confess it, and repent it, father.
trg: 'Tis meet so, daughter:

src: and that's my pith of business 'Twixt you and your poor brother.
trg: Doth he so seek his life?

src: and thou dost, And that beyond commission, and I find it, And that to the infection of my brains And hardening of my brows.
trg: What means Sicilia?

src: If the law would allow it, sir.
trg: But the law will not allow it, Pompey; nor it shall not be allowed in Vienna.

src: Shall I be charged no further than this present? Must all determine here?
trg: I do demand, If you submit you to the people's voices, Allow their officers and are content To suffer lawful censure for such faults As shall be proved upon you?

src: ' Yet camest thou to a morsel of this feast, Having fully dined before.
trg: O general, Here is the steed, we the caparison: Hadst thou beheld--

src: Tush, I will stir about, And all things shall be well, I warrant thee, wife: Go thou to Juliet, help to deck up her; I'll not to bed to-night; let me alone; I'll play the housewife for this once.
trg: What, ho! They are all forth. Well, I will walk myself To County Paris, to prepare him up Against to-morrow: my heart is wondrous light, Since this same wayward girl is so reclaim'd.

src: Go, then; for 'tis in vain To seek him here that means not to be found.
trg: He jests at scars that never felt a wound. But, soft! what light through yonder window breaks? It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.

src: Madam, I am not well.
trg: Evermore weeping for your cousin's death? What, wilt thou wash him from his grave with tears? An if thou couldst, thou couldst not make him live; Therefore, have done: some grief shows much of love;

src: when you shall know your mistress Has deserved prison, then abound in tears As I come out: this action I now go on Is for my better grace. Adieu, my lord: I never wish'd to see you sorry;
trg: now I trust I shall. My women, come; you have leave.

src: Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edward's grave, And plant your joys in living Edward's throne.
trg: Madam, have comfort: all of us have cause To wail the dimming of our shining star; But none can cure their harms by wailing them. Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy; I did not see your grace:

src: That fellow is a fellow of much licence: let him be called before us. Away with her to prison! Go to; no more words. Provost, my brother Angelo will not be altered; Claudio must die to-morrow:
trg: let him be furnished with divines, and have all charitable preparation. if my brother wrought by my pity, it should not be so with him.

src: Be eloquent in my behalf to her.
trg: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.

src: O single-soled jest, solely singular for the singleness.
trg: Come between us, good Benvolio; my wits faint.

src: If that I could for weeping, you should hear,-- Nay, and you shall hear some. Will you be gone?
Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.
trg: Yet you are wither'd.

src: Ay, but why?
trg: To satisfy your highness and the entreaties Of our most gracious mistress.

src: Call him my king by whose injurious doom My elder brother, the Lord Aubrey Vere, Was done to death?
trg: and more than so, my father, Even in the downfall of his mellow'd years, When nature brought him to the door of death? No, Warwick, no;

src: O, she knew well Thy love did read by rote and could not spell. But come, young waverer, come, go with me, In one respect I'll thy assistant be;
trg: For this alliance may so happy prove, To turn your households' rancour to pure love.

src: Why brother Rivers, are you yet to learn What late misfortune is befall'n King Edward?
trg: What! loss of some pitch'd battle against Warwick?

src: Sicilia cannot show himself over-kind to Bohemia. They were trained together in their childhoods; and there rooted betwixt them then such an affection, which cannot choose but branch now.
trg: that they have seemed to be together, though absent, shook hands, as over a vast, and embraced, as it were, from the ends of opposed winds. The heavens continue their loves!

src: It is his highness' pleasure that the queen Appear in person here in court. Silence!
trg: Read the indictment.

src: Pray you, go to him.
trg: What should I do?

src: Had she such power, She had just cause.
trg: She had; and would incense me To murder her I married.

src: Little have you to say When you depart from him, but, soft and low, 'Remember now my brother.'
trg: Fear me not.

src: If it be honest you have spoke, you have courage to maintain it: I am bound to call upon you; and, I pray you, your name?
trg: Sir, my name is Lucio; well known to the duke.

src: I'll bring mine action on the proudest he That stops my way in Padua. Grumio, Draw forth thy weapon, we are beset with thieves; Rescue thy mistress, if thou be a man.
trg: Fear not, sweet wench, they shall not touch thee, Kate: I'll buckler thee against a million.

src: Make dust our paper and with rainy eyes Write sorrow on the bosom of the earth, Let's choose executors and talk of wills:
trg: And yet not so, for what can we bequeath Save our deposed bodies to the ground?

src: For them! I cannot do it to the gods; Must I then do't to them?
trg: You are too absolute; Though therein you can never be too noble, But when extremities speak. I have heard you say, Honour and policy, like unsever'd friends, I' the war do grow together:

src: A goodly city is this Antium. City, 'Tis I that made thy widows: many an heir Of these fair edifices 'fore my wars Have I heard groan and drop:
trg: then know me not, Lest that thy wives with spits and boys with stones In puny battle slay me. Save you, sir.

src: Is there no pity sitting in the clouds, That sees into the bottom of my grief? O, sweet my mother, cast me not away! Delay this marriage for a month, a week;
trg: Or, if you do not, make the bridal bed In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.

src: Whereto, when they shall know what men are rich, They shall subscribe them for large sums of gold And send them after to supply our wants; For we will make for Ireland presently. Bushy, what news?
trg: Old John of Gaunt is grievous sick, my lord, Suddenly taken; and hath sent post haste To entreat your majesty to visit him.

src: We have: whereupon the Earl of Worcester Hath broke his staff, resign'd his stewardship, And all the household servants fled with him To Bolingbroke.
trg: So, Green, thou art the midwife to my woe, And Bolingbroke my sorrow's dismal heir:

src: I do not like this news.
trg: Nor I.

src: No; he doth but mistake the truth totally.
trg: But the rarity of it is,--which is indeed almost beyond credit,--

src: Shake it off. Come on; We'll visit Caliban my slave, who never Yields us kind answer.
trg: 'Tis a villain, sir, I do not love to look on.

src: Now, knock when I bid you, sirrah villain!
trg: How now! what's the matter? My old friend Grumio! and my good friend Petruchio! How do you all at Verona?

src: How now, my as fair as noble ladies,--and the moon, were she earthly, no nobler,--whither do you follow your eyes so fast?
trg: Honourable Menenius, my boy Marcius approaches; for the love of Juno, let's go.

src: If you would not so, You pity not the state, nor the remembrance Of his most sovereign name;
trg: consider little What dangers, by his highness' fail of issue, May drop upon his kingdom and devour Incertain lookers on. What were more holy Than to rejoice the former queen is well?

src: and for a hand, and a foot, and a body, though they be not to be talked on, yet they are past compare: he is not the flower of courtesy, but, I'll warrant him, as gentle as a lamb.
trg: Go thy ways, wench; serve God. What, have you dined at home?

src: O, good madam, there can be none yet.
trg: Verily, I do not jest with you; there came news from him last night.

src: to report otherwise, were a malice, that, giving itself the lie, would pluck reproof and rebuke from every ear that heard it.
trg: No more of him; he is a worthy man: make way, they are coming.

src: Look how thy servants do attend on thee, Each in his office ready at thy beck. Wilt thou have music? hark! Apollo plays, And twenty caged nightingales do sing: Or wilt thou sleep?
trg: we'll have thee to a couch Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed On purpose trimm'd up for Semiramis. Say thou wilt walk; we will bestrew the ground: Or wilt thou ride?

src: You, my lords, Look on her, mark her well; be but about To say 'she is a goodly lady,' and The justice of your bearts will thereto add 'Tis pity she's not honest, honourable:
trg: these shrugs, these hums and ha's, When you have said 'she's goodly,' come between Ere you can say 'she's honest:

src: Merely, my lord.
trg: Your suit's unprofitable; stand up, I say. I have bethought me of another fault. Provost, how came it Claudio was beheaded At an unusual hour?

src: The roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade To paly ashes, thy eyes' windows fall, Like death, when he shuts up the day of life;
trg: Each part, deprived of supple government, Shall, stiff and stark and cold, appear like death:

src: Oh for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!
trg: Oh for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!

src: Ay, and burn too.
trg: Come, come, you have been too rough, something too rough; You must return and mend it.

src: Welcome, my lord: what, will our mother come?
trg: On what occasion, God he knows, not I, The queen your mother, and your brother York, Have taken sanctuary:

src: First he was A noble servant to them; but he could not Carry his honours even: whether 'twas pride, Which out of daily fortune ever taints The happy man;
trg: whether defect of judgment, To fail in the disposing of those chances Which he was lord of;

src: they my seize On the white wonder of dear Juliet's hand And steal immortal blessing from her lips, Who even in pure and vestal modesty, Still blush, as thinking their own kisses sin;
trg: But Romeo may not; he is banished: Flies may do this, but I from this must fly: They are free men, but I am banished. And say'st thou yet that exile is not death?

src: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.
trg: Then patiently hear my impatience.

src: I am their fathers mother; I will see them.
trg: Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother: Then bring me to their sights; I'll bear thy blame And take thy office from thee, on my peril.

src: How now! what's the matter? My old friend Grumio! and my good friend Petruchio! How do you all at Verona?
trg: Signior Hortensio, come you to part the fray? 'Con tutto il cuore, ben trovato,' may I say.

src: He's the devil.
trg: Bolder, though not so subtle. My valour's poison'd With only suffering stain by him; for him Shall fly out of itself:

src: Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day! Most miserable hour that e'er time saw In lasting labour of his pilgrimage!
trg: But one, poor one, one poor and loving child, But one thing to rejoice and solace in, And cruel death hath catch'd it from my sight!

src: Thou art perfect then, our ship hath touch'd upon The deserts of Bohemia?
trg: Ay, my lord: and fear We have landed in ill time: the skies look grimly And threaten present blusters. In my conscience, The heavens with that we have in hand are angry And frown upon 's.

src: No, I warrant you; I will not adventure my discretion so weakly. Will you laugh me asleep, for I am very heavy?
trg: Go sleep, and hear us.

src: So much the more our carver's excellence; Which lets go by some sixteen years and makes her As she lived now.
trg: As now she might have done, So much to my good comfort, as it is Now piercing to my soul. O, thus she stood, Even with such life of majesty, warm life, As now it coldly stands, when first I woo'd her!

src: That's not my fear; my meed hath got me fame: I have not stopp'd mine ears to their demands, Nor posted off their suits with slow delays;
trg: My pity hath been balm to heal their wounds, My mildness hath allay'd their swelling griefs, My mercy dried their water-flowing tears;

src: Though Richard my life's counsel would not hear, My death's sad tale may yet undeaf his ear.
trg: No; it is stopp'd with other flattering sounds, As praises, of whose taste the wise are fond, Lascivious metres, to whose venom sound The open ear of youth doth always listen;

src: I confess the cape.
Grumio, my horse.
trg: Ay, sir, they be ready: the oats have eaten the horses.

src: Nor did you think it folly To keep your great pretences veil'd till when They needs must show themselves; which in the hatching, It seem'd, appear'd to Rome. By the discovery.
trg: We shall be shorten'd in our aim, which was To take in many towns ere almost Rome Should know we were afoot.

src: Ah, thou, the model where old Troy did stand, Thou map of honour, thou King Richard's tomb, And not King Richard;
trg: thou most beauteous inn, Why should hard-favour'd grief be lodged in thee, When triumph is become an alehouse guest?

src: O, but, sir, Your resolution cannot hold, when 'tis Opposed, as it must be, by the power of the king:
trg: One of these two must be necessities, Which then will speak, that you must change this purpose, Or I my life.
Who is't that calls? is it my lady mother? Is she not down so late, or up so early? What unaccustom'd cause procures her hither?

src: Pardon, my lord; I will not show my face Until my husband bid me.
trg: What, are you married?

src: Yes; keep you warm.
trg: Marry, so I mean, sweet Katharina, in thy bed: And therefore, setting all this chat aside, Thus in plain terms: your father hath consented That you shall be my wife; your dowry 'greed on;

src: Where's that?
trg: I' the city of kites and crows.

src: I am too sure of it: and it is for getting Madam Julietta with child.
trg: Believe me, this may be: he promised to meet me two hours since, and he was ever precise in promise-keeping.

src: say thou but 'I,' And that bare vowel 'I' shall poison more Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice: I am not I, if there be such an I; Or those eyes shut, that make thee answer 'I.
trg: ' If he be slain, say 'I'; or if not, no: Brief sounds determine of my weal or woe.

src: Well-minded Clarence, be thou fortunate!
trg: Comfort, my lord; and so I take my leave.

src: I will follow you.
trg: Farewell, ancient lady; farewell, 'lady, lady, lady.'

src: On pain of death, no person be so bold Or daring-hardy as to touch the lists, Except the marshal and such officers Appointed to direct these fair designs.
trg: Lord marshal, let me kiss my sovereign's hand, And bow my knee before his majesty: For Mowbray and myself are like two men That vow a long and weary pilgrimage;

src: Eleven hours I spent to write it over, For yesternight by Catesby was it brought me; The precedent was full as long a-doing:
trg: And yet within these five hours lived Lord Hastings, Untainted, unexamined, free, at liberty Here's a good world the while! Why who's so gross, That seeth not this palpable device?

src: Tell him, when that our princely father York Bless'd his three sons with his victorious arm, And charged us from his soul to love each other, He little thought of this divided friendship:
trg: Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.

src: And so say I.
trg: Then be it so; and go we to determine Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow. Madam, and you, my mother, will you go To give your censures in this weighty business?

src: Where is he?
trg: In her chamber, making a sermon of continency to her; And rails, and swears, and rates, that she, poor soul, Knows not which way to stand, to look, to speak, And sits as one new-risen from a dream.

src: Even or odd, of all days in the year, Come Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen. Susan and she--God rest all Christian souls!-- Were of an age: well, Susan is with God; She was too good for me:
trg: but, as I said, On Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen; That shall she, marry; I remember it well. 'Tis since the earthquake now eleven years;

src: and he and I Will watch thy waking, and that very night Shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua. And this shall free thee from this present shame;
trg: If no inconstant toy, nor womanish fear, Abate thy valour in the acting it.

src: Ay, sir; so his mother says, if I may believe her.
Assemble presently the people hither;
trg: And when they bear me say 'It shall be so I' the right and strength o' the commons,' be it either For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them If I say fine, cry 'Fine;' if death, cry 'Death.

src: Wilt thou be gone? it is not yet near day: It was the nightingale, and not the lark, That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear; Nightly she sings on yon pomegranate-tree:
trg: Believe me, love, it was the nightingale.

src: Then patiently hear my impatience.
trg: Madam, I have a touch of your condition, Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.

src: I would your duty were as foolish too: The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca, Hath cost me an hundred crowns since supper-time.
trg: The more fool you, for laying on my duty.

src: Softly and swiftly, sir; for the priest is ready.
trg: I fly, Biondello: but they may chance to need thee at home; therefore leave us.

src: Thou sheer, immaculate and silver fountain, From when this stream through muddy passages Hath held his current and defiled himself!
trg: Thy overflow of good converts to bad, And thy abundant goodness shall excuse This deadly blot in thy digressing son.

src: You must think, if we give you any thing, we hope to gain by you.
trg: Well then, I pray, your price o' the consulship?

src: I'll drown more sailors than the mermaid shall; I'll slay more gazers than the basilisk;
trg: I'll play the orator as well as Nestor, Deceive more slily than Ulysses could, And, like a Sinon, take another Troy.

src: sparrows must not build in his house-eaves, because they are lecherous. The duke yet would have dark deeds darkly answered; he would never bring them to light: would he were returned!
trg: Marry, this Claudio is condemned for untrussing. Farewell, good friar: I prithee, pray for me. The duke, I say to thee again, would eat mutton on Fridays.

src: Well, give me the moiety. Are you a party in this business?
trg: In some sort, sir: but though my case be a pitiful one, I hope I shall not be flayed out of it.

src: Where lies he?
trg: At Ely House.

src: And say, what store of parting tears were shed?
trg: Faith, none for me; except the north-east wind, Which then blew bitterly against our faces, Awaked the sleeping rheum, and so by chance Did grace our hollow parting with a tear.

src: Have I not told thee how I was cozened by the way and lost all my money?
trg: And indeed, sir, there are cozeners abroad; therefore it behoves men to be wary.

src: Me they shall feel while I am able to stand: and 'tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.
trg: 'Tis well thou art not fish; if thou hadst, thou hadst been poor John. Draw thy tool! here comes two of the house of the Montagues.

src: And do you tell me of a woman's tongue, That gives not half so great a blow to hear As will a chestnut in a farmer's fire? Tush, tush! fear boys with bugs.
trg: For he fears none.

src: No, not a whit: I find you passing gentle. 'Twas told me you were rough and coy and sullen, And now I find report a very liar;
trg: For thou are pleasant, gamesome, passing courteous, But slow in speech, yet sweet as spring-time flowers: Why does the world report that Kate doth limp? O slanderous world!

src: It is my soul that calls upon my name: How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night, Like softest music to attending ears!
trg: Romeo!

src: I told her so, my lord, On your displeasure's peril and on mine, She should not visit you.
trg: What, canst not rule her?

src: Then, Pompey, nor now. What news abroad, friar? what news?
trg: Come your ways, sir; come.

src: Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?
trg: Why, no; for she hath broke the lute to me. I did but tell her she mistook her frets, And bow'd her hand to teach her fingering; When, with a most impatient devilish spirit, 'Frets, call you these?

src: My only love sprung from my only hate! Too early seen unknown, and known too late! Prodigious birth of love it is to me, That I must love a loathed enemy.
trg: What's this? what's this?

src: to-morrow 't shall be mended, And, for this night, we'll fast for company: Come, I will bring thee to thy bridal chamber.
trg: Peter, didst ever see the like?

src: Pembroke and Stafford, you in our behalf Go levy men, and make prepare for war; They are already, or quickly will be landed: Myself in person will straight follow you.
trg: But, ere I go, Hastings and Montague, Resolve my doubt. You twain, of all the rest, Are near to Warwick by blood and by alliance: Tell me if you love Warwick more than me?

src: Ah, Tranio, what a cruel father's he! But art thou not advised, he took some care To get her cunning schoolmasters to instruct her?
trg: Ay, marry, am I, sir; and now 'tis plotted.

src: No, to the dignity and height of honour The high imperial type of this earth's glory.
trg: Flatter my sorrows with report of it; Tell me what state, what dignity, what honour, Canst thou demise to any child of mine?

src: The plebeians have got your fellow-tribune And hale him up and down, all swearing, if The Roman ladies bring not comfort home, They'll give him death by inches.
trg: What's the news?

src: A persecutor, I am sure, thou art: If murdering innocents be executing, Why, then thou art an executioner.
trg: Thy son I kill'd for his presumption.

src: Well, peace be with you, sir: here comes my man.
trg: But I'll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery: Marry, go before to field, he'll be your follower; Your worship in that sense may call him 'man.'

src: Where the devil should this Romeo be? Came he not home to-night?
trg: Not to his father's; I spoke with his man.

src: Believe me, love, it was the nightingale.
trg: It was the lark, the herald of the morn, No nightingale: look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east:

src: making parties strong And feebling such as stand not in their liking Below their cobbled shoes. They say there's grain enough!
trg: Would the nobility lay aside their ruth, And let me use my sword, I'll make a quarry With thousands of these quarter'd slaves, as high As I could pick my lance.

src: I shall report, For most it caught me, the celestial habits, Methinks I so should term them, and the reverence Of the grave wearers. O, the sacrifice!
trg: How ceremonious, solemn and unearthly It was i' the offering!

src: I am content.
trg: Are you content to stay?

src: Close by, my master.
trg: But are they, Ariel, safe?

src: Why, what need we Commune with you of this, but rather follow Our forceful instigation? Our prerogative Calls not your counsels, but our natural goodness Imparts this;
trg: which if you, or stupefied Or seeming so in skill, cannot or will not Relish a truth like us, inform yourselves We need no more of your advice:

src: he's in for a commodity of brown paper and old ginger, ninescore and seventeen pounds; of which he made five marks, ready money:
trg: marry, then ginger was not much in request, for the old women were all dead.

src: My master hath appointed me to go to Saint Luke's, to bid the priest be ready to come against you come with your appendix.
trg: I may, and will, if she be so contented: She will be pleased; then wherefore should I doubt? Hap what hap may, I'll roundly go about her: It shall go hard if Cambio go without her.

src: She's dead, deceased, she's dead; alack the day!
trg: Alack the day, she's dead, she's dead, she's dead!

src: Richly in both, if justice had her right.
trg: My heart is great; but it must break with silence, Ere't be disburden'd with a liberal tongue.

src: Warwick, this is some post to us or thee.
He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not; The ape is dead, and I must conjure him.
trg: And if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.

src: I humbly beseech you, sir, to pardon me all the faults I have committed to your worship and to give me your good report to the prince my master.
trg: Prithee, son, do; for we must be gentle, now we are gentlemen.

src: Who brought it?
trg: I.

src: For me, the ransom of my bold attempt Shall be this cold corpse on the earth's cold face; But if I thrive, the gain of my attempt The least of you shall share his part thereof.
trg: Sound drums and trumpets boldly and cheerfully; God and Saint George! Richmond and victory!

src: I do remember an apothecary,-- And hereabouts he dwells,--which late I noted In tatter'd weeds, with overwhelming brows, Culling of simples;
trg: meagre were his looks, Sharp misery had worn him to the bones: And in his needy shop a tortoise hung, An alligator stuff'd, and other skins Of ill-shaped fishes;

src: I was promised them against the feast; but they come not too late now.
trg: He hath promised you more than that, or there be liars.

src: 'Tis grace indeed. Why, lo you now, I have spoke to the purpose twice: The one for ever earn'd a royal husband; The other for some while a friend.
Come forth, I say! there's other business for thee: Come, thou tortoise! when? Fine apparition! My quaint Ariel, Hark in thine ear.
trg: My lord it shall be done.

src: Sir, it is three days since I saw the prince. What his happier affairs may be, are to me unknown:
trg: but I have missingly noted, he is of late much retired from court and is less frequent to his princely exercises than formerly he hath appeared.

src: This dead king to the living king I'll bear Take hence the rest, and give them burial here.
trg: Kind uncle York, the latest news we hear Is that the rebels have consumed with fire Our town of Cicester in Gloucestershire; But whether they be ta'en or slain we hear not.

src: Forspent with toil, as runners with a race, I lay me down a little while to breathe;
trg: For strokes received, and many blows repaid, Have robb'd my strong-knit sinews of their strength, And spite of spite needs must I rest awhile.

src: So two, together weeping, make one woe. Weep thou for me in France, I for thee here; Better far off than near, be ne'er the near. Go, count thy way with sighs; I mine with groans.
trg: So longest way shall have the longest moans.

src: O, You have, I know, petition'd all the gods For my prosperity!
trg: Nay, my good soldier, up; My gentle Marcius, worthy Caius, and By deed-achieving honour newly named,-- What is it?--Coriolanus must I call thee?-- But O, thy wife!
Most sure, the goddess On whom these airs attend! Vouchsafe my prayer May know if you remain upon this island; And that you will some good instruction give How I may bear me here:
Could great men thunder As Jove himself does, Jove would ne'er be quiet, For every pelting, petty officer Would use his heaven for thunder; Nothing but thunder!

src: O, very well; I have perused the note. Hark you, sir: I'll have them very fairly bound: All books of love, see that at any hand; And see you read no other lectures to her: You understand me:
trg: over and beside Signior Baptista's liberality, I'll mend it with a largess. Take your paper too, And let me have them very well perfumed For she is sweeter than perfume itself To whom they go to.

src: Ha!
trg: Stays here longer.

src: Thou didst speak but well When most the truth; which I receive much better Than to be pitied of thee. Prithee, bring me To the dead bodies of my queen and son: One grave shall be for both:
trg: upon them shall The causes of their death appear, unto Our shame perpetual. Once a day I'll visit The chapel where they lie, and tears shed there Shall be my recreation:

src: Most mighty sovereign, You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful: I never was nor never will be false.
trg: Well, Go muster men; but, hear you, leave behind Your son, George Stanley: look your faith be firm. Or else his head's assurance is but frail.

src: And that may be determined at the one which may make you and him to rue at the other.
trg: Therefore he sends to know your lordship's pleasure, If presently you will take horse with him, And with all speed post with him toward the north, To shun the danger that his soul divines.

src: For ever Unvenerable be thy hands, if thou Takest up the princess by that forced baseness Which he has put upon't!
trg: He dreads his wife.

src: What, with my tongue in your tail? nay, come again, Good Kate; I am a gentleman.
trg: That I'll try.

src: Hover about her; say, that right for right Hath dimm'd your infant morn to aged night.
trg: So many miseries have crazed my voice, That my woe-wearied tongue is mute and dumb, Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?

src: which is more Than history can pattern, though devised And play'd to take spectators. For life, I prize it As I weigh grief, which I would spare:
trg: for honour, 'Tis a derivative from me to mine, And only that I stand for. I appeal To your own conscience, sir, before Polixenes Came to your court, how I was in your grace, How merited to be so;

src: Peter!
trg: Anon!

src: Or shut me nightly in a charnel-house, O'er-cover'd quite with dead men's rattling bones, With reeky shanks and yellow chapless skulls;
trg: Or bid me go into a new-made grave And hide me with a dead man in his shroud; Things that, to hear them told, have made me tremble;

src: Enough of this; I pray thee, hold thy peace.
trg: Yes, madam: yet I cannot choose but laugh, To think it should leave crying and say 'Ay.' And yet, I warrant, it had upon its brow A bump as big as a young cockerel's stone; A parlous knock;

src: Pray you, sit down; For now we sit to chat as well as eat.
trg: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!

src: No, but the loss of his own royal person.
trg: Then is my sovereign slain?

src: I hate it, and desire all good men's love. First, madam, I entreat true peace of you, Which I will purchase with my duteous service;
trg: Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham, If ever any grudge were lodged between us; Of you, Lord Rivers, and, Lord Grey, of you; That without desert have frown'd on me; Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen;

src: Indeed, madam?
trg: In earnest, it's true; I heard a senator speak it. Thus it is: the Volsces have an army forth; against whom Cominius the general is gone, with one part of our Roman power:

src: O, good sir, softly, good sir! I fear, sir, my shoulder-blade is out.
trg: How now! canst stand?

src: Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be Ere one can say 'It lightens.' Sweet, good night! This bud of love, by summer's ripening breath, May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.
trg: Good night, good night! as sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast!

src: And I unjustly too, must grant it you But for my brother not a man would speak, Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself For him, poor soul.
trg: The proudest of you all Have been beholding to him in his life; Yet none of you would once plead for his life. O God, I fear thy justice will take hold On me, and you, and mine, and yours for this!

src: Thy father hath.
trg: But 'twas ere I was born. Thou hast one son; for his sake pity me, Lest in revenge thereof, sith God is just, He be as miserably slain as I. Ah, let me live in prison all my days;

src: Madam, I am here. What is your will?
trg: This is the matter:--Nurse, give leave awhile, We must talk in secret:--nurse, come back again; I have remember'd me, thou's hear our counsel. Thou know'st my daughter's of a pretty age.

src: What my tongue dares not, that my heart shall say.
trg: My lord, will't please you to fall to?

src: Away, away! Once more, sweet lords farewell.
trg: Yet let us all together to our troops, And give them leave to fly that will not stay; And call them pillars that will stand to us;

src: O monstrous arrogance! Thou liest, thou thread, thou thimble, Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail! Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter-cricket thou!
trg: Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread? Away, thou rag, thou quantity, thou remnant; Or I shall so be-mete thee with thy yard As thou shalt think on prating whilst thou livest!

src: lay it on me; And therefore frolic: we will hence forthwith, To feast and sport us at thy father's house. Go, call my men, and let us straight to him; And bring our horses unto Long-lane end;
trg: There will we mount, and thither walk on foot Let's see; I think 'tis now some seven o'clock, And well we may come there by dinner-time.

src: I thank you, general; But cannot make my heart consent to take A bribe to pay my sword: I do refuse it; And stand upon my common part with those That have beheld the doing.
trg: May these same instruments, which you profane, Never sound more! when drums and trumpets shall I' the field prove flatterers, let courts and cities be Made all of false-faced soothing!

src: more of your conversation would infect my brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly plebeians: I will be bold to take my leave of you.
trg: How now, my as fair as noble ladies,--and the moon, were she earthly, no nobler,--whither do you follow your eyes so fast?

src: Were never orphans had so dear a loss!
trg: Was never mother had so dear a loss! Alas, I am the mother of these moans! Their woes are parcell'd, mine are general. She for an Edward weeps, and so do I; I for a Clarence weep, so doth not she:

src: That I do beg his life, if it be sin, Heaven let me bear it! you granting of my suit, If that be sin, I'll make it my morn prayer To have it added to the faults of mine, And nothing of your answer.
trg: Nay, but hear me. Your sense pursues not mine: either you are ignorant, Or seem so craftily; and that's not good.

src: Which is the wiser here? Justice or Iniquity? Is this true?
trg: O thou caitiff! O thou varlet! O thou wicked Hannibal! I respected with her before I was married to her!

src: Here's much to do with hate, but more with love. Why, then, O brawling love! O loving hate! O any thing, of nothing first create! O heavy lightness! serious vanity!
trg: Mis-shapen chaos of well-seeming forms! Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire, sick health! Still-waking sleep, that is not what it is! This love feel I, that feel no love in this.

src: the leisure and the fearful time Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love And ample interchange of sweet discourse, Which so long sunder'd friends should dwell upon:
trg: God give us leisure for these rites of love! Once more, adieu: be valiant, and speed well!

src: but I have missingly noted, he is of late much retired from court and is less frequent to his princely exercises than formerly he hath appeared.
trg: I have considered so much, Camillo, and with some care; so far that I have eyes under my service which look upon his removedness;
Why speaks my father so ungently? This Is the third man that e'er I saw, the first That e'er I sigh'd for: pity move my father To be inclined my way!

src: Abhorred slave, Which any print of goodness wilt not take, Being capable of all ill! I pitied thee, Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour One thing or other:
trg: when thou didst not, savage, Know thine own meaning, but wouldst gabble like A thing most brutish, I endow'd thy purposes With words that made them known.

src: How blest am I In my just censure, in my true opinion! Alack, for lesser knowledge! how accursed In being so blest!
trg: There may be in the cup A spider steep'd, and one may drink, depart, And yet partake no venom, for his knowledge Is not infected:

src: O, the better, sir; for he that drinks all night, and is hanged betimes in the morning, may sleep the sounder all the next day.
trg: Look you, sir; here comes your ghostly father: do we jest now, think you?

src: being something gently considered, I'll bring you where he is aboard, tender your persons to his presence, whisper him in your behalfs;
trg: and if it be in man besides the king to effect your suits, here is man shall do it.

src: What say'st thou, Henry, wilt thou yield the crown?
trg: Why, how now, long-tongued Warwick! dare you speak? When you and I met at Saint Alban's last, Your legs did better service than your hands.

src: --but this new governor Awakes me all the enrolled penalties Which have, like unscour'd armour, hung by the wall So long that nineteen zodiacs have gone round And none of them been worn;
trg: and, for a name, Now puts the drowsy and neglected act Freshly on me: 'tis surely for a name.

src: We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good. What authority surfeits on would relieve us:
trg: if they would yield us but the superfluity, while it were wholesome, we might guess they relieved us humanely; but they think we are too dear:

src: with thought of such affections, Step forth mine advocate; at your request My father will grant precious things as trifles.
trg: Would he do so, I'ld beg your precious mistress, Which he counts but a trifle.

src: We see the very wreck that we must suffer; And unavoided is the danger now, For suffering so the causes of our wreck.
trg: Not so; even through the hollow eyes of death I spy life peering; but I dare not say How near the tidings of our comfort is.

src: Yes, my good lord, It doth contain a king; King Richard lies Within the limits of yon lime and stone:
trg: And with him are the Lord Aumerle, Lord Salisbury, Sir Stephen Scroop, besides a clergyman Of holy reverence; who, I cannot learn.

src: a thousand-fold it doth. And to conclude, the shepherd's homely curds, His cold thin drink out of his leather bottle.
trg: Ill blows the wind that profits nobody. This man, whom hand to hand I slew in fight, May be possessed with some store of crowns;

src: Have patience, madam: there's no doubt his majesty Will soon recover his accustom'd health.
trg: In that you brook it in, it makes him worse: Therefore, for God's sake, entertain good comfort, And cheer his grace with quick and merry words.

src: Romeo slew him, he slew Mercutio; Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?
trg: Not Romeo, prince, he was Mercutio's friend; His fault concludes but what the law should end, The life of Tybalt.

src: My lord, he doth deny to come.
trg: Off with his son George's head!
Widow, we will consider of your suit; And come some other time to know our mind.

src: O, God defend my soul from such deep sin! Shall I seem crest-fall'n in my father's sight? Or with pale beggar-fear impeach my height Before this out-dared dastard?
trg: We were not born to sue, but to command; Which since we cannot do to make you friends, Be ready, as your lives shall answer it, At Coventry, upon Saint Lambert's day:

src: I am appointed him to murder you.
trg: By whom, Camillo?

src: Yes, as I love the woman that wrong'd him.
trg: So then it seems your most offenceful act Was mutually committed?

src: You may not pass, you must return: our general Will no more hear from thence.
trg: You'll see your Rome embraced with fire before You'll speak with Coriolanus.

src: --but, as I said, When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool, To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug! Shake quoth the dove-house:
trg: 'twas no need, I trow, To bid me trudge: And since that time it is eleven years; For then she could stand alone; nay, by the rood, She could have run and waddled all about;

src: He, more incensed against your majesty Than all the rest, discharged me with these words: 'Tell him from me that he hath done me wrong, And therefore I'll uncrown him ere't be long.'
trg: Ha! durst the traitor breathe out so proud words? Well I will arm me, being thus forewarn'd: They shall have wars and pay for their presumption. But say, is Warwick friends with Margaret?

src: And hath he too Exposed this paragon to the fearful usage, At least ungentle, of the dreadful Neptune, To greet a man not worth her pains, much less The adventure of her person?
trg: Good my lord, She came from Libya.

src: I had rather you did lack than I, my lord, Upon this ground; and more it would content me To have her honour true than your suspicion, Be blamed for't how you might.
trg: Why, what need we Commune with you of this, but rather follow Our forceful instigation? Our prerogative Calls not your counsels, but our natural goodness Imparts this;

src: O Tullus,--
trg: Thou hast done a deed whereat valour will weep.

src: Good heart, and, i' faith, I will tell her as much: Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.
trg: What wilt thou tell her, nurse? thou dost not mark me.

src: And so did I; and, to say the truth, so did very many of us: that we did, we did for the best; and though we willingly consented to his banishment, yet it was against our will.
trg: Ye re goodly things, you voices!
The keeper of the prison, call to him; let him have knowledge who I am. Good lady, No court in Europe is too good for thee; What dost thou then in prison? Now, good sir, You know me, do you not?

src: The offences we have made you do we'll answer, If you first sinn'd with us and that with us You did continue fault and that you slipp'd not With any but with us.
trg: Is he won yet?

src: 'Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so.
trg: Boatswain!

src: Sorry I am my noble cousin should Suspect me, that I mean no good to him: By heaven, I come in perfect love to him; And so once more return and tell his grace.
trg: When holy and devout religious men Are at their beads, 'tis hard to draw them thence, So sweet is zealous contemplation.

src: Go thou away: I'll follow instantly.
trg: I am glad at heart To be so rid o' the business.

src: This way the king will come; this is the way To Julius Caesar's ill-erected tower, To whose flint bosom my condemned lord Is doom'd a prisoner by proud Bolingbroke:
trg: Here let us rest, if this rebellious earth Have any resting for her true king's queen. But soft, but see, or rather do not see, My fair rose wither:

src: Mopsa must be your mistress: marry, garlic, To mend her kissing with!
trg: Now, in good time!

src: But heaven hath a hand in these events, To whose high will we bound our calm contents. To Bolingbroke are we sworn subjects now, Whose state and honour I for aye allow.
trg: Here comes my son Aumerle.

src: Come, come, we fear the worst; all shall be well.
trg: When clouds appear, wise men put on their cloaks; When great leaves fall, the winter is at hand; When the sun sets, who doth not look for night? Untimely storms make men expect a dearth.

src: Thou shalt not do't.
trg: O, were it but my life, I'ld throw it down for your deliverance As frankly as a pin.

src: Will you pluck your sword out of his pitcher by the ears? make haste, lest mine be about your ears ere it be out.
trg: I am for you.

src: When, I beseech you? that in his reprieve, Longer or shorter, he may be so fitted That his soul sicken not.
trg: Ha! fie, these filthy vices! It were as good To pardon him that hath from nature stolen A man already made, as to remit Their saucy sweetness that do coin heaven's image In stamps that are forbid:

src: Now tell me, madam, do you love your children?
trg: Ay, full as dearly as I love myself.

src: Wash they his wounds with tears: mine shall be spent, When theirs are dry, for Romeo's banishment. Take up those cords: poor ropes, you are beguiled, Both you and I; for Romeo is exiled:
trg: He made you for a highway to my bed; But I, a maid, die maiden-widowed. Come, cords, come, nurse; I'll to my wedding-bed; And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead!

src: Alack, poor Richard! where rode he the whilst?
trg: As in a theatre, the eyes of men, After a well-graced actor leaves the stage, Are idly bent on him that enters next, Thinking his prattle to be tedious;

src: but what mystery there should be in hanging, if I should be hanged, I cannot imagine.
trg: Sir, it is a mystery.

src: You may say it, but not swear it.
trg: Not swear it, now I am a gentleman? Let boors and franklins say it, I'll swear it.

src: I am thine.
trg: For shame, come down: he made thee Duke of York.

src: If I were not in love with Mopsa, thou shouldst take no money of me; but being enthralled as I am, it will also be the bondage of certain ribbons and gloves.
trg: I was promised them against the feast; but they come not too late now.

src: Why Doth it not then our eyelids sink? I find not Myself disposed to sleep.
trg: Nor I; my spirits are nimble. They fell together all, as by consent; They dropp'd, as by a thunder-stroke. What might, Worthy Sebastian? O, what might?--No more:

src: This is all: Do't and thou hast the one half of my heart; Do't not, thou split'st thine own.
trg: I'll do't, my lord.

src: Well, thou hast comforted me marvellous much. Go in: and tell my lady I am gone, Having displeased my father, to Laurence' cell, To make confession and to be absolved.
trg: Marry, I will; and this is wisely done.

src: Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbours, Will you undo yourselves?
trg: We cannot, sir, we are undone already.

src: were my wife's liver Infected as her life, she would not live The running of one glass.
trg: Who does infect her?

src: For at their hands I have deserved no pity. The air hath got into my deadly wounds, And much effuse of blood doth make me faint. Come, York and Richard, Warwick and the rest;
trg: I stabb'd your fathers' bosoms, split my breast.

src: Warwick and Clarence give me both your hands: Now join your hands, and with your hands your hearts, That no dissension hinder government:
trg: I make you both protectors of this land, While I myself will lead a private life And in devotion spend my latter days, To sin's rebuke and my Creator's praise.

src: For mine own part, When I said, banish him, I said 'twas pity.
trg: And so did I.

src: For so your father charged me at our parting, 'Be serviceable to my son,' quoth he, Although I think 'twas in another sense; I am content to be Lucentio, Because so well I love Lucentio.
trg: Tranio, be so, because Lucentio loves: And let me be a slave, to achieve that maid Whose sudden sight hath thrall'd my wounded eye. Here comes the rogue. Sirrah, where have you been?

src: Let them go on; This mutiny were better put in hazard, Than stay, past doubt, for greater: If, as his nature is, he fall in rage With their refusal, both observe and answer The vantage of his anger.
trg: To the Capitol, come: We will be there before the stream o' the people; And this shall seem, as partly 'tis, their own, Which we have goaded onward.

src: else imputation, For that he knew you, might reproach your life And choke your good to come;
trg: for his possessions, Although by confiscation they are ours, We do instate and widow you withal, To buy you a better husband.

src: I the great toe! why the great toe?
trg: For that, being one o' the lowest, basest, poorest, Of this most wise rebellion, thou go'st foremost: Thou rascal, that art worst in blood to run, Lead'st first to win some vantage.

src: Why, had your bodies No heart among you? or had you tongues to cry Against the rectorship of judgment?
trg: Have you Ere now denied the asker? and now again Of him that did not ask, but mock, bestow Your sued-for tongues?

src: But, madam, where is Warwick then become?
trg: I am inform'd that he comes towards London, To set the crown once more on Henry's head: Guess thou the rest; There shall I rest secure from force and fraud.

src: Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.
trg: None that I more love than myself. You are a counsellor; if you can command these elements to silence, and work the peace of the present, we will not hand a rope more; use your authority:

src: His is the right, and therefore pardon me.
trg: Why whisper you, my lords, and answer not?

src: for whose old love I have, Though I show'd sourly to him, once more offer'd The first conditions, which they did refuse And cannot now accept;
trg: to grace him only That thought he could do more, a very little I have yielded to: fresh embassies and suits, Nor from the state nor private friends, hereafter Will I lend ear to. Ha!

src: The price is to ask it kindly.
trg: Kindly! Sir, I pray, let me ha't: I have wounds to show you, which shall be yours in private. Your good voice, sir; what say you?

src: Each substance of a grief hath twenty shadows, Which shows like grief itself, but is not so; For sorrow's eye, glazed with blinding tears, Divides one thing entire to many objects;
trg: Like perspectives, which rightly gazed upon Show nothing but confusion, eyed awry Distinguish form:

src: Alack, poor soul! thou hast need of more rags to lay on thee, rather than have these off.
trg: O sir, the loathsomeness of them offends me more than the stripes I have received, which are mighty ones and millions.

src: Let me be ignorant, and in nothing good, But graciously to know I am no better.
trg: Thus wisdom wishes to appear most bright When it doth tax itself; as these black masks Proclaim an enshield beauty ten times louder Than beauty could, display'd. But mark me;

src: I'll not be tied to hours nor 'pointed times, But learn my lessons as I please myself. And, to cut off all strife, here sit we down: Take you your instrument, play you the whiles;
trg: His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.

src: How fares the prince?
trg: Well, madam, and in health.

src: But if so be Thou darest not this and that to prove more fortunes Thou'rt tired, then, in a word, I also am Longer to live most weary, and present My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice;
trg: O Marcius, Marcius! Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart A root of ancient envy.

src: Offended us you have not, but the king.
trg: I shall be reconciled to him again.

src: When holy and devout religious men Are at their beads, 'tis hard to draw them thence, So sweet is zealous contemplation.
trg: See, where he stands between two clergymen!

src: we'll fit him to our turn,-- And he shall be Vincentio of Pisa; And make assurance here in Padua Of greater sums than I have promised.
trg: So shall you quietly enjoy your hope, And marry sweet Bianca with consent.

src: Then have you lost a sight, which was to be seen, cannot be spoken of.
trg: There might you have beheld one joy crown another, so and in such manner that it seemed sorrow wept to take leave of them, for their joy waded in tears.

src: Forward, I pray, since we have come so far, And be it moon, or sun, or what you please: An if you please to call it a rush-candle, Henceforth I vow it shall be so for me.
trg: I say it is the moon.

src: I swear I will not die to-day for any man's persuasion.
trg: But hear you.

src: and then I loved thee And show'd thee all the qualities o' the isle, The fresh springs, brine-pits, barren place and fertile: Cursed be I that did so!
trg: All the charms Of Sycorax, toads, beetles, bats, light on you! For I am all the subjects that you have, Which first was mine own king:

src: For a worthy lady And one whom much I honour.
trg: Pray you then, Conduct me to the queen.

src: Hark ye; The queen your mother rounds apace: we shall Present our services to a fine new prince One of these days; and then you'ld wanton with us, If we would have you.
trg: She is spread of late Into a goodly bulk: good time encounter her!

src: Our holy lives must win a new world's crown, Which our profane hours here have stricken down.
trg: What, is my Richard both in shape and mind Transform'd and weaken'd? hath Bolingbroke deposed Thine intellect? hath he been in thy heart?

src: Now, sir, how do you find the prisoner?
trg: A creature unprepared, unmeet for death; And to transport him in the mind he is Were damnable.

src: My Lord Fitzwater, I do remember well The very time Aumerle and you did talk.
trg: 'Tis very true: you were in presence then; And you can witness with me this is true.

src: Even as a flattering dream or worthless fancy. Then take him up and manage well the jest: Carry him gently to my fairest chamber And hang it round with all my wanton pictures:
trg: Balm his foul head in warm distilled waters And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet: Procure me music ready when he wakes, To make a dulcet and a heavenly sound;

src: I think you have As little skill to fear as I have purpose To put you to't. But come; our dance, I pray: Your hand, my Perdita: so turtles pair, That never mean to part.
trg: I'll swear for 'em.

src: Will you swear Never to marry but by my free leave?
trg: Never, Paulina; so be blest my spirit!

src: So, I am satisfied. Give me a bowl of wine: I have not that alacrity of spirit, Nor cheer of mind, that I was wont to have. Set it down. Is ink and paper ready?
trg: It is, my lord.

src: Peace, Grumio! it is the rival of my love. Petruchio, stand by a while.
trg: A proper stripling and an amorous!

src: I got them in my country's service, when Some certain of your brethren roar'd and ran From the noise of our own drums.'
trg: O me, the gods! You must not speak of that: you must desire them To think upon you.

src: It may be so; but yet my inward soul Persuades me it is otherwise: howe'er it be, I cannot but be sad;
trg: so heavy sad As, though on thinking on no thought I think, Makes me with heavy nothing faint and shrink.

src: None, but such remedy as, to save a head, To cleave a heart in twain.
trg: But is there any?

src: Now, Clifford, I have singled thee alone: Suppose this arm is for the Duke of York, And this for Rutland; both bound to revenge, Wert thou environ'd with a brazen wall.
trg: Now, Richard, I am with thee here alone: This is the hand that stabb'd thy father York; And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland;

src: Ye are a baggage: the Slys are no rogues; look in the chronicles; we came in with Richard Conqueror. Therefore paucas pallabris; let the world slide: sessa!
trg: You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?

src: Ay, a thousand times. Peter!
trg: Anon!

src: Nay, but my letters, by this means being there So soon as you arrive, shall clear that doubt.
trg: And those that you'll procure from King Leontes--

src: Awake, dear heart, awake! thou hast slept well; Awake!
trg: The strangeness of your story put Heaviness in me.

src: But in your bride you bury brotherhood.
trg: Or else you would not have bestow'd the heir Of the Lord Bonville on your new wife's son, And leave your brothers to go speed elsewhere.

src: For testimony whereof, one in the prison, That should by private order else have died, I have reserved alive.
trg: What's he?

src: On your allegiance, Out of the chamber with her! Were I a tyrant, Where were her life? she durst not call me so, If she did know me one. Away with her!
trg: I pray you, do not push me; I'll be gone. Look to your babe, my lord; 'tis yours: Jove send her A better guiding spirit! What needs these hands?

src: a lady's 'Verily' 's As potent as a lord's. Will you go yet? Force me to keep you as a prisoner, Not like a guest; so you shall pay your fees When you depart, and save your thanks. How say you?
trg: My prisoner? or my guest? by your dread 'Verily,' One of them you shall be.

src: For what, lieutenant? for well using me? Nay, be thou sure I'll well requite thy kindness, For that it made my imprisonment a pleasure;
trg: Ay, such a pleasure as incaged birds Conceive when after many moody thoughts At last by notes of household harmony They quite forget their loss of liberty.

src: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover, To entertain these fair well-spoken days, I am determined to prove a villain And hate the idle pleasures of these days.
trg: Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous, By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams, To set my brother Clarence and the king In deadly hate the one against the other: Dive, thoughts, down to my soul:

src: Thou art no Atlas for so great a weight: And weakling, Warwick takes his gift again; And Henry is my king, Warwick his subject.
trg: But Warwick's king is Edward's prisoner: And, gallant Warwick, do but answer this: What is the body when the head is off?

src: Right, I mean you.
trg: And I am mean indeed, respecting you.

src: for he this very day receives letters of strange tenor; perchance of the duke's death; perchance entering into some monastery; but, by chance, nothing of what is writ.
trg: Look, the unfolding star calls up the shepherd. Put not yourself into amazement how these things should be: all difficulties are but easy when they are known.

src: And in this resolution here we leave you.-- Come, citizens: 'zounds! I'll entreat no more.
trg: O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham.

src: It cannot be; for when I parted with him, He hugg'd me in his arms, and swore, with sobs, That he would labour my delivery.
trg: Why, so he doth, now he delivers thee From this world's thraldom to the joys of heaven.

src: Then bid me kill myself, and I will do it.
trg: I have already.

src: At any time 'fore noon.
trg: 'Save your honour!

src: Why stops my lord, shall I not hear my task?
trg: An easy task; 'tis but to love a king.

src: But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence, That they who brought me in my master's hate I live to look upon their tragedy. I tell thee, Catesby--
trg: What, my lord?

src: Yet I wish, sir,-- I mean for your particular,--you had not Join'd in commission with him; but either Had borne the action of yourself, or else To him had left it solely.
trg: I understand thee well; and be thou sure, when he shall come to his account, he knows not What I can urge against him.

src: 'Tybalt is dead, and Romeo--banished;' That 'banished,' that one word 'banished,' Hath slain ten thousand Tybalts. Tybalt's death Was woe enough, if it had ended there:
trg: But with a rear-ward following Tybalt's death, 'Romeo is banished,' to speak that word, Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet, All slain, all dead. 'Romeo is banished!

src: O, full of danger is the Duke of Gloucester! And the queen's sons and brothers haught and proud: And were they to be ruled, and not to rule, This sickly land might solace as before.
trg: Come, come, we fear the worst; all shall be well.

src: O lamentable day!
trg: O woful time!

src: Who is't that goes with me? Beseech your highness, My women may be with me; for you see My plight requires it. Do not weep, good fools; There is no cause:
trg: when you shall know your mistress Has deserved prison, then abound in tears As I come out: this action I now go on Is for my better grace. Adieu, my lord: I never wish'd to see you sorry;

src: Wert thou not banished on pain of death?
trg: I was; but I do find more pain in banishment Than death can yield me here by my abode. A husband and a son thou owest to me; And thou a kingdom; all of you allegiance:

src: That high All-Seer that I dallied with Hath turn'd my feigned prayer on my head And given in earnest what I begg'd in jest.
trg: Thus doth he force the swords of wicked men To turn their own points on their masters' bosoms: Now Margaret's curse is fallen upon my head;

src: Where is the Duke of Norfolk, gentle Warwick? And when came George from Burgundy to England?
trg: Some six miles off the duke is with the soldiers; And for your brother, he was lately sent From your kind aunt, Duchess of Burgundy, With aid of soldiers to this needful war.

src: I am afraid, sir, Do what you can, yours will not be entreated. Now, where's my wife?
trg: She says you have some goodly jest in hand: She will not come: she bids you come to her.

src: To whom in all this presence speaks your grace?
trg: To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace. When have I injured thee? when done thee wrong? Or thee? or thee? or any of your faction? A plague upon you all!

src: Well get you gone: o' Thursday be it, then. Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed, Prepare her, wife, against this wedding-day. Farewell, my lord. Light to my chamber, ho! Afore me!
trg: it is so very very late, That we may call it early by and by. Good night.

src: For thy complexion shifts to strange effects, After the moon. If thou art rich, thou'rt poor;
trg: For, like an ass whose back with ingots bows, Thou bear's thy heavy riches but a journey, And death unloads thee. Friend hast thou none;

src: Curster than she? why, 'tis impossible.
trg: Why he's a devil, a devil, a very fiend.

src: Tranio, at once Uncase thee; take my colour'd hat and cloak: When Biondello comes, he waits on thee; But I will charm him first to keep his tongue.
trg: So had you need. In brief, sir, sith it your pleasure is, And I am tied to be obedient;

src: Content thee, gentle coz, let him alone; He bears him like a portly gentleman; And, to say truth, Verona brags of him To be a virtuous and well-govern'd youth:
trg: I would not for the wealth of all the town Here in my house do him disparagement: Therefore be patient, take no note of him:
Heaven keep your honour safe!

src: And, in good time, here comes the sweating lord.
trg: Welcome, my lord: what, will our mother come?

src: Ay, but not mine own desire.
trg: How not your own desire?

src: Excepting one, I would he were the best In all this presence that hath moved me so.
trg: If that thy valour stand on sympathy, There is my gage, Aumerle, in gage to thine:

src: So, your opinion is, Aufidius, That they of Rome are entered in our counsels And know how we proceed.
trg: Is it not yours? What ever have been thought on in this state, That could be brought to bodily act ere Rome Had circumvention? 'Tis not four days gone Since I heard thence; these are the words:

src: but then you'll think-- Which I protest against--I am assisted By wicked powers.
trg: What you can make her do, I am content to look on: what to speak, I am content to hear; for 'tis as easy To make her speak as move.

src: ' quoth she; 'I'll fume with them:' And, with that word, she struck me on the head, And through the instrument my pate made way;
trg: And there I stood amazed for a while, As on a pillory, looking through the lute; While she did call me rascal fiddler And twangling Jack;

src: Withal I did infer your lineaments, Being the right idea of your father, Both in your form and nobleness of mind;
trg: Laid open all your victories in Scotland, Your dicipline in war, wisdom in peace, Your bounty, virtue, fair humility:'

src: Good faith, and when I met this holy man, Those men you talk of came into my mind. What, go you toward the Tower?
trg: I do, my lord; but long I shall not stay I shall return before your lordship thence.

src: I warrant him, Petruchio is Kated.
trg: Neighbours and friends, though bride and bridegroom wants For to supply the places at the table, You know there wants no junkets at the feast. Lucentio, you shall supply the bridegroom's place:

src: If! He is their god: he leads them like a thing Made by some other deity than nature, That shapes man better;
trg: and they follow him, Against us brats, with no less confidence Than boys pursuing summer butterflies, Or butchers killing flies.

src: How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?
trg: I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord, You said that idle weeds are fast in growth The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.

src: Come on, strike up!
trg: Mopsa must be your mistress: marry, garlic, To mend her kissing with!

src: O Warwick, I do bend my knee with thine; And in this vow do chain my soul to thine! Now, lords, take leave until we meet again, Where'er it be, in heaven or in earth.
trg: Brother, give me thy hand; and, gentle Warwick, Let me embrace thee in my weary arms: I, that did never weep, now melt with woe That winter should cut off our spring-time so.

src: Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost: My grandam told me he was murdered there.
trg: I fear no uncles dead.

src: I beseech you, Grant me this boon.
trg: With all my heart; and much it joys me too, To see you are become so penitent. Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.

src: That by degrees we mean to look into, And watch our vantage in this business: We'll over-reach the greybeard, Gremio, The narrow-prying father, Minola, The quaint musician, amorous Licio;
trg: All for my master's sake, Lucentio. Signior Gremio, came you from the church?

src: Thou art always figuring diseases in me; but thou art full of error; I am sound.
trg: Nay, not as one would say, healthy; but so sound as things that are hollow: thy bones are hollow; impiety has made a feast of thee.

src: Musicians, O, musicians, 'Heart's ease, Heart's ease:' O, an you will have me live, play 'Heart's ease.'
trg: Why 'Heart's ease?'

src: Answer me to-morrow, Or, by the affection that now guides me most, I'll prove a tyrant to him. As for you, Say what you can, my false o'erweighs your true.
trg: To whom should I complain? Did I tell this, Who would believe me? O perilous mouths, That bear in them one and the self-same tongue, Either of condemnation or approof;

src: Our hap is loss, our hope but sad despair; Our ranks are broke, and ruin follows us: What counsel give you? whither shall we fly?
trg: Bootless is flight, they follow us with wings; And weak we are and cannot shun pursuit.

src: Most true, if ever truth were pregnant by circumstance: that which you hear you'll swear you see, there is such unity in the proofs. Did you see the meeting of the two kings?
trg: No.

src: Why, so: now have I done a good day's work: You peers, continue this united league: I every day expect an embassage From my Redeemer to redeem me hence;
trg: And now in peace my soul shall part to heaven, Since I have set my friends at peace on earth. Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hand; Dissemble not your hatred, swear your love.

src: I am content.
trg: Lo, citizens, he says he is content: The warlike service he has done, consider; think Upon the wounds his body bears, which show Like graves i' the holy churchyard.

src: If God prevent not, I purpose so.
trg: What seal is that, that hangs without thy bosom? Yea, look'st thou pale? let me see the writing.

src: I am attended at the cypress grove: I pray you-- 'Tis south the city mills--bring me word thither How the world goes, that to the pace of it I may spur on my journey.
trg: I shall, sir.

src: Why dost thou stay?
trg: Which way ran he that kill'd Mercutio? Tybalt, that murderer, which way ran he?

src: Here comes a gentleman that haply knows more. The news, Rogero?
trg: Nothing but bonfires: the oracle is fulfilled; the king's daughter is found: such a deal of wonder is broken out within this hour that ballad-makers cannot be able to express it.

src: You pay a great deal too dear for what's given freely.
trg: Believe me, I speak as my understanding instructs me and as mine honesty puts it to utterance.

src: which, say to her, did drain The purple sap from her sweet brother's body And bid her dry her weeping eyes therewith. If this inducement force her not to love, Send her a story of thy noble acts;
trg: Tell her thou madest away her uncle Clarence, Her uncle Rivers; yea, and, for her sake, Madest quick conveyance with her good aunt Anne.

src: He had so; looking as it were--would I were hanged, but I thought there was more in him than I could think.
trg: So did I, I'll be sworn: he is simply the rarest man i' the world.

src: Pray you, let's hear.
Make not impossible That which but seems unlike: 'tis not impossible But one, the wicked'st caitiff on the ground, May seem as shy, as grave, as just, as absolute As Angelo;
trg: even so may Angelo, In all his dressings, characts, titles, forms, Be an arch-villain; believe it, royal prince: If he be less, he's nothing; but he's more, Had I more name for badness.

src: That last is true; the sweeter rest was mine.
trg: God pardon sin! wast thou with Rosaline?

src: Ely with Richmond troubles me more near Than Buckingham and his rash-levied army. Come, I have heard that fearful commenting Is leaden servitor to dull delay;
trg: Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggary Then fiery expedition be my wing, Jove's Mercury, and herald for a king! Come, muster men: my counsel is my shield;

src: Now, pray, sir, get you gone: You have done a brave deed. Ere you go, hear this:
trg: -- As far as doth the Capitol exceed The meanest house in Rome, so far my son-- This lady's husband here, this, do you see-- Whom you have banish'd, does exceed you all.

src: To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.
trg: Why, then thou shalt not have thy husband's lands.

src: Better do so than tarry and be hang'd.
trg: Come then, away; let's ha' no more ado.

src: No harm.
trg: More to know Did never meddle with my thoughts.

src: No wonder, sir; But certainly a maid.
trg: My language! heavens! I am the best of them that speak this speech, Were I but where 'tis spoken.

src: I pray you, let it stand.
trg: The poorest service is repaid with thanks; And so shall mine, before you touch the meat.

src: Thou worthiest Marcius! Go, sound thy trumpet in the market-place; Call thither all the officers o' the town, Where they shall know our mind: away!
trg: Breathe you, my friends: well fought; we are come off Like Romans, neither foolish in our stands, Nor cowardly in retire: believe me, sirs, We shall be charged again.

src: I do desire to learn, sir: and I hope, if you have occasion to use me for your own turn, you shall find me yare; for truly, sir, for your kindness I owe you a good turn.
trg: Call hither Barnardine and Claudio: The one has my pity; not a jot the other, Being a murderer, though he were my brother. Look, here's the warrant, Claudio, for thy death:

src: O God! did Romeo's hand shed Tybalt's blood?
trg: It did, it did; alas the day, it did!

src: My lord Sebastian, The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness And time to speak it in: you rub the sore, When you should bring the plaster.
trg: Very well.

src: My foreward shall be drawn out all in length, Consisting equally of horse and foot;
trg: Our archers shall be placed in the midst John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Surrey, Shall have the leading of this foot and horse.

src: Thou shalt be free As mountain winds: but then exactly do All points of my command.
trg: To the syllable.

src: Read it.
trg: The note lies in's throat, if he say I said so.

src: Peter, take my fan, and go before and apace.
trg: The clock struck nine when I did send the nurse; In half an hour she promised to return. Perchance she cannot meet him: that's not so. O, she is lame!

src: Thank you, good Pompey; and, in requital of your prophecy, hark you: I advise you, let me not find you before me again upon any complaint whatsoever; no, not for dwelling where you do:
trg: if I do, Pompey, I shall beat you to your tent, and prove a shrewd Caesar to you; in plain dealing, Pompey, I shall have you whipt: so, for this time, Pompey, fare you well.

src: By holy Paul, they love his grace but lightly That fill his ears with such dissentious rumours.
trg: Because I cannot flatter and speak fair, Smile in men's faces, smooth, deceive and cog, Duck with French nods and apish courtesy, I must be held a rancorous enemy.

src: No more talking on't; let it be done: away, away!
trg: One word, good citizens.

src: High-stomach'd are they both, and full of ire, In rage deaf as the sea, hasty as fire.
trg: Many years of happy days befal My gracious sovereign, my most loving liege!

src: Why I desire thee To give me secret harbour, hath a purpose More grave and wrinkled than the aims and ends Of burning youth.
trg: May your grace speak of it?

src: O my most sacred lady! Temptations have since then been born to's; for In those unfledged days was my wife a girl; Your precious self had then not cross'd the eyes Of my young play-fellow.
trg: Grace to boot! Of this make no conclusion, lest you say Your queen and I are devils: yet go on;

src: Needs must I like it well: I weep for joy To stand upon my kingdom once again. Dear earth, I do salute thee with my hand, Though rebels wound thee with their horses' hoofs:
trg: As a long-parted mother with her child Plays fondly with her tears and smiles in meeting, So, weeping, smiling, greet I thee, my earth, And do thee favours with my royal hands.

src: Welcome, my son: who are the violets now That strew the green lap of the new come spring?
trg: Madam, I know not, nor I greatly care not: God knows I had as lief be none as one.

src: Masterly done: The very life seems warm upon her lip.
trg: The fixture of her eye has motion in't, As we are mock'd with art.

src: ' Thus we debase The nature of our seats and make the rabble Call our cares fears; which will in time Break ope the locks o' the senate and bring in The crows to peck the eagles.
trg: Come, enough.

src: God for his mercy! what a tide of woes Comes rushing on this woeful land at once! I know not what to do:
trg: I would to God, So my untruth had not provoked him to it, The king had cut off my head with my brother's. What, are there no posts dispatch'd for Ireland? How shall we do for money for these wars?

src: Madam, we'll dance.
trg: My legs can keep no measure in delight, When my poor heart no measure keeps in grief: Therefore, no dancing, girl; some other sport.

src: But, since it serves my purpose, I will venture To stale 't a little more.
trg: Well, I'll hear it, sir: yet you must not think to fob off our disgrace with a tale: but, an 't please you, deliver.

src: A woman.
trg: But what's his offence?

src: And, for an entrance to my entertainment, I do present you with a man of mine, Cunning in music and the mathematics, To instruct her fully in those sciences, Whereof I know she is not ignorant:
trg: Accept of him, or else you do me wrong: His name is Licio, born in Mantua.

src: Was ever match clapp'd up so suddenly?
trg: Faith, gentlemen, now I play a merchant's part, And venture madly on a desperate mart.

src: to whose feeling sorrows I might be some allay, or I o'erween to think so, which is another spur to my departure.
trg: As thou lovest me, Camillo, wipe not out the rest of thy services by leaving me now: the need I have of thee thine own goodness hath made; better not to have had thee than thus to want thee:

src: Wonder not, Nor be grieved: she is of good esteem, Her dowery wealthy, and of worthy birth; Beside, so qualified as may beseem The spouse of any noble gentleman.
