trg: Let me embrace with old Vincentio, And wander we to see thy honest son, Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.

src: At what hour to-morrow Shall I attend your lordship?
trg: At any time 'fore noon.

src: Besides, he tells me that, if peradventure He speak against me on the adverse side, I should not think it strange; for 'tis a physic That's bitter to sweet end.
trg: I would Friar Peter--

src: Had he done so, himself had borne the crown, Which waste of idle hours hath quite thrown down.
trg: What, think you then the king shall be deposed?

src: Mended again. The matter; proceed.
trg: He would not, but by gift of my chaste body To his concupiscible intemperate lust, Release my brother; and, after much debatement, My sisterly remorse confutes mine honour, And I did yield to him:

src: How hast thou offended? Where is Lucentio?
trg: Here's Lucentio, Right son to the right Vincentio; That have by marriage made thy daughter mine, While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.

src: Thy sun sets weeping in the lowly west, Witnessing storms to come, woe and unrest: Thy friends are fled to wait upon thy foes, And crossly to thy good all fortune goes.
trg: Bring forth these men. Bushy and Green, I will not vex your souls-- Since presently your souls must part your bodies-- With too much urging your pernicious lives, For 'twere no charity;

src: What storm is this that blows so contrary? Is Romeo slaughter'd, and is Tybalt dead? My dear-loved cousin, and my dearer lord? Then, dreadful trumpet, sound the general doom!
trg: For who is living, if those two are gone?

src: If they have done this thing, my gracious lord--
trg: If I thou protector of this damned strumpet-- Tellest thou me of 'ifs'?  Thou art a traitor: Off with his head! Now, by Saint Paul I swear, I will not dine until I see the same.

src: You have brought A trembling upon Rome, such as was never So incapable of help.
trg: Say not we brought it.

src: First will I see the coronation; And then to Brittany I'll cross the sea, To effect this marriage, so it please my lord.
trg: Even as thou wilt, sweet Warwick, let it be; For in thy shoulder do I build my seat, And never will I undertake the thing Wherein thy counsel and consent is wanting.

src: and set down-- As best thou art experienced, since thou know'st Thy country's strength and weakness,--thine own ways;
trg: Whether to knock against the gates of Rome, Or rudely visit them in parts remote, To fright them, ere destroy. But come in: Let me commend thee first to those that shall Say yea to thy desires.

src: O, let me speak!
trg: Do then: but I'll not hear.

src: you that have worn your eyes almost out in the service, you will be considered.
trg: What's to do here, Thomas tapster? let's withdraw.

src: O blessed heavens!
trg: More noble blows than ever thou wise words; And for Rome's good. I'll tell thee what; yet go: Nay, but thou shalt stay too:

src: 'Twas never merry world since, of two usuries, the merriest was put down, and the worser allowed by order of law a furred gown to keep him warm;
trg: and furred with fox and lamb-skins too, to signify, that craft, being richer than innocency, stands for the facing.

src: I pray thee, good Mercutio, let's retire: The day is hot, the Capulets abroad, And, if we meet, we shall not scape a brawl; For now, these hot days, is the mad blood stirring.
trg: Thou art like one of those fellows that when he enters the confines of a tavern claps me his sword upon the table and says 'God send me no need of thee!

src: Here come the Lords of Ross and Willoughby, Bloody with spurring, fiery-red with haste.
trg: Welcome, my lords. I wot your love pursues A banish'd traitor: all my treasury Is yet but unfelt thanks, which more enrich'd Shall be your love and labour's recompense.

src: is he not stupid With age and altering rheums? can he speak? hear? Know man from man? dispute his own estate? Lies he not bed-rid? and again does nothing But what he did being childish?
trg: No, good sir; He has his health and ampler strength indeed Than most have of his age.

src: Good aunt, you wept not for our father's death; How can we aid you with our kindred tears?
trg: Our fatherless distress was left unmoan'd; Your widow-dolour likewise be unwept!

src: Why, what is Tybalt?
trg: More than prince of cats, I can tell you. O, he is the courageous captain of compliments. He fights as you sing prick-song, keeps time, distance, and proportion;

src: since he came, With what encounter so uncurrent I Have strain'd to appear thus:
trg: if one jot beyond The bound of honour, or in act or will That way inclining, harden'd be the hearts Of all that hear me, and my near'st of kin Cry fie upon my grave!

src: Bid her devise Some means to come to shrift this afternoon; And there she shall at Friar Laurence' cell Be shrived and married. Here is for thy pains.
trg: No truly sir; not a penny.

src: Tut, you saw her fair, none else being by, Herself poised with herself in either eye:
trg: But in that crystal scales let there be weigh'd Your lady's love against some other maid That I will show you shining at this feast, And she shall scant show well that now shows best.

src: From all such devils, good Lord deliver us!
trg: And me too, good Lord!

src: How many children hast thou, widow? tell me.
Tybalt, here slain, whom Romeo's hand did slay; Romeo that spoke him fair, bade him bethink How nice the quarrel was, and urged withal Your high displeasure: Romeo he cries aloud, 'Hold, friends!
trg: friends, part!' and, swifter than his tongue, His agile arm beats down their fatal points, And 'twixt them rushes;

src: Make us thy ministers of chastisement, That we may praise thee in the victory! To thee I do commend my watchful soul, Ere I let fall the windows of mine eyes: Sleeping and waking, O, defend me still!
Nor do I think the man of safe discretion That does affect it. Once more, fare you well.
trg: The heavens give safety to your purposes!

src: His friends still wrought reprieves for him: and, indeed, his fact, till now in the government of Lord Angelo, came not to an undoubtful proof.
trg: It is now apparent?

src: Why 'her unhappy brother'? let me ask, The rather for I now must make you know I am that Isabella and his sister.
trg: Gentle and fair, your brother kindly greets you: Not to be weary with you, he's in prison.

src: Ha! little honour to be much believed, And most pernicious purpose! Seeming, seeming! I will proclaim thee, Angelo; look for't:
trg: Sign me a present pardon for my brother, Or with an outstretch'd throat I'll tell the world aloud What man thou art.

src: Yea, distaff-women manage rusty bills Against thy seat: both young and old rebel, And all goes worse than I have power to tell.
trg: Too well, too well thou tell'st a tale so ill. Where is the Earl of Wiltshire? where is Bagot? What is become of Bushy? where is Green?

src: Desires you to attach his son, who has-- His dignity and duty both cast off-- Fled from his father, from his hopes, and with A shepherd's daughter.
trg: Where's Bohemia? speak.

src: I know you'ld fain be gone. An officer! To prison with her! Shall we thus permit A blasting and a scandalous breath to fall On him so near us? This needs must be a practise.
trg: Who knew of Your intent and coming hither?

src: ' And full as oft came Edward to my side, With purple falchion, painted to the hilt In blood of those that had encounter'd him: And when the hardiest warriors did retire, Richard cried 'Charge!
trg: and give no foot of ground!' And cried 'A crown, or else a glorious tomb! A sceptre, or an earthly sepulchre!' With this, we charged again: but, out, alas! We bodged again;

src: hath sorrow struck So many blows upon this face of mine, And made no deeper wounds? O flattering glass, Like to my followers in prosperity, Thou dost beguile me!
trg: Was this face the face That every day under his household roof Did keep ten thousand men? was this the face That, like the sun, did make beholders wink?

src: Thou want'st a rough pash and the shoots that I have, To be full like me: yet they say we are Almost as like as eggs; Come, sir page, Look on me with your welkin eye: sweet villain! Most dear'st!
trg: my collop! Can thy dam?--may't be?-- Affection! thy intention stabs the centre: Thou dost make possible things not so held, Communicatest with dreams;--how can this be?

src: Doth he so seek his life?
trg: Has censured him Already; and, as I hear, the provost hath A warrant for his execution.

src: Bidding the law make court'sy to their will: Hooking both right and wrong to the appetite, To follow as it draws! I'll to my brother:
trg: Though he hath fallen by prompture of the blood, Yet hath he in him such a mind of honour.

src: Ay, the woman's maid of the house.
trg: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!

src: My first son. Whither wilt thou go? Take good Cominius With thee awhile: determine on some course, More than a wild exposture to each chance That starts i' the way before thee.
trg: O the gods!

src: If, in thy wisdom, thou canst give no help, Do thou but call my resolution wise, And with this knife I'll help it presently. God join'd my heart and Romeo's, thou our hands;
trg: And ere this hand, by thee to Romeo seal'd, Shall be the label to another deed, Or my true heart with treacherous revolt Turn to another, this shall slay them both: Be not so long to speak;

src: Noble Aufidius, Take your commission; hie you to your bands: Let us alone to guard Corioli: If they set down before 's, for the remove Bring your army;
trg: but, I think, you'll find They've not prepared for us.

src: Welcome, brave Warwick! What brings thee to France?
trg: Ay, now begins a second storm to rise; For this is he that moves both wind and tide.

src: Foul shame upon you! you have all moved mine.
trg: Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.

src: The mathematics and the metaphysics, Fall to them as you find your stomach serves you; No profit grows where is no pleasure ta'en: In brief, sir, study what you most affect.
trg: Gramercies, Tranio, well dost thou advise. If, Biondello, thou wert come ashore, We could at once put us in readiness, And take a lodging fit to entertain Such friends as time in Padua shall beget.

src: No longer stay.
trg: One seven-night longer.

src: ' his bloody brow With his mail'd hand then wiping, forth he goes, Like to a harvest-man that's task'd to mow Or all or lose his hire.
trg: His bloody brow! O Jupiter, no blood!

src: Double and treble admonition, and still forfeit in the same kind! This would make mercy swear and play the tyrant.
trg: A bawd of eleven years' continuance, may it please your honour.

src: And when I give occasion of offence, Then let me die, for now thou hast no cause.
trg: No cause! Thy father slew my father; therefore, die.

src: How well my comfort is revived by this!
trg: Go hence; good night; and here stands all your state: Either be gone before the watch be set, Or by the break of day disguised from hence: Sojourn in Mantua;

src: I know him not, but I have heard of him; A merchant of incomparable wealth.
trg: He is my father, sir; and, sooth to say, In countenance somewhat doth resemble you.

src: My other self, my counsel's consistory, My oracle, my prophet! My dear cousin, I, like a child, will go by thy direction. Towards Ludlow then, for we'll not stay behind.
trg: Neighbour, well met: whither away so fast?

src: And with thy blessings steel my lance's point, That it may enter Mowbray's waxen coat, And furbish new the name of John a Gaunt, Even in the lusty havior of his son.
trg: God in thy good cause make thee prosperous! Be swift like lightning in the execution; And let thy blows, doubly redoubled, Fall like amazing thunder on the casque Of thy adverse pernicious enemy:

src: Come, let us to our holy task again. Farewell, good cousin; farewell, gentle friends.
trg: Who meets us here?  my niece Plantagenet Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester? Now, for my life, she's wandering to the Tower, On pure heart's love to greet the tender princes.

src: Where then, alas, may I complain myself?
trg: To God, the widow's champion and defence.

src: His royal person,-- Whom God preserve better than you would wish!-- Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing-while, But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.
trg: Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the matter. The king, of his own royal disposition, And not provoked by any suitor else;

src: Thus have I politicly begun my reign, And 'tis my hope to end successfully. My falcon now is sharp and passing empty;
trg: And till she stoop she must not be full-gorged, For then she never looks upon her lure.

src: Suppose, my lords, he did it unconstrain'd, Think you 'twere prejudicial to his crown?
trg: No; for he could not so resign his crown But that the next heir should succeed and reign.

src: It is a quarrel just and reasonable, To be revenged on him that slew my husband.
trg: He that bereft thee, lady, of thy husband, Did it to help thee to a better husband.

src: Farewell, my gracious lord; I'll to my castle.
trg: And I'll keep London with my soldiers.

src: Say 'better:' here comes one of my master's kinsmen.
trg: Yes, better, sir.

src: Then he was urged to tell my tale again, 'Thus saith the duke, thus hath the duke inferr'd;' But nothing spake in warrant from himself.
trg: When he had done, some followers of mine own, At the lower end of the hall, hurl'd up their caps, And some ten voices cried 'God save King Richard!

src: Your mistress' name?
trg: Mistress Overdone.

src: No quarrel, but a slight contention.
trg: About what?

src: Most notedly, sir.
trg: Do you so, sir? And was the duke a fleshmonger, a fool, and a coward, as you then reported him to be?

src: Sir, my mistress sends you word That she is busy and she cannot come.
trg: How! she is busy and she cannot come! Is that an answer?

src: What is granted them?
trg: Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms, Of their own choice: one's Junius Brutus, Sicinius Velutus, and I know not--'Sdeath!

src: Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius?
trg: He has no equal.

src: It must and shall be so: content thyself.
trg: Be Duke of Lancaster; let him be king.

src: Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe, A villain that is hither come in spite, To scorn at our solemnity this night.
trg: Young Romeo is it?

src: Who comes with him?
trg: O, sir, his lackey, for all the world caparisoned like the horse; with a linen stock on one leg and a kersey boot-hose on the other, gartered with a red and blue list;

src: --How now, Balthasar! Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar? How doth my lady? Is my father well? How fares my Juliet? that I ask again; For nothing can be ill, if she be well.
trg: Then she is well, and nothing can be ill: Her body sleeps in Capel's monument, And her immortal part with angels lives.

src: 'Tis the way To call hers exquisite, in question more: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows Being black put us in mind they hide the fair;
trg: He that is strucken blind cannot forget The precious treasure of his eyesight lost:

src: Huntsman, I charge thee, tender well my hounds: Brach Merriman, the poor cur is emboss'd; And couple Clowder with the deep--mouth'd brach.
trg: Saw'st thou not, boy, how Silver made it good At the hedge-corner, in the coldest fault? I would not lose the dog for twenty pound.

src: You do him wrong, surely.
trg: Sir, I was an inward of his. A shy fellow was the duke: and I believe I know the cause of his withdrawing.

src: Know thus far forth. By accident most strange, bountiful Fortune, Now my dear lady, hath mine enemies Brought to this shore;
trg: and by my prescience I find my zenith doth depend upon A most auspicious star, whose influence If now I court not but omit, my fortunes Will ever after droop. Here cease more questions:

src: We two, my lord, Will guard your person while you take your rest, And watch your safety.
trg: Thank you. Wondrous heavy.

src: Hist! Romeo, hist! O, for a falconer's voice, To lure this tassel-gentle back again! Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud;
trg: Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies, And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, With repetition of my Romeo's name.

src: What, is the man lunatic?
trg: Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by your habit, but your words show you a madman. Why, sir, what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold? I thank my good father, I am able to maintain it.

src: Lay A fault on us, your tribunes; that we laboured, No impediment between, but that you must Cast your election on him.
trg: lay the fault on us.

src: My lord, you shall o'er-rule my mind for once. Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?
trg: I go, my lord.

src: O, 'twas the foulest deed to slay that babe, And the most merciless that e'er was heard of!
trg: Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.

src: More than prince of cats, I can tell you. O, he is the courageous captain of compliments. He fights as you sing prick-song, keeps time, distance, and proportion;
trg: rests me his minim rest, one, two, and the third in your bosom: the very butcher of a silk button, a duellist, a duellist; a gentleman of the very first house, of the first and second cause:

src: O that you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks, and make but an interior survey of your good selves! O that you could!
trg: What then, sir?

src: We'll keep no great ado,--a friend or two; For, hark you, Tybalt being slain so late, It may be thought we held him carelessly, Being our kinsman, if we revel much:
trg: Therefore we'll have some half a dozen friends, And there an end. But what say you to Thursday?

src: Do not bid me Dismiss my soldiers, or capitulate Again with Rome's mechanics: tell me not Wherein I seem unnatural: desire not To ally my rages and revenges with Your colder reasons.
trg: O, no more, no more! You have said you will not grant us any thing; For we have nothing else to ask, but that Which you deny already: yet we will ask;

src: He swore consent to your succession, His oath enrolled in the parliament; And now to London all the crew are gone, To frustrate both his oath and what beside May make against the house of Lancaster.
trg: Their power, I think, is thirty thousand strong:

src: What say'st thou, my dear nurse?
trg: Is your man secret? Did you ne'er hear say, Two may keep counsel, putting one away?

src: His name is Romeo, and a Montague; The only son of your great enemy.
trg: My only love sprung from my only hate! Too early seen unknown, and known too late! Prodigious birth of love it is to me, That I must love a loathed enemy.

src: Have you collected them by tribes?
trg: I have.

src: You shall not be admitted to his sight.
trg: Unhappy Claudio! wretched Isabel! Injurious world! most damned Angelo!

src: A brace of draymen bid God speed him well And had the tribute of his supple knee, With 'Thanks, my countrymen, my loving friends;
trg: ' As were our England in reversion his, And he our subjects' next degree in hope.

src: Not that I pity Henry's misery, But seek revenge on Edward's mockery. 3 KING HENRY VI
trg: Now tell me, brother Clarence, what think you Of this new marriage with the Lady Grey? Hath not our brother made a worthy choice?

src: What can you vouch against him, Signior Lucio? Is this the man that you did tell us of?
trg: 'Tis he, my lord. Come hither, goodman baldpate: do you know me?

src: What would you have, friend? whence are you? Here's no place for you: pray, go to the door.
trg: I have deserved no better entertainment, In being Coriolanus.

src: Go to: what quality are they of? Elbow is your name? why dost thou not speak, Elbow?
trg: He cannot, sir; he's out at elbow.

src: If the duke with the other dukes come not to composition with the King of Hungary, why then all the dukes fall upon the king.
trg: Heaven grant us its peace, but not the King of Hungary's!

src: I did not kill your husband.
trg: Why, then he is alive.

src: Why, what should you fear?
trg: Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost: My grandam told me he was murdered there.

src: I was by at the opening of the fardel, heard the old shepherd deliver the manner how he found it: whereupon, after a little amazedness, we were all commanded out of the chamber;
trg: only this methought I heard the shepherd say, he found the child.

src: You will think you have made no offence, if the duke avouch the justice of your dealing?
trg: But what likelihood is in that?

src: I, sir! ne'er a whit.
trg: And not a jot of Tranio in your mouth: Tranio is changed into Lucentio.

src: But in that crystal scales let there be weigh'd Your lady's love against some other maid That I will show you shining at this feast, And she shall scant show well that now shows best.
trg: I'll go along, no such sight to be shown, But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.

src: And if we be, how dare thy joints forget To pay their awful duty to our presence? If we be not, show us the hand of God That hath dismissed us from our stewardship;
trg: For well we know, no hand of blood and bone Can gripe the sacred handle of our sceptre, Unless he do profane, steal, or usurp.

src: Give me some breath, some little pause, my lord Before I positively herein: I will resolve your grace immediately.
A cold premeditation for my purpose! Why, then, I do but dream on sovereignty; So do I wish the crown, being so far off; And so I chide the means that keeps me from it;
trg: And so I say, I'll cut the causes off, Flattering me with impossibilities. My eye's too quick, my heart o'erweens too much, Unless my hand and strength could equal them.

src: Wisely and slow; they stumble that run fast.
trg: Where the devil should this Romeo be? Came he not home to-night?

src: And when my uncle told me so, he wept, And hugg'd me in his arm, and kindly kiss'd my cheek; Bade me rely on him as on my father, And he would love me dearly as his child.
trg: Oh, that deceit should steal such gentle shapes, And with a virtuous vizard hide foul guile! He is my son; yea, and therein my shame; Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.

src: What, canst not rule her?
trg: From all dishonesty he can: in this, Unless he take the course that you have done, Commit me for committing honour, trust it, He shall not rule me.

src: Go, some of you convey him to the Tower.
trg: O, good! convey? conveyers are you all, That rise thus nimbly by a true king's fall.

src: No, sir, I do not bite my thumb at you, sir, but I bite my thumb, sir.
trg: Do you quarrel, sir?

src: The Duke of Norfolk sends you word by me, The queen is coming with a puissant host; And craves your company for speedy counsel.
trg: Why then it sorts, brave warriors, let's away. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: but, as I said, On Lammas-eve at night shall she be fourteen; That shall she, marry; I remember it well. 'Tis since the earthquake now eleven years;
trg: And she was wean'd,--I never shall forget it,-- Of all the days of the year, upon that day: For I had then laid wormwood to my dug, Sitting in the sun under the dove-house wall;

src: O Ned, sweet Ned! speak to thy mother, boy! Canst thou not speak? O traitors! murderers!
trg: They that stabb'd Caesar shed no blood at all, Did not offend, nor were not worthy blame, If this foul deed were by to equal it: He was a man; this, in respect, a child:

src: I must perforce. Farewell.
trg: Go, tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return. Simple, plain Clarence! I do love thee so, That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven, If heaven will take the present at our hands.

src: How have you slept, my lord?
trg: The sweetest sleep, and fairest-boding dreams That ever enter'd in a drowsy head, Have I since your departure had, my lords.

src: Hark, Perdita I'll hear you by and by.
trg: He's irremoveable, Resolved for flight.

src: I tell you, he does sit in gold, his eye Red as 'twould burn Rome; and his injury The gaoler to his pity. I kneel'd before him; 'Twas very faintly he said 'Rise;
trg: ' dismiss'd me Thus, with his speechless hand: what he would do, He sent in writing after me; what he would not, Bound with an oath to yield to his conditions: So that all hope is vain.

src: I do owe them still My life and services.
trg: It then remains That you do speak to the people.

src: A letter for me! it gives me an estate of seven years' health; in which time I will make a lip at the physician:
trg: the most sovereign prescription in Galen is but empiricutic, and, to this preservative, of no better report than a horse-drench. Is he not wounded? he was wont to come home wounded.

src: What is become of Marcius?
trg: Slain, sir, doubtless.

src: Truly, sir, I am a poor fellow that would live.
trg: How would you live, Pompey? by being a bawd? What do you think of the trade, Pompey? is it a lawful trade?

src: He must before the deputy, sir; he has given him warning: the deputy cannot abide a whoremaster: if he be a whoremonger, and comes before him, he were as good go a mile on his errand.
trg: That we were all, as some would seem to be, From our faults, as faults from seeming, free!

src: Can this be so? did Angelo so leave her?
trg: Left her in her tears, and dried not one of them with his comfort; swallowed his vows whole, pretending in her discoveries of dishonour:

src: such a pother As if that whatsoever god who leads him Were slily crept into his human powers And gave him graceful posture.
trg: On the sudden, I warrant him consul.

src: How lush and lusty the grass looks! how green!
trg: The ground indeed is tawny.

src: I dare assure you, sir, 'tis almost two; And 'twill be supper-time ere you come there.
trg: It shall be seven ere I go to horse: Look, what I speak, or do, or think to do, You are still crossing it. Sirs, let't alone: I will not go to-day; and ere I do, It shall be what o'clock I say it is.

src: May it please you, lords, to grant the commons' suit.
trg: Fetch hither Richard, that in common view He may surrender; so we shall proceed Without suspicion.

src: Ye re goodly things, you voices!
trg: You have made Good work, you and your cry! Shall's to the Capitol?

src: Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner: I see a woman may be made a fool, If she had not a spirit to resist.
trg: They shall go forward, Kate, at thy command. Obey the bride, you that attend on her;

src: As near the dawning, provost, as it is, You shall hear more ere morning.
trg: Happily You something know; yet I believe there comes No countermand; no such example have we: Besides, upon the very siege of justice Lord Angelo hath to the public ear Profess'd the contrary.

src: But for the rest, you tell a pedigree Of threescore and two years; a silly time To make prescription for a kingdom's worth.
trg: Why, Warwick, canst thou speak against thy liege, Whom thou obeyed'st thirty and six years, And not bewray thy treason with a blush?

src: If I thou protector of this damned strumpet-- Tellest thou me of 'ifs'?  Thou art a traitor: Off with his head! Now, by Saint Paul I swear, I will not dine until I see the same.
trg: Lovel and Ratcliff, look that it be done: The rest, that love me, rise and follow me.

src: If yet your gentle souls fly in the air And be not fix'd in doom perpetual, Hover about me with your airy wings And hear your mother's lamentation!
trg: Hover about her; say, that right for right Hath dimm'd your infant morn to aged night.

src: I would Friar Peter--
trg: O, peace! the friar is come.

src: How if it come to thee again?
trg: I'll not meddle with it: it is a dangerous thing: it makes a man a coward: a man cannot steal, but it accuseth him; he cannot swear, but it cheques him;

src: She shall, she shall.
trg: Indeed, no, by your patience; I'll not over the threshold till my lord return from the wars.

src: He something seems unsettled.
trg: How, my lord! What cheer? how is't with you, best brother?

src: That he, our hope, might have retired his power, And driven into despair an enemy's hope, Who strongly hath set footing in this land:
trg: The banish'd Bolingbroke repeals himself, And with uplifted arms is safe arrived At Ravenspurgh.

src: O piteous spectacle! O bloody times! Whiles lions war and battle for their dens, Poor harmless lambs abide their enmity. Weep, wretched man, I'll aid thee tear for tear;
trg: And let our hearts and eyes, like civil war, Be blind with tears, and break o'ercharged with grief.

src: yet, by the faith of men, We have some old crab-trees here at home that will not Be grafted to your relish. Yet welcome, warriors: We call a nettle but a nettle and The faults of fools but folly.
trg: Ever right.

src: 'Hic steterat,' and that Lucentio that comes a-wooing, 'Priami,' is my man Tranio, 'regia,' bearing my port, 'celsa senis,' that we might beguile the old pantaloon.
trg: Madam, my instrument's in tune.

src: Nay, your wit will not so soon out as another man's will;'tis strongly wedged up in a block-head, but if it were at liberty, 'twould, sure, southward.
trg: Why that way?

src: To her, widow!
trg: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

src: And no worldly suit would he be moved, To draw him from his holy exercise.
trg: Return, good Catesby, to thy lord again;

src: To men in joy; but grief makes one hour ten.
trg: Call it a travel that thou takest for pleasure.

src: As thou lovest me, Camillo, wipe not out the rest of thy services by leaving me now: the need I have of thee thine own goodness hath made; better not to have had thee than thus to want thee:
trg: thou, having made me businesses which none without thee can sufficiently manage, must either stay to execute them thyself or take away with thee the very services thou hast done;

src: Sorrow and grief of heart Makes him speak fondly, like a frantic man Yet he is come.
trg: Stand all apart, And show fair duty to his majesty. My gracious lord,--

src: For strokes received, and many blows repaid, Have robb'd my strong-knit sinews of their strength, And spite of spite needs must I rest awhile.
trg: Smile, gentle heaven! or strike, ungentle death! For this world frowns, and Edward's sun is clouded.

src: Come, I'll conduct you to the sanctuary.
trg: Welcome, sweet prince, to London, to your chamber.

src: The heavens have bless'd you with a goodly son, To be your comforter when he is gone.
trg: Oh, he is young and his minority Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester, A man that loves not me, nor none of you.

src: Things sweet to taste prove in digestion sour. You urged me as a judge; but I had rather You would have bid me argue like a father.
trg: O, had it been a stranger, not my child, To smooth his fault I should have been more mild: A partial slander sought I to avoid, And in the sentence my own life destroy'd.

src: but, gentle nurse, I pray thee, leave me to myself to-night, For I have need of many orisons To move the heavens to smile upon my state, Which, well thou know'st, is cross, and full of sin.
trg: What, are you busy, ho? need you my help?

src: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
trg: I do bite my thumb, sir.

src: Thus far our fortune keeps an upward course, And we are graced with wreaths of victory.
trg: But, in the midst of this bright-shining day, I spy a black, suspicious, threatening cloud, That will encounter with our glorious sun, Ere he attain his easeful western bed:

src: How high a pitch his resolution soars! Thomas of Norfolk, what say'st thou to this?
trg: O, let my sovereign turn away his face And bid his ears a little while be deaf, Till I have told this slander of his blood, How God and good men hate so foul a liar.

src: By heaven, fond wretch, thou knowist not what thou speak'st, Or else thou art suborn'd against his honour In hateful practise. First, his integrity Stands without blemish.
trg: Next, it imports no reason That with such vehemency he should pursue Faults proper to himself: if he had so offended, He would have weigh'd thy brother by himself And not have cut him off.

src: Many and hearty thankings to you both. We have made inquiry of you; and we hear Such goodness of your justice, that our soul Cannot but yield you forth to public thanks, Forerunning more requital.
trg: You make my bonds still greater.

src: Is the axe upon the block, sirrah?
trg: Very ready, sir.

src: 'Tis not possible.
trg: Who, not the duke? yes, your beggar of fifty; and his use was to put a ducat in her clack-dish: the duke had crotchets in him. He would be drunk too; that let me inform you.

src: Look, what is done cannot be now amended: Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes, Which after hours give leisure to repent.
trg: If I did take the kingdom from your sons, To make amends, Ill give it to your daughter. They are as children but one step below, Even of your mettle, of your very blood;

src: And, Norfolk, throw down his.
trg: When, Harry, when? Obedience bids I should not bid again.

src: Nay, by Saint Jamy, I hold you a penny, A horse and a man Is more than one, And yet not many.
trg: Come, where be these gallants? who's at home?

src: Well, my lord.
trg: My lord; I do confess I ne'er was married; And I confess besides I am no maid: I have known my husband; yet my husband Knows not that ever he knew me.

src: A crown for York! and, lords, bow low to him: Hold you his hands, whilst I do set it on. Ay, marry, sir, now looks he like a king!
trg: Ay, this is he that took King Henry's chair, And this is he was his adopted heir. But how is it that great Plantagenet Is crown'd so soon, and broke his solemn oath?

src: Unhappy Claudio! wretched Isabel! Injurious world! most damned Angelo!
trg: This nor hurts him nor profits you a jot; Forbear it therefore; give your cause to heaven. Mark what I say, which you shall find By every syllable a faithful verity: The duke comes home to-morrow;

src: Fouler than heart can think thee, thou canst make No excuse current, but to hang thyself.
trg: By such despair, I should accuse myself.

src: Three, they say: but 'tis thought of every one Coriolanus will carry it.
trg: That's a brave fellow; but he's vengeance proud, and loves not the common people.

src: So, master mayor: these gates must not be shut But in the night or in the time of war. What! fear not, man, but yield me up the keys;
trg: For Edward will defend the town and thee, And all those friends that deign to follow me.

src: Ay, what else? and but I be deceived Signior Baptista may remember me, Near twenty years ago, in Genoa, Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.
trg: 'Tis well; and hold your own, in any case, With such austerity as 'longeth to a father.

src: There's no remedy; Unless, by not so doing, our good city Cleave in the midst, and perish.
trg: Pray, be counsell'd: I have a heart as little apt as yours, But yet a brain that leads my use of anger To better vantage.

src: O master, master, I have watch'd so long That I am dog-weary: but at last I spied An ancient angel coming down the hill, Will serve the turn.
trg: What is he, Biondello?

src: but she shall be such As, walk'd your first queen's ghost, it should take joy To see her in your arms.
trg: My true Paulina, We shall not marry till thou bid'st us.

src: Be not so hot; the duke Dare no more stretch this finger of mine than he Dare rack his own: his subject am I not, Nor here provincial.
trg: My business in this state Made me a looker on here in Vienna, Where I have seen corruption boil and bubble Till it o'er-run the stew;

src: nay, let him choose Out of my files, his projects to accomplish, My best and freshest men; served his designments In mine own person; holp to reap the fame Which he did end all his;
trg: and took some pride To do myself this wrong: till, at the last, I seem'd his follower, not partner, and He waged me with his countenance, as if I had been mercenary.

src: But the rarity of it is,--which is indeed almost beyond credit,--
trg: As many vouched rarities are.

src: Away, I say; I charge ye, bear her hence.
trg: So come to you and yours, as to this Prince!

src: if they would yield us but the superfluity, while it were wholesome, we might guess they relieved us humanely; but they think we are too dear:
trg: the leanness that afflicts us, the object of our misery, is as an inventory to particularise their abundance; our sufferance is a gain to them Let us revenge this with our pikes, ere we become rakes:

src: Fair lords, take leave and stand not to reply. Farewell, my sovereign.
trg: Farewell, my Hector, and my Troy's true hope.

src: Yes; I do think that you might pardon him, And neither heaven nor man grieve at the mercy.
trg: I will not do't.
I shall obey him.

src: Our very priests must become mockers, if they shall encounter such ridiculous subjects as you are. When you speak best unto the purpose, it is not worth the wagging of your beards;
trg: and your beards deserve not so honourable a grave as to stuff a botcher's cushion, or to be entombed in an ass's pack- saddle. Yet you must be saying, Marcius is proud;

src: since that thy sight, which should Make our eyes flow with joy, hearts dance with comforts, Constrains them weep and shake with fear and sorrow;
trg: Making the mother, wife and child to see The son, the husband and the father tearing His country's bowels out. And to poor we Thine enmity's most capital:

src: In the mean time, against thou shalt awake, Shall Romeo by my letters know our drift, And hither shall he come:
trg: and he and I Will watch thy waking, and that very night Shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua. And this shall free thee from this present shame;

src: Thou art inclined to sleep; 'tis a good dulness, And give it way: I know thou canst not choose. Come away, servant, come. I am ready now. Approach, my Ariel, come.
trg: All hail, great master! grave sir, hail! I come To answer thy best pleasure;

src: If 'twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.
trg: A parlous boy: go to, you are too shrewd.

src: The mayor is here at hand: intend some fear; Be not you spoke with, but by mighty suit: And look you get a prayer-book in your hand, And stand betwixt two churchmen, good my lord;
trg: For on that ground I'll build a holy descant: And be not easily won to our request: Play the maid's part, still answer nay, and take it.

src: Part of your cares you give me with your crown.
trg: Your cares set up do not pluck my cares down. My care is loss of care, by old care done; Your care is gain of care, by new care won: The cares I give I have, though given away;

src: aidless came off, And with a sudden reinforcement struck Corioli like a planet: now all's his: When, by and by, the din of war gan pierce His ready sense;
trg: then straight his doubled spirit Re-quicken'd what in flesh was fatigate, And to the battle came he; where he did Run reeking o'er the lives of men, as if 'Twere a perpetual spoil:

src: What if we do omit This reprobate till he were well inclined; And satisfy the deputy with the visage Of Ragozine, more like to Claudio?
trg: O, 'tis an accident that heaven provides! Dispatch it presently; the hour draws on Prefix'd by Angelo: see this be done, And sent according to command;

src: So you must be the first that gives this sentence, And he, that suffer's. O, it is excellent To have a giant's strength; but it is tyrannous To use it like a giant.
Have done thy charm, thou hateful wither'd hag!
trg: And leave out thee? stay, dog, for thou shalt hear me. The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul! Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou livest, And take deep traitors for thy dearest friends!

src: If to either, thou dost ill.
trg: Neither.

src: Truly, sir, in my poor opinion, they will to't then. If your worship will take order for the drabs and the knaves, you need not to fear the bawds.
trg: There are pretty orders beginning, I can tell you: it is but heading and hanging.

src: Carry me to the gaol!
trg: Stay, officer: he shall not go to prison.

src: Why? For filling a bottle with a tundish. I would the duke we talk of were returned again: the ungenitured agent will unpeople the province with continency;
trg: sparrows must not build in his house-eaves, because they are lecherous. The duke yet would have dark deeds darkly answered; he would never bring them to light: would he were returned!

src: Mistress! what, mistress! Juliet! fast, I warrant her, she: Why, lamb! why, lady! fie, you slug-a-bed! Why, love, I say! madam! sweet-heart! why, bride! What, not a word?
trg: you take your pennyworths now; Sleep for a week; for the next night, I warrant, The County Paris hath set up his rest, That you shall rest but little.

src: So will it, madam till I lie with you.
trg: I hope so.

src: Once more we sit in England's royal throne, Re-purchased with the blood of enemies. What valiant foemen, like to autumn's corn, Have we mow'd down, in tops of all their pride!
trg: Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold renown'd For hardy and undoubted champions; Two Cliffords, as the father and the son, And two Northumberlands;

src: Tell me, for you seem to be honest plain men, what you have to the king:
trg: being something gently considered, I'll bring you where he is aboard, tender your persons to his presence, whisper him in your behalfs;

src: Come, Hastings, help me to my closet. Oh, poor Clarence!
trg: This is the fruit of rashness! Mark'd you not How that the guilty kindred of the queen Look'd pale when they did hear of Clarence' death? O, they did urge it still unto the king! God will revenge it.

src: The time will come when thou shalt wish for me To help thee curse that poisonous bunchback'd toad.
trg: False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse, Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.

src: On safe-guard he came to me; and did curse Against the Volsces, for they had so vilely Yielded the town: he is retired to Antium.
trg: Spoke he of me?

src: I pray thee, mark me. and my trust, Like a good parent, did beget of him A falsehood in its contrary as great As my trust was; which had indeed no limit, A confidence sans bound.
trg: out o' the substitution And executing the outward face of royalty, With all prerogative: hence his ambition growing-- Dost thou hear?

src: Not for myself, Lord Warwick, but my son, Whom I unnaturally shall disinherit. But be it as it may: I here entail The crown to thee and to thine heirs for ever;
trg: This oath I willingly take and will perform.

src: Sham it be put to that?
trg: The gods forbid! I prithee, noble friend, home to thy house; Leave us to cure this cause.

src: Then, England's messenger, return in post, And tell false Edward, thy supposed king, That Lewis of France is sending over masquers To revel it with him and his new bride:
trg: Thou seest what's past, go fear thy king withal.

src: And till she stoop she must not be full-gorged, For then she never looks upon her lure.
trg: Another way I have to man my haggard, To make her come and know her keeper's call, That is, to watch her, as we watch these kites That bate and beat and will not be obedient.

src: Say there be; Yet nature is made better by no mean But nature makes that mean: so, over that art Which you say adds to nature, is an art That nature makes.
trg: You see, sweet maid, we marry A gentler scion to the wildest stock, And make conceive a bark of baser kind By bud of nobler race:

src: This is the hand which, with a vow'd contract, Was fast belock'd in thine; this is the body That took away the match from Isabel, And did supply thee at thy garden-house In her imagined person.
trg: Know you this woman?

src: My traffic is sheets; when the kite builds, look to lesser linen. My father named me Autolycus; who being, as I am, littered under Mercury, was likewise a snapper-up of unconsidered trifles.
trg: With die and drab I purchased this caparison, and my revenue is the silly cheat. Gallows and knock are too powerful on the highway: beating and hanging are terrors to me:

src: Good night. This deed unshapes me quite, makes me unpregnant And dull to all proceedings. A deflower'd maid! And by an eminent body that enforced The law against it!
trg: But that her tender shame Will not proclaim against her maiden loss, How might she tongue me! Yet reason dares her no;

src: Who bare my letter, then, to Romeo?
trg: I could not send it,--here it is again,-- Nor get a messenger to bring it thee, So fearful were they of infection.

src: tell me, that I may sack The hateful mansion.
trg: Hold thy desperate hand: Art thou a man? thy form cries out thou art: Thy tears are womanish; thy wild acts denote The unreasonable fury of a beast: Unseemly woman in a seeming man!

src: Now, by the stock and honour of my kin, To strike him dead, I hold it not a sin.
trg: Why, how now, kinsman! wherefore storm you so?

src: Nor I, but stoop with patience to my fortune.
trg: So part we sadly in this troublous world, To meet with joy in sweet Jerusalem.

src: Though there the people had more absolute power, I say, they nourish'd disobedience, fed The ruin of the state.
trg: Why, shall the people give One that speaks thus their voice?

src: one worse, And better used, would make her sainted spirit Again possess her corpse, and on this stage, Where we're offenders now, appear soul-vex'd, And begin, 'Why to me?'
trg: Had she such power, She had just cause.

src: What misadventure is so early up, That calls our person from our morning's rest?
trg: What should it be, that they so shriek abroad?

src: As I was banish'd, I was banish'd Hereford; But as I come, I come for Lancaster. And, noble uncle, I beseech your grace Look on my wrongs with an indifferent eye:
trg: You are my father, for methinks in you I see old Gaunt alive; O, then, my father, Will you permit that I shall stand condemn'd A wandering vagabond;

src: You live that shall cry woe for this after.
trg: Dispatch; the limit of your lives is out.

src: Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies, And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, With repetition of my Romeo's name.
trg: It is my soul that calls upon my name: How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night, Like softest music to attending ears!

src: I not purpose it. I think, Camillo?
trg: Even he, my lord.

src: Away, you three-inch fool! I am no beast.
trg: Am I but three inches? why, thy horn is a foot; and so long am I at the least.

src: But then a noise did scare me from the tomb; And she, too desperate, would not go with me, But, as it seems, did violence on herself. All this I know; and to the marriage Her nurse is privy:
trg: and, if aught in this Miscarried by my fault, let my old life Be sacrificed, some hour before his time, Unto the rigour of severest law.

src: No, Caius Marcius; I'll lean upon one crutch and fight with t'other, Ere stay behind this business.
trg: O, true-bred!

src: Be ruled by him.
trg: Besides, he tells me that, if peradventure He speak against me on the adverse side, I should not think it strange; for 'tis a physic That's bitter to sweet end.

src: I doubt it not, sir; but you will curse your wooing. Neighbour, this is a gift very grateful, I am sure of it.
trg: To express the like kindness, myself, that have been more kindly beholding to you than any, freely give unto you this young scholar, that hath been long studying at Rheims;

src: They are come. Your mother was most true to wedlock, prince; For she did print your royal father off, Conceiving you:
trg: were I but twenty-one, Your father's image is so hit in you, His very air, that I should call you brother, As I did him, and speak of something wildly By us perform'd before. Most dearly welcome!

src: As if it had lungs and rotten ones.
trg: Or as 'twere perfumed by a fen.

src: As well as Lewis of France, or the Earl of Warwick, Which are so weak of courage and in judgment That they'll take no offence at our abuse.
trg: Suppose they take offence without a cause, They are but Lewis and Warwick: I am Edward, Your king and Warwick's, and must have my will.

src: Well then, I pray, your price o' the consulship?
trg: The price is to ask it kindly.

src: To be imprison'd in the viewless winds, And blown with restless violence round about The pendent world; or to be worse than worst Of those that lawless and incertain thought Imagine howling:
trg: 'tis too horrible! The weariest and most loathed worldly life That age, ache, penury and imprisonment Can lay on nature is a paradise To what we fear of death.

src: Peace, peace; be not so loud.
trg: If that I could for weeping, you should hear,-- Nay, and you shall hear some. Will you be gone?

src: As those that feed grow full, as blossoming time That from the seedness the bare fallow brings To teeming foison, even so her plenteous womb Expresseth his full tilth and husbandry.
trg: Some one with child by him? My cousin Juliet?

src: But is he gracious in the people's eye?
trg: The more that Henry was unfortunate.

src: O Marcius, Marcius! Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart A root of ancient envy.
trg: If Jupiter Should from yond cloud speak divine things, And say 'Tis true,' I'ld not believe them more Than thee, all noble Marcius.

src: But few, And those but mean.
trg: His princess, say you, with him?

src: With other muniments and petty helps In this our fabric, if that they--
trg: What then? 'Fore me, this fellow speaks! What then? what then?

src: The sweetest sleep, and fairest-boding dreams That ever enter'd in a drowsy head, Have I since your departure had, my lords.
trg: Methought their souls, whose bodies Richard murder'd, Came to my tent, and cried on victory: I promise you, my soul is very jocund In the remembrance of so fair a dream.

src: But, Warwick, after God, thou set'st me free, And chiefly therefore I thank God and thee; He was the author, thou the instrument.
trg: Your grace hath still been famed for virtuous; And now may seem as wise as virtuous, By spying and avoiding fortune's malice, For few men rightly temper with the stars:

src: Then fare thee well: I must go buy spices for our sheep-shearing.
trg: Prosper you, sweet sir! Your purse is not hot enough to purchase your spice. I'll be with you at your sheep-shearing too:

src: Please your highness, posts From those you sent to the oracle are come An hour since: Cleomenes and Dion, Being well arrived from Delphos, are both landed, Hasting to the court.
trg: So please you, sir, their speed Hath been beyond account.

src: And wilt thou pluck my fair son from mine age, And rob me of a happy mother's name? Is he not like thee? is he not thine own?
trg: Thou fond mad woman, Wilt thou conceal this dark conspiracy? A dozen of them here have ta'en the sacrament, And interchangeably set down their hands, To kill the king at Oxford.

src: Ay, crook-back, here I stand to answer thee, Or any he the proudest of thy sort.
trg: 'Twas you that kill'd young Rutland, was it not?

src: Whether it like me or no, I am a courtier. Seest thou not the air of the court in these enfoldings? hath not my gait in it the measure of the court? receives not thy nose court-odor from me?
trg: reflect I not on thy baseness court-contempt? Thinkest thou, for that I insinuate, or toaze from thee thy business, I am therefore no courtier? I am courtier cap-a-pe;

src: where we will, not appearing what we are, have some question with the shepherd; from whose simplicity I think it not uneasy to get the cause of my son's resort thither.
trg: Prithee, be my present partner in this business, and lay aside the thoughts of Sicilia.

src: Gremio, 'tis now no time to vent our love: Listen to me, and if you speak me fair, I'll tell you news indifferent good for either.
trg: Here is a gentleman whom by chance I met, Upon agreement from us to his liking, Will undertake to woo curst Katharina, Yea, and to marry her, if her dowry please.

src: Full half an hour.
trg: Go with me to the vault.

src: To your worship's house, sir?
trg: To my house. Fare you well. What's o'clock, think you?

src: Besides, our nearness to the king in love Is near the hate of those love not the king.
trg: And that's the wavering commons: for their love Lies in their purses, and whoso empties them By so much fills their hearts with deadly hate.

src: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.
trg: What, would you have my weapon, little lord?

src: A cold world, Curtis, in every office but thine; and therefore fire: do thy duty, and have thy duty; for my master and mistress are almost frozen to death.
trg: There's fire ready; and therefore, good Grumio, the news.

src: I'll look to like, if looking liking move: But no more deep will I endart mine eye Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.
trg: Madam, the guests are come, supper served up, you called, my young lady asked for, the nurse cursed in the pantry, and every thing in extremity. I must hence to wait; I beseech you, follow straight.

src: Whilst I remember Her and her virtues, I cannot forget My blemishes in them, and so still think of The wrong I did myself;
trg: which was so much, That heirless it hath made my kingdom and Destroy'd the sweet'st companion that e'er man Bred his hopes out of.

src: and their people Will be as rash in the repeal, as hasty To expel him thence. I think he'll be to Rome As is the osprey to the fish, who takes it By sovereignty of nature.
trg: First he was A noble servant to them; but he could not Carry his honours even: whether 'twas pride, Which out of daily fortune ever taints The happy man;

src: Sirrah, here's a fellow will help you to-morrow in your execution. If you think it meet, compound with him by the year, and let him abide here with you;
trg: if not, use him for the present and dismiss him. He cannot plead his estimation with you; he hath been a bawd.

src: But reason with the fellow, Before you punish him, where he heard this, Lest you shall chance to whip your information And beat the messenger who bids beware Of what is to be dreaded.
trg: Tell not me: I know this cannot be.

src: Madam, my instrument's in tune.
trg: Let's hear. O fie! the treble jars.

src: Let AEsop fable in a winter's night; His currish riddles sort not with this place.
trg: By heaven, brat, I'll plague ye for that word.

src: Fool-hardiness; not I.
trg: Nor I.

src: Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the matter. The king, of his own royal disposition, And not provoked by any suitor else;
trg: Aiming, belike, at your interior hatred, Which in your outward actions shows itself Against my kindred, brothers, and myself, Makes him to send;

src: Indeed, you shall not. Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum, See him pluck Aufidius down by the hair, As children from a bear, the Volsces shunning him:
trg: Methinks I see him stamp thus, and call thus: 'Come on, you cowards! you were got in fear, Though you were born in Rome:

src: Whose tongue?
trg: Yours, if you talk of tails: and so farewell.

src: I saw her laid low in her kindred's vault, And presently took post to tell it you: O, pardon me for bringing these ill news, Since you did leave it for my office, sir.
trg: Is it even so? then I defy you, stars! Thou know'st my lodging: get me ink and paper, And hire post-horses; I will hence to-night.

src: I cannot speak So well, nothing so well; no, nor mean better: By the pattern of mine own thoughts I cut out The purity of his.
trg: Take hands, a bargain! And, friends unknown, you shall bear witness to 't: I give my daughter to him, and will make Her portion equal his.

src: I must away to-day, before night come: Make it no wonder; if you knew my business, You would entreat me rather go than stay.
trg: And, honest company, I thank you all, That have beheld me give away myself To this most patient, sweet and virtuous wife: Dine with my father, drink a health to me; For I must hence;

src: Sovereign, here lies the County Paris slain; And Romeo dead; and Juliet, dead before, Warm and new kill'd.
trg: Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.

src: Mark you that?
trg: To brag unto them, thus I did, and thus; Show them the unaching scars which I should hide, As if I had received them for the hire Of their breath only!

src: Take't; 'tis yours. What is't?
trg: I sometime lay here in Corioli At a poor man's house; he used me kindly: He cried to me; I saw him prisoner; But then Aufidius was within my view, And wrath o'erwhelm'd my pity:

src: A match, sir. There's in all two worthy voices begged. I have your alms: adieu.
trg: But this is something odd.

src: Then you should hate Rome, as he does. Can you think to blow out the intended fire your city is ready to flame in, with such weak breath as this? No, you are deceived;
trg: therefore, back to Rome, and prepare for your execution: you are condemned, our general has sworn you out of reprieve and pardon.

src: The children live, whose parents thou hast slaughter'd, Ungovern'd youth, to wail it in their age;
trg: The parents live, whose children thou hast butcher'd, Old wither'd plants, to wail it with their age. Swear not by time to come; for that thou hast Misused ere used, by time misused o'erpast.

src: As much to you, good sister! Whither away?
trg: No farther than the Tower; and, as I guess, Upon the like devotion as yourselves, To gratulate the gentle princes there.

src: A greater gift! O, that's the sword to it.
trg: A gentle cousin, were it light enough.

src: Please your ladyship To visit the next room, I'll presently Acquaint the queen of your most noble offer;
trg: Who but to-day hammer'd of this design, But durst not tempt a minister of honour, Lest she should be denied.

src: Thither will I with you; for little office The hateful commons will perform for us, Except like curs to tear us all to pieces. Will you go along with us?
trg: No; I will to Ireland to his majesty. Farewell: if heart's presages be not vain, We three here art that ne'er shall meet again.

src: My charity is outrage, life my shame And in that shame still live my sorrow's rage.
trg: Have done, have done.

src: I know not, an't like you.
trg: Advocate's the court-word for a pheasant: say you have none.

src: What do you prate of service?
trg: I talk of that, that know it.

src: Destroy'd his country, and his name remains To the ensuing age abhorr'd.' Speak to me, son: Thou hast affected the fine strains of honour, To imitate the graces of the gods;
trg: To tear with thunder the wide cheeks o' the air, And yet to charge thy sulphur with a bolt That should but rive an oak. Why dost not speak?

src: O, my heart!
trg: I'll have thy beauty scratch'd with briers, and made More homely than thy state.

src: here Clarence comes. Brother, good day; what means this armed guard That waits upon your grace?
trg: His majesty Tendering my person's safety, hath appointed This conduct to convey me to the Tower.

src: Why, then you mean not as I thought you did.
trg: But now you partly may perceive my mind.

src: My lord!
trg: How chance the prophet could not at that time Have told me, I being by, that I should kill him?

src: A thousand flatterers sit within thy crown, Whose compass is no bigger than thy head; And yet, incaged in so small a verge, The waste is no whit lesser than thy land.
trg: Why, cousin, wert thou regent of the world, It were a shame to let this land by lease; But for thy world enjoying but this land, Is it not more than shame to shame it so?

src: whom he loves-- He bade me say so--more than all the sceptres And those that bear them living.
trg: O my brother, Good gentleman! the wrongs I have done thee stir Afresh within me, and these thy offices, So rarely kind, are as interpreters Of my behind-hand slackness.

src: And if thine eyes can water for his death, I give thee this to dry thy cheeks withal. Alas poor York! but that I hate thee deadly, I should lament thy miserable state.
trg: I prithee, grieve, to make me merry, York. What, hath thy fiery heart so parch'd thine entrails That not a tear can fall for Rutland's death? Why art thou patient, man? thou shouldst be mad;

src: Hang all the husbands That cannot do that feat, you'll leave yourself Hardly one subject.
trg: Once more, take her hence.

src: Within thine eyes sat twenty thousand deaths, In thy hand clutch'd as many millions, in Thy lying tongue both numbers, I would say 'Thou liest' unto thee with a voice as free As I do pray the gods.
trg: Mark you this, people?

src: A ghostly father, belike. Who knows that Lodowick?
trg: My lord, I know him; 'tis a meddling friar; I do not like the man: had he been lay, my lord For certain words he spake against your grace In your retirement, I had swinged him soundly.

src: Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.
trg: Pray you, who does the wolf love?

src: Let's before as he bids us: he was provided to do us good.
trg: If I had a mind to be honest, I see Fortune would not suffer me: she drops booties in my mouth. I am courted now with a double occasion, gold and a means to do the prince my master good;

src: Nay, good sweet Kate, be merry. Off with my boots, you rogues! you villains, when? It was the friar of orders grey, As he forth walked on his way:-- Out, you rogue! you pluck my foot awry:
trg: Take that, and mend the plucking off the other. Be merry, Kate. Some water, here; what, ho! Where's my spaniel Troilus? Sirrah, get you hence, And bid my cousin Ferdinand come hither:

src: Earl of Northumberland, he slew thy father. And thine, Lord Clifford; and you both have vow'd revenge On him, his sons, his favourites and his friends.
trg: If I be not, heavens be revenged on me!

src: Ha!
trg: I call thee not.

src: With Rosaline, my ghostly father? no; I have forgot that name, and that name's woe.
trg: That's my good son: but where hast thou been, then?

src: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!
trg: For me, that I may surely keep mine oath, I will be married to a wealthy widow, Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.

src: for Mercutio's soul Is but a little way above our heads, Staying for thine to keep him company: Either thou, or I, or both, must go with him.
trg: Thou, wretched boy, that didst consort him here, Shalt with him hence.

src: You have holp to ravish your own daughters and To melt the city leads upon your pates, To see your wives dishonour'd to your noses,--
trg: What's the news? what's the news?

src: What, art thou afraid?
trg: Not to kill him, having a warrant for it; but to be damned for killing him, from which no warrant can defend us.

src: But in what nature?
trg: In such a one as, you consenting to't, Would bark your honour from that trunk you bear, And leave you naked.

src: Acquaint her here of my son Paris' love; And bid her, mark you me, on Wednesday next-- But, soft! what day is this?
trg: Monday, my lord,

src: No lord of thine, thou haught insulting man, Nor no man's lord; I have no name, no title, No, not that name was given me at the font, But 'tis usurp'd:
trg: alack the heavy day, That I have worn so many winters out, And know not now what name to call myself!

src: We have strict statutes and most biting laws. The needful bits and curbs to headstrong weeds, Which for this nineteen years we have let slip;
trg: Even like an o'ergrown lion in a cave, That goes not out to prey.

src: A thousand times the worse, to want thy light. Love goes toward love, as schoolboys from their books, But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.
trg: Hist! Romeo, hist! O, for a falconer's voice, To lure this tassel-gentle back again! Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud;

src: Adieu, sir.
trg: O Perdita, what have we twain forgot! Pray you, a word.

src: When, Harry, when? Obedience bids I should not bid again.
trg: Norfolk, throw down, we bid; there is no boot.

src: Ay, my good lord.
trg: I' fecks! Why, that's my bawcock. What, hast smutch'd thy nose? They say it is a copy out of mine. Come, captain, We must be neat; not neat, but cleanly, captain:

src: Bohemia stops his ears, and threatens them With divers deaths in death.
trg: O my poor father! The heaven sets spies upon us, will not have Our contract celebrated.

src: first, you, my liege, Comes it not something near?
trg: Her natural posture! Chide me, dear stone, that I may say indeed Thou art Hermione; or rather, thou art she In thy not chiding, for she was as tender As infancy and grace.

src: The loss of those three lords torments my heart: I'll write unto them and entreat them fair. Come, cousin you shall be the messenger.
trg: And I, I hope, shall reconcile them all. 3 KING HENRY VI

src: I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as they list.
trg: Nay, as they dare. I will bite my thumb at them; which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.

src: To make an envious mountain on my back, Where sits deformity to mock my body; To shape my legs of an unequal size;
trg: To disproportion me in every part, Like to a chaos, or an unlick'd bear-whelp That carries no impression like the dam. And am I then a man to be beloved? O monstrous fault, to harbour such a thought!

src: My guilt be on my head, and there an end. Take leave and part; for you must part forthwith.
trg: Doubly divorced! Bad men, you violate A twofold marriage, 'twixt my crown and me, And then betwixt me and my married wife. Let me unkiss the oath 'twixt thee and me;

src: but we do learn By those that know the very nerves of state, His givings-out were of an infinite distance From his true-meant design.
trg: Upon his place, And with full line of his authority, Governs Lord Angelo; a man whose blood Is very snow-broth;

src: Talk not, Signior Gremio: I say he shall go to prison.
trg: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catched in this business: I dare swear this is the right Vincentio.

src: Painting, sir, I have heard say, is a mystery; and your whores, sir, being members of my occupation, using painting, do prove my occupation a mystery:
trg: but what mystery there should be in hanging, if I should be hanged, I cannot imagine.

src: Nurse?
trg: Your lady mother is coming to your chamber: The day is broke; be wary, look about.

src: Now, fair befal thee, good Petruchio! The wager thou hast won; and I will add Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns; Another dowry to another daughter, For she is changed, as she had never been.
trg: Nay, I will win my wager better yet And show more sign of her obedience, Her new-built virtue and obedience. See where she comes and brings your froward wives As prisoners to her womanly persuasion.

src: How?
trg: Out of their saddles into the dirt; and thereby hangs a tale.

src: Which to recure, we heartily solicit Your gracious self to take on you the charge And kingly government of this your land, Not as protector, steward, substitute, Or lowly factor for another's gain;
trg: But as successively from blood to blood, Your right of birth, your empery, your own.

src: If by your art, my dearest father, you have Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.
trg: The sky, it seems, would pour down stinking pitch, But that the sea, mounting to the welkin's cheek, Dashes the fire out. O, I have suffered With those that I saw suffer:

src: Some report a sea-maid spawned him; some, that he was begot between two stock-fishes. But it is certain that when he makes water his urine is congealed ice; that I know to be true:
trg: and he is a motion generative; that's infallible.

src: Valiant gentlemen, Let us survey the vantage of the field Call for some men of sound direction Let's want no discipline, make no delay, For, lords, to-morrow is a busy day.
trg: The weary sun hath made a golden set, And by the bright track of his fiery car, Gives signal, of a goodly day to-morrow. Sir William Brandon, you shall bear my standard.
Sweet flower, with flowers thy bridal bed I strew,-- O woe! thy canopy is dust and stones;-- Which with sweet water nightly I will dew, Or, wanting that, with tears distill'd by moans:

src: Unless for that, my liege, I cannot guess.
trg: Unless for that he comes to be your liege, You cannot guess wherefore the Welshman comes. Thou wilt revolt, and fly to him, I fear.

src: If without peril it be possible, Good Captain Blunt, bear my good-night to him, And give him from me this most needful scroll.
trg: Upon my life, my lord, I'll under-take it; And so, God give you quiet rest to-night!

src: Send for the county; go tell him of this: I'll have this knot knit up to-morrow morning.
trg: I met the youthful lord at Laurence' cell; And gave him what becomed love I might, Not step o'er the bounds of modesty.

src: and it is as dangerous to be aged in any kind of course, as it is virtuous to be constant in any undertaking. There is scarce truth enough alive to make societies secure;
trg: but security enough to make fellowships accurst: much upon this riddle runs the wisdom of the world. This news is old enough, yet it is every day's news.

src: Camillo has betray'd me; Whose honour and whose honesty till now Endured all weathers.
trg: Lay't so to his charge: He's with the king your father.

src: I show it most of all when I show justice; For then I pity those I do not know, Which a dismiss'd offence would after gall; And do him right that, answering one foul wrong, Lives not to act another.
trg: Be satisfied; Your brother dies to-morrow; be content.

src: A' has a little gall'd me, I confess; And, as the jest did glance away from me, 'Tis ten to one it maim'd you two outright.
trg: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio, I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

src: Here, my lord.
trg: Fly to the duke: Post thou to Salisbury When thou comest thither-- Dull, unmindful villain, Why stand'st thou still, and go'st not to the duke?

src: a beggar's tongue Make motion through my lips, and my arm'd knees, Who bow'd but in my stirrup, bend like his That hath received an alms!
trg: I will not do't, Lest I surcease to honour mine own truth And by my body's action teach my mind A most inherent baseness.

src: I fear he will. How now, Catesby, what says your lord?
trg: My lord, He wonders to what end you have assembled Such troops of citizens to speak with him, His grace not being warn'd thereof before: My lord, he fears you mean no good to him.

src: And Nero will be tainted with remorse, To hear and see her plaints, her brinish tears. Ay, but she's come to beg, Warwick to give;
trg: She, on his left side, craving aid for Henry, He, on his right, asking a wife for Edward. She weeps, and says her Henry is deposed; He smiles, and says his Edward is install'd;

src: There is thy gold, worse poison to men's souls, Doing more murders in this loathsome world, Than these poor compounds that thou mayst not sell. I sell thee poison; thou hast sold me none. Farewell:
trg: buy food, and get thyself in flesh. Come, cordial and not poison, go with me To Juliet's grave; for there must I use thee.

src: Show those things you found about her, those secret things, all but what she has with her: this being done, let the law go whistle: I warrant you.
trg: I will tell the king all, every word, yea, and his son's pranks too; who, I may say, is no honest man, neither to his father nor to me, to go about to make me the king's brother-in-law.

src: Didst thou not mark the king, what words he spake, 'Have I no friend will rid me of this living fear?' Was it not so?
trg: These were his very words.

src: Cousin, farewell: what presence must not know, From where you do remain let paper show.
trg: My lord, no leave take I; for I will ride, As far as land will let me, by your side.

src: And I'll still stay, to have thee still forget, Forgetting any other home but this.
trg: 'Tis almost morning; I would have thee gone: And yet no further than a wanton's bird;

src: Yea, and much better blood than his or thine.
trg: In all which time you and your husband Grey Were factious for the house of Lancaster; And, Rivers, so were you. Was not your husband In Margaret's battle at Saint Alban's slain?

src: Thou shalt not stir a foot to seek a foe.
trg: Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace, Profaners of this neighbour-stained steel,-- Will they not hear? What, ho! If ever you disturb our streets again, Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace.

src: Sweet father, do so; set it on your head.
trg: Good brother, as thou lovest and honourest arms, Let's fight it out and not stand cavilling thus.

src: Of either, madam.
trg: Of neither, girl: For of joy, being altogether wanting, It doth remember me the more of sorrow; Or if of grief, being altogether had, It adds more sorrow to my want of joy:

src: I saw no man use you a pleasure; if I had, my weapon should quickly have been out, I warrant you: I dare draw as soon as another man, if I see occasion in a good quarrel, and the law on my side.
trg: Now, afore God, I am so vexed, that every part about me quivers. Scurvy knave! Pray you, sir, a word: and as I told you, my young lady bade me inquire you out;

src: O, I am press'd to death through want of speaking! Thou, old Adam's likeness, set to dress this garden, How dares thy harsh rude tongue sound this unpleasing news?
trg: What Eve, what serpent, hath suggested thee To make a second fall of cursed man? Why dost thou say King Richard is deposed? Darest thou, thou little better thing than earth, Divine his downfall?

src: A thousand knees Ten thousand years together, naked, fasting, Upon a barren mountain and still winter In storm perpetual, could not move the gods To look that way thou wert.
trg: Go on, go on Thou canst not speak too much; I have deserved All tongues to talk their bitterest.

src: But with a rear-ward following Tybalt's death, 'Romeo is banished,' to speak that word, Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet, All slain, all dead. 'Romeo is banished!
trg: ' There is no end, no limit, measure, bound, In that word's death; no words can that woe sound. Where is my father, and my mother, nurse?

src: Well, I do so.
trg: Doth your honour see any harm in his face?

src: 'Tis like enough, for I stay dinner there.
ah, the immortal passado! the punto reverso! the hai!
trg: The what?

src: not all so much for love As for another secret close intent, By marrying her which I must reach unto. But yet I run before my horse to market: Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns:
trg: When they are gone, then must I count my gains.

src: Are you there, butcher? O, I cannot speak!
trg: Ay, crook-back, here I stand to answer thee, Or any he the proudest of thy sort.

src: Hang thee, young baggage! disobedient wretch! I tell thee what: get thee to church o' Thursday, Or never after look me in the face: Speak not, reply not, do not answer me; My fingers itch.
trg: Wife, we scarce thought us blest That God had lent us but this only child; But now I see this one is one too much, And that we have a curse in having her: Out on her, hilding!

src: So part we sadly in this troublous world, To meet with joy in sweet Jerusalem.
trg: Is proclamation made, that who finds Edward Shall have a high reward, and he his life?

src: Fear not, sweet wench, they shall not touch thee, Kate: I'll buckler thee against a million.
trg: Nay, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.

src: All pomp and majesty I do forswear; My manors, rents, revenues I forego; My acts, decrees, and statutes I deny: God pardon all oaths that are broke to me!
trg: God keep all vows unbroke that swear to thee! Make me, that nothing have, with nothing grieved, And thou with all pleased, that hast all achieved!

src: The people in the street cry Romeo, Some Juliet, and some Paris; and all run, With open outcry toward our monument.
trg: What fear is this which startles in our ears?

src: God save his majesty!
trg: Long live Gonzalo!

src: We see the ground whereon these woes do lie; But the true ground of all these piteous woes We cannot without circumstance descry.
trg: Here's Romeo's man; we found him in the churchyard.

src: Spoke like a tail fellow that respects his reputation. Come, shall we to this gear?
trg: Take him over the costard with the hilts of thy sword, and then we will chop him in the malmsey-butt in the next room.

src: Ay, if thou wilt say 'ay' to my request; No if thou dost say 'no' to my demand.
trg: Then, no, my lord. My suit is at an end.

src: And to conclude, we have 'greed so well together, That upon Sunday is the wedding-day.
trg: I'll see thee hang'd on Sunday first.
Give me another horse: bind up my wounds. Have mercy, Jesu!--Soft! I did but dream. O coward conscience, how dost thou afflict me! The lights burn blue. It is now dead midnight.

src: O, is it so? But why commands the king That his chief followers lodge in towns about him, While he himself keeps in the cold field?
trg: 'Tis the more honour, because more dangerous.

src: You do but lose your labour. Away with him to death! Now, sir, to you.
trg: O my good lord! Sweet Isabel, take my part; Lend me your knees, and all my life to come I'll lend you all my life to do you service.

src: And why so, my lord?
trg: Not for because Your brows are blacker; yet black brows, they say, Become some women best, so that there be not Too much hair there, but in a semicircle Or a half-moon made with a pen.
I confess the cape.

src: Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.
trg: O, thou art deceived; I would have made it short: for I was come to the whole depth of my tale; and meant, indeed, to occupy the argument no longer.

src: What fear is this which startles in our ears?
trg: Sovereign, here lies the County Paris slain; And Romeo dead; and Juliet, dead before, Warm and new kill'd.

src: Insolent villain!
trg: Kill, kill, kill, kill, kill him!

src: Tell him, myself, the mayor and citizens, In deep designs and matters of great moment, No less importing than our general good, Are come to have some conference with his grace.
trg: I'll tell him what you say, my lord.

src: O, the Fates! How would he look, to see his work so noble Vilely bound up? What would he say? Or how Should I, in these my borrow'd flaunts, behold The sternness of his presence?
trg: Apprehend Nothing but jollity. The gods themselves, Humbling their deities to love, have taken The shapes of beasts upon them: Jupiter Became a bull, and bellow'd;

src: My gracious sovereign?
trg: Give me thy hand. Thus high, by thy advice And thy assistance, is King Richard seated; But shall we wear these honours for a day? Or shall they last, and we rejoice in them?

src: Ay, why not? Grace is grace, despite of all controversy: as, for example, thou thyself art a wicked villain, despite of all grace.
trg: Well, there went but a pair of shears between us.

src: Has said enough.
trg: Has spoken like a traitor, and shall answer As traitors do.

src: Look, here's a letter from him: the state hath another, his wife another; and, I think, there's one at home for you.
trg: I will make my very house reel tonight: a letter for me!

src: He is our cousin, cousin; but 'tis doubt, When time shall call him home from banishment, Whether our kinsman come to see his friends.
trg: Ourself and Bushy, Bagot here and Green Observed his courtship to the common people; Off goes his bonnet to an oyster-wench;

src: But I have reasons strong and forcible.
trg: Why, how now, sons and brother! at a strife? What is your quarrel? how began it first?

src: Kindly! Sir, I pray, let me ha't: I have wounds to show you, which shall be yours in private. Your good voice, sir; what say you?
trg: You shall ha' it, worthy sir.

src: But Romeo may not; he is banished: Flies may do this, but I from this must fly: They are free men, but I am banished. And say'st thou yet that exile is not death?
trg: Hadst thou no poison mix'd, no sharp-ground knife, No sudden mean of death, though ne'er so mean, But 'banished' to kill me?--'banished'? O friar, the damned use that word in hell;
